case_id: 2024-08-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: AI image-generation models allegedly trained on copyrighted artworks without permission, enabling style imitation and infringing outputs.

parties.plaintiff_description: class-action from group of visual artists
parties.defendant_description: AI and online art platforms developing and hosting image generators

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ artworks to train Stable Diffusion and generate infringing images
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motions to dismiss denied in relevant part; direct copyright infringement claims allowed to proceed against all defendants.

claims.claim: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) violations related to removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with training and outputs of Stable Diffusion
claims.outcome: Claims dismissed with prejudice for failure to plead sufficient, legally viable allegations; not allowed to be repleaded.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ alleged benefit from using plaintiffs’ artworks to develop and commercialize AI image-generation services
claims.legal_basis: State common law unjust enrichment (potentially subject to Copyright Act preemption)
claims.outcome: Claims dismissed with leave to amend due to likely preemption and insufficient allegations; plaintiffs permitted to replead.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim for direct copyright infringement regarding training and outputs of Stable Diffusion
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); sufficiency of pleading under the Copyright Act

defenses.defense: DMCA claims inadequately pled because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege removal or alteration of copyright management information with the requisite scienter
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 1202; Rule 12(b)(6) pleading standards

defenses.defense: Unjust enrichment claims are preempted by the Copyright Act and otherwise insufficiently alleged
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption, 17 U.S.C. § 301; Rule 12(b)(6)

defenses.defense: Some asserted state-law and ancillary claims (including unjust enrichment) are duplicative of copyright claims and lack an extra element
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption doctrine and related case law on extra-element test

case_id: 2023-10-30_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and use of AI image generator Stable Diffusion on artists’ copyrighted works.

parties.plaintiff_description: class-action from group of visual artists
parties.defendant_description: AI and online art platforms offering generative image tools

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement by Stability AI for using Andersen’s artworks to train Stable Diffusion without permission.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – direct infringement of exclusive rights in copyrighted works.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to Andersen’s direct infringement claim against Stability AI; this claim proceeds.

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement by Stability AI against McKernan and Ortiz for training Stable Diffusion on their artworks.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – direct infringement of reproduction and related rights.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for insufficiently specific and implausible allegations; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement by DeviantArt and Midjourney based on use of plaintiffs’ works in or via Stable Diffusion–based services.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – direct infringement theory tied to training and output images.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of specific factual allegations connecting defendants to copying of particular works; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Vicarious and/or contributory copyright infringement by all defendants for facilitating or profiting from infringing uses of Stable Diffusion outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Secondary copyright liability under the Copyright Act (contributory and vicarious infringement).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to plausibly allege underlying direct infringement and specific secondary-liability conduct; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Creation and distribution of infringing derivative works by Stable Diffusion outputs that allegedly incorporate plaintiffs’ styles and elements.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – exclusive right to prepare derivative works.
claims.outcome: Dismissed because complaint did not plausibly allege that specific outputs are substantially similar derivative works; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Violation of the DMCA for removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with training data and AI outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 1202 (CIM removal/alteration).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to allege specific instances of removed or altered copyright management information and required scienter; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Violation of the DMCA anti-circumvention provisions by bypassing technological measures protecting plaintiffs’ works to obtain training data.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 1201 (anti-circumvention).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for insufficient allegations of specific technological protection measures and acts of circumvention; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Right of publicity / misappropriation of name or likeness based on use of artists’ names or styles in prompts or marketing.
claims.legal_basis: State right of publicity and misappropriation statutes/common law (likely California).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to allege use of plaintiffs’ actual names or likenesses in a manner covered by the statutes; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and deceptive business practices related to marketing and operation of AI image tools trained on copyrighted works.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law (e.g., California UCL, Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200).
claims.outcome: Dismissed as derivative of deficient copyright/DMCA theories and lacking independent unlawful, unfair, or fraudulent conduct; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ benefit from using plaintiffs’ works to develop and commercialize Stable Diffusion and related services.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable unjust enrichment / restitution under state law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as duplicative of copyright claims and insufficiently pled; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Negligence or related tort theories for failing to prevent misuse of plaintiffs’ works in AI training and outputs.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law (general negligence or similar duty-based claims).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to plausibly allege duty, breach, and non-preempted harm; leave to amend granted.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim due to lack of specific allegations tying particular copyrighted works to copying or outputs.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) – plausibility standard under Twombly/Iqbal.

defenses.defense: Implausibility of theory that Stable Diffusion contains “compressed copies” of training images rather than learned parameters.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) – allegations deemed speculative and inconsistent with how models function.

defenses.defense: Insufficient allegations of substantial similarity or derivative works in AI-generated outputs.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act standards for infringement and derivative works; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Failure to plead elements of DMCA claims, including specific copyright management information and scienter.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 1202 and § 1201 pleading requirements; Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Preemption of state-law claims by the Copyright Act where claims rest on rights equivalent to copyright.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 301 preemption of overlapping state-law causes of action.

defenses.defense: Lack of concrete, non-speculative injury and causation for certain state-law and publicity claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Article III standing and state-law elements of injury and causation.

case_id: 2025-03-19_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training generative AI (Stable Diffusion) on artists’ works without permission.

parties.plaintiff_description: class-action from group of visual artists
parties.defendant_description: AI and tech companies behind Stable Diffusion model

claims.claim: Unauthorized use of plaintiffs’ visual artworks to train the Stable Diffusion generative AI model.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use).
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided in this order; court only resolves discovery and ESI protocol disputes, allowing case to proceed.

claims.claim: Widespread copying and exploitation of copyrighted works at large scale through AI training datasets.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and related rights in connection with mass copying for AI training.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; court addresses only discovery scope and mechanics, not liability or damages.

defenses.defense: Discovery, including ESI and depositions, should be limited to reduce burden on defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure proportionality and burden limits on discovery.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court partially agrees; sets structured ESI protocol and limits depositions to thirty instead of sixty.

case_id: 2024-02-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03223_Tremblay et al v. OpenAI_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Tremblay et al. v. OpenAI, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training and operation of OpenAI’s ChatGPT AI model using copyrighted books without authorization.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors bringing putative class action lawsuit.
parties.defendant_description: AI company and related entities operating ChatGPT.

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ books to train OpenAI’s AI language models (including ChatGPT) without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act – direct infringement (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in relevant part; claim allowed to proceed at pleading stage.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement arising from OpenAI’s alleged control over and financial benefit from infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works by its AI models and users.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act – vicarious infringement (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for insufficient allegations; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) for removal or alteration of copyright management information in connection with use of plaintiffs’ works in training data and outputs.
claims.legal_basis: DMCA, including 17 U.S.C. § 1202.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for lack of sufficient factual detail; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Negligence based on OpenAI’s alleged failure to exercise reasonable care in acquiring, handling, and using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to develop and deploy its AI models.
claims.legal_basis: California common-law negligence (duty, breach, causation, damages).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss; court found insufficient basis for a negligence duty; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment / restitution for benefits OpenAI allegedly obtained by using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works without compensation.
claims.legal_basis: California unjust enrichment / quasi-contract / restitution principles.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss as inadequately pled; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on “unfair” business practices in using copyrighted books without consent to train AI models and commercially exploiting resulting products.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 – “unfair” prong.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; court held allegations could support an “unfair” UCL claim, allowing it to proceed.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on “unlawful” and/or “fraudulent” prongs of the UCL tied to other alleged statutory and common-law violations.
claims.legal_basis: California UCL, Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 – “unlawful” and “fraudulent” prongs.
claims.outcome: Dismissed to the extent predicated on claims the court dismissed (e.g., vicarious infringement, DMCA, negligence, unjust enrichment); leave to amend granted to reallege with sufficient supporting violations.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for direct copyright infringement, including insufficient allegations that training or outputs infringe exclusive rights.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); substantive copyright pleading standards under 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for vicarious copyright infringement due to inadequate allegations of right and ability to supervise and direct financial benefit from specific infringing acts.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); vicarious infringement doctrine under federal copyright law.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a DMCA claim because plaintiffs did not plausibly allege removal or alteration of copyright management information with the requisite scienter.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); 17 U.S.C. § 1202 pleading requirements.

defenses.defense: Negligence claim barred or inadequately pled because OpenAI owed no cognizable tort duty regarding use of copyrighted works in model training and deployment.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); California negligence and economic loss doctrines.

defenses.defense: Unjust enrichment not an independent cause of action or inadequately supported by facts showing unjust retention of a benefit at plaintiffs’ expense.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); California unjust enrichment / restitution law.

defenses.defense: UCL claims insufficient because plaintiffs failed to allege actionable “unlawful,” “unfair,” or “fraudulent” conduct with particularity and failed to tether “unfair” theory to established public policy or balancing test.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200 and related case law.

case_id: 2019-11-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_19-cv-03132_UAB _Planner5D_ v. Meta Platforms_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: UAB Planner5D v. Meta Platforms, Inc. (Facebook) et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on scraped 3D data used to train AI scene-recognition systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Company providing online 3D interior design tools
parties.defendant_name: Meta Platforms, Inc.; Princeton University, et al.
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and university alleged data scrapers

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged unauthorized copying and use of Planner 5D’s 3D design objects and scenes dataset via automated scraping.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act, including 17 U.S.C. § 501 and registration requirements under 17 U.S.C. § 411(a).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court held plaintiff failed to sufficiently allege valid copyright registrations, originality, and specific infringing acts, but granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Contributory and/or vicarious copyright infringement for facilitating or benefiting from third-party use of the scraped 3D design data.
claims.legal_basis: Secondary copyright liability doctrines under the U.S. Copyright Act and related case law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice along with primary copyright claims; insufficient underlying infringement allegations, with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Trade secret misappropriation based on alleged scraping, copying, and use of proprietary 3D design data and dataset structure.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA), 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq., and/or state trade secret law (e.g., California Uniform Trade Secrets Act).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; court found plaintiff did not adequately allege reasonable measures to maintain secrecy or sufficiently plead improper acquisition, use, or disclosure; leave to amend granted.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for copyright infringement, including lack of adequately pled registration, originality, and specific infringing conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); requirements under 17 U.S.C. §§ 101, 102, 411, and relevant case law on pleading copyright infringement.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for trade secret misappropriation because the alleged information was not plausibly secret and reasonable secrecy measures were not sufficiently alleged.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Defend Trade Secrets Act and state trade secret statutes requiring existence of a trade secret and reasonable measures to maintain secrecy.

defenses.defense: Failure to adequately allege improper acquisition, use, or disclosure of trade secrets by defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: DTSA and state trade secret law elements requiring misappropriation through improper means or unauthorized use/disclosure.

case_id: 2025-06-25_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Use of copyrighted books to train Meta’s Llama generative AI models; fair use of AI training data at issue.

parties.plaintiff_description: Group of individual author copyright holders
parties.defendant_description: Large technology and social media corporation

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Meta’s use of plaintiffs’ books as training data for Llama generative AI models.
claims.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 106 (exclusive rights of copyright owners), alleging unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works.
claims.outcome: Court granted Meta’s motion for partial summary judgment; held Meta’s training use of the books was protected as fair use, so this infringement theory failed.

claims.claim: Derivative works infringement, alleging that outputs of the Llama models constitute infringing derivative works of plaintiffs’ books.
claims.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 106(2) (exclusive right to prepare derivative works).
claims.outcome: To the extent addressed in the motion, the court found plaintiffs had not shown actionable infringement via model outputs and granted summary judgment for Meta on this theory.

claims.claim: Market harm and lost licensing opportunities from unlicensed use of books for AI training.
claims.legal_basis: Fair use factor four under 17 U.S.C. § 107 (effect of the use upon the potential market).
claims.outcome: Court held plaintiffs failed to provide sufficient evidence of actual or likely market harm or a cognizable licensing market; this favored Meta and supported summary judgment for Meta on fair use.

defenses.defense: Fair use based on transformative use of books to train Llama models.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107; use was highly transformative, for machine learning rather than human-readable substitution.

defenses.defense: Lack of evidence of market harm from AI training use.
defenses.legal_basis: Fourth fair use factor under 17 U.S.C. § 107; plaintiffs failed to show actual or potential market harm or a traditional, likely-to-be-developed licensing market.

defenses.defense: No substantial similarity or direct copying in model outputs constituting infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: General copyright infringement standards requiring copying of protectable expression and substantial similarity; plaintiffs did not show infringing outputs tied to their specific works.

case_id: 2025-07-30_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-04534_Sage Global Services Limited et al v. 4th Paradigm _Beijing_ Technology Co._ Ltd..pdf
case_name: Sage Global Services Limited et al. v. 4th Paradigm (Beijing) Technology Co., Ltd.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves software and AI products branded with the SAGE mark.

parties.plaintiff_name: Sage Global Services Limited; Sage Software, Inc.
parties.plaintiff_description: Related corporate software companies asserting SAGE trademark rights.
parties.defendant_description: Chinese technology company offering software and AI products.

claims.claim: Trademark infringement based on defendant’s use of the SAGE mark in connection with software and AI products.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. trademark law (likely Lanham Act) protecting the SAGE mark against unauthorized use causing confusion.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found no personal jurisdiction over the defendant.

claims.claim: Related trademark and unfair competition claims arising from alleged unauthorized use of the SAGE mark in commerce.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state unfair competition and trademark statutes and common law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction; court did not adjudicate liability or damages.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in California and the United States.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and personal jurisdiction doctrines requiring sufficient minimum contacts for general or specific jurisdiction.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court held it lacked personal jurisdiction and granted motion to dismiss.

case_id: 2024-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03417_Kadrey et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Kadrey et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training Meta’s Llama large language models on copyrighted books without permission.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual author alleging copyright infringement by AI training use
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating and developing Llama AI models

claims.claim: Meta used plaintiffs’ copyrighted books without authorization to train Llama AI models.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (unauthorized reproduction/use).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; discovery motion to compel partially granted to obtain information about training data and model development.

claims.claim: Meta failed to provide adequate discovery about datasets and copyrighted works used to train Llama models, including which books were used and how.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure discovery obligations (Rules 26, 34, 36).
claims.outcome: Court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs’ motions to compel; Meta ordered to provide fuller responses and documents for certain requests.

claims.claim: Meta’s responses to Requests for Admission were evasive, incomplete, or improperly objected to, hindering proof of training-data facts.
claims.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 (Requests for Admission) and related discovery rules.
claims.outcome: Court ordered Meta to amend several RFA responses, clarify admissions/denials, and correct overbroad objections; other RFAs left as originally answered.

claims.claim: Meta improperly limited discovery by excluding later Llama versions (e.g., Llama 5) from the scope of definitions and responses.
claims.legal_basis: Relevance and proportionality under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1).
claims.outcome: Court required Meta to include Llama 5 within discovery definitions and to supplement responses accordingly.

claims.claim: Meta improperly produced summaries or partial information instead of full underlying documents responsive to plaintiffs’ requests for production.
claims.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 34 (production of documents) and duty to produce responsive materials.
claims.outcome: Court compelled Meta to produce full documents, not just summaries or limited excerpts, for certain specified requests; other requests were denied as overbroad or not proportional.

defenses.defense: Meta’s existing discovery responses and objections are sufficient, and additional information sought is irrelevant, overbroad, or disproportionate to the needs of the case.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1) (relevance and proportionality) and general discovery standards.

defenses.defense: Certain requested information or documents are not reasonably accessible, unduly burdensome to collect, or not maintained in the form demanded by plaintiffs.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(2)(B) (undue burden/inaccessibility).

defenses.defense: Some requests for admission are vague, ambiguous, or call for legal conclusions rather than facts, justifying objections or qualified responses.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 36 (scope and form of RFAs).

defenses.defense: Meta may rely on public or licensed datasets and fair use or other copyright defenses to justify training its Llama models on text data, including books.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. copyright law defenses, including fair use under 17 U.S.C. § 107 (substantive defense, not decided in this discovery order).

case_id: 2025-08-19_USCOURTS-ded-1_24-cv-01092_Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co._ Ltd et al v. Anaconda_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Hangzhou Jicai Procurement Co., Ltd. et al. v. Anaconda, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns contracts for Anaconda’s AI technology software and related use.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate entities linked to Alibaba using Anaconda AI software
parties.defendant_description: Software company providing AI and data science tools

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Plaintiffs have not breached the Anaconda Agreements and that the agreements are invalid or unenforceable as to them.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act; contract law principles regarding validity and breach of the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; court held no subject matter jurisdiction and did not reach the merits of contract validity or breach.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Anaconda’s pending Texas breach of contract litigation against other Alibaba entities does not create liability, obligations, or legal exposure for Jicai and AliCloud under the Anaconda Agreements.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act; Article III case-or-controversy requirement; contract interpretation regarding parties bound by agreements.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of Article III standing; court found no immediate, real, or substantial threat of injury to Plaintiffs from the Texas litigation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs lack Article III standing because they are not parties to the Anaconda Agreements at issue in the Texas breach of contract suit and have no adverse legal interests with Anaconda.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution Article III case-or-controversy requirement; standing doctrine (injury in fact, causation, redressability).

defenses.defense: No immediate, substantial, or real threat of future harm to Plaintiffs from Anaconda’s Texas litigation against other Alibaba entities, so no justiciable controversy exists for declaratory relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Declaratory Judgment Act justiciability requirements; federal standing and ripeness doctrines.

case_id: 2025-01-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al. v. NVIDIA Corporation (consolidated with Dubus v. NVIDIA Inc.)
ai_relevance: Protective order governs disclosure of proprietary AI and ML source code.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals bringing civil actions against NVIDIA
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation developing AI and GPU products

claims.claim: Substantive civil claims by plaintiffs against NVIDIA (details not specified in the protective-order opinion).
claims.legal_basis: Underlying causes of action not described in the provided summary; opinion addresses only discovery confidentiality procedures.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling; court issues stipulated protective order governing confidential discovery materials.

claims.claim: Request for court order to protect confidential and highly confidential discovery material, including AI-related proprietary technology and source code.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(c) (protective orders) and related local rules governing confidentiality and sealing of court records.
claims.outcome: Granted; court enters stipulated protective order specifying designations, access limits, handling, and filing procedures for Confidential and Highly Confidential material.

defenses.defense: Need to prevent public and competitive disclosure of NVIDIA’s proprietary AI technology, trade secrets, and source code.
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary information protections under FRCP 26(c) and general principles protecting confidential commercial information in discovery.

defenses.defense: Litigation can proceed fairly while restricting access to sensitive technical materials to only those who need to know under a structured protective regime.
defenses.legal_basis: Balancing test under FRCP 26(c) between discovery needs and burden/harms from disclosure, as applied through stipulated protective orders.

case_id: 2025-07-15_USCOURTS-ded-1_25-cv-00201_Aon Re_ Inc. v. Zesty.ai_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Aon Re, Inc. v. Zesty.ai, Inc.
ai_relevance: Patents cover machine-learning models analyzing aerial images for property risk.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering reinsurance and risk analytics services
parties.defendant_description: Technology company using AI for property risk analytics

claims.claim: Patent infringement of Aon’s patents covering machine-learning methods that analyze aerial property images to assess risk.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on asserted patents involving ML-based risk assessment from aerial imagery.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; at motion-to-dismiss stage the court did not dismiss based on § 101 invalidity, allowing the infringement claims to proceed.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents are invalid because they are directed to the abstract idea of risk assessment implemented with generic machine learning.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligibility; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo).

defenses.defense: The patents merely claim the generalized use of computers and machine learning to perform conventional risk assessment, lacking an inventive concept.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 and Alice/Mayo framework requiring more than generic computer implementation.

case_id: 2022-09-21_USCOURTS-cand-3_22-cv-02366_Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Shared Partnership v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Canadian online content creator business
parties.defendant_description: Social media and online advertising corporation

claims.claim: Breach of contract for restricting or terminating Shared’s access to Facebook advertising and monetization services contrary to agreed terms.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; alleged violation of Facebook/Meta terms and related agreements.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed; aspects tied directly to content removal barred by Section 230(c)(1), but contract-based procedural obligations (e.g., notice, timing of payments) allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failure to provide adequate notice of restrictions, account actions, and ad rejections as required by Meta’s contractual terms and policies.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law; duties arising from Facebook/Meta terms of service and advertising policies.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to these procedural-breach theories; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Misrepresentation related to Meta’s promises or statements about access to advertising and monetization services and how restrictions or enforcement would be handled.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law (fraud/negligent misrepresentation) based on alleged false or misleading statements in Meta’s policies and communications.
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed to the extent premised on content-removal decisions covered by Section 230(c)(1); any surviving theories limited to non–content-removal, contractual-procedure aspects.

claims.claim: Claims seeking liability for Meta’s decisions to remove, restrict, or limit the distribution of Shared’s content on Facebook.
claims.legal_basis: Various state-law theories (including contract and tort) challenging Meta’s moderation and distribution decisions.
claims.outcome: Dismissed as barred by Section 230(c)(1) of the Communications Decency Act; Meta immune for content-removal and restriction decisions.

defenses.defense: Section 230(c)(1) immunity bars claims based on Meta’s decisions to remove, restrict, or limit the distribution of user content.
defenses.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 230(c)(1) (Communications Decency Act) providing immunity to interactive computer service providers for publishing decisions regarding third-party content.

defenses.defense: Contractual rights to moderate and restrict content and accounts under Facebook/Meta terms of service.
defenses.legal_basis: Express provisions in Meta’s user and advertising agreements reserving broad discretion over content and account enforcement.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for misrepresentation because alleged statements are non-actionable (e.g., vague, aspirational, or not justifiably relied upon).
defenses.legal_basis: State tort law standards for fraud and negligent misrepresentation pleading sufficiency (e.g., Rule 9(b) particularity and elements of reliance and falsity).

case_id: 2022-12-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-08570_Klein et al v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Klein et al. v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege Meta used AI/ML ad tools to maintain advertising monopoly and inflate ad prices.

parties.plaintiff_description: Class of Facebook advertisers alleging antitrust violations
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating Facebook social advertising platform

claims.claim: Meta unlawfully monopolized the social advertising market, leading to inflated ad prices for Facebook advertisers.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – monopolization and maintenance of monopoly power in the social advertising market.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; monopolization claim allowed to proceed based on plausible allegations, including AI/ML-related conduct.

claims.claim: Meta engaged in anticompetitive conduct to maintain its dominance in social advertising, including use of AI and machine learning systems to entrench its position and exclude rivals.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – unlawful maintenance of monopoly through exclusionary and anticompetitive practices.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court found allegations of exclusionary conduct, including AI/ML integration, sufficient to move forward to discovery.

claims.claim: Meta entered into agreements and engaged in coordinated practices that restrained trade and harmed competition in the social advertising market, resulting in supracompetitive prices for advertisers.
claims.legal_basis: Section 1 of the Sherman Act – unreasonable restraints of trade through contracts, combinations, or conspiracies affecting social advertising.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; Section 1 claims sustained as plausibly alleging anticompetitive agreements and restraints.

defenses.defense: The complaint fails to state a claim because plaintiffs have not plausibly alleged monopoly power, anticompetitive conduct, or harm to competition in a properly defined relevant market.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); substantive standards under Sections 1 and 2 of the Sherman Act.

defenses.defense: Meta’s conduct, including integration of AI and machine learning into its advertising platform, reflects lawful product improvement and competition on the merits, not exclusionary or anticompetitive behavior.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust law principle that procompetitive or innovative conduct, even by a dominant firm, is not unlawful under the Sherman Act.

defenses.defense: Any alleged price effects or advertiser harms are the result of legitimate business decisions and market forces, not unlawful restraints or monopolization.
defenses.legal_basis: Sherman Act requirements of anticompetitive effect and injury to competition, not merely to individual competitors or customers.

case_id: 2024-12-20_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-10723_In Re Cerence Stockholder Derivative Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Cerence Stockholder Derivative Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-powered virtual assistants for automakers developed by Cerence.

parties.plaintiff_description: Shareholders bringing derivative action on company’s behalf
parties.defendant_description: Corporate officers and directors of Cerence, Inc.

claims.claim: Violation of the Exchange Act in connection with Cerence’s disclosures and conduct.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities law – Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for improper forum denied; Exchange Act-based derivative claims may proceed in federal court under Bylaws’ forum clause.

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty by Cerence officers and directors to the company and its shareholders.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law fiduciary duties (duty of care, loyalty, good faith).
claims.outcome: Not dismissed on forum grounds; case allowed to proceed in current federal forum.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment arising from alleged wrongful conduct and benefits received by defendants.
claims.legal_basis: State common law doctrine of unjust enrichment.
claims.outcome: Not dismissed on forum grounds; claim may proceed in federal court with derivative action.

claims.claim: Insider trading by certain Cerence insiders based on material nonpublic information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities law and related state-law derivative insider trading theories.
claims.outcome: Not dismissed on forum grounds; insider trading-based derivative claims may proceed in federal court.

defenses.defense: Forum-selection clause in Cerence’s Charter requires derivative actions to be brought exclusively in Delaware state courts.
defenses.legal_basis: Contractual/forum-selection enforcement principles under Delaware corporate law and federal forum non conveniens doctrine.

defenses.defense: Federal court is an improper forum for derivative claims due to Charter’s exclusive Delaware forum provision, warranting dismissal.
defenses.legal_basis: Motion to dismiss based on improper venue/forum and deference to corporate charter provisions.

case_id: 2025-10-22_USCOURTS-cand-4_25-cv-09081_Pete v. Facebook Data Breach __Transferred to ND_CA__.pdf
case_name: Pete v. Meta Platforms, Inc. (Facebook Data Breach)
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer alleging data breach harm
parties.defendant_description: Large social media technology corporation

claims.claim: Meta is liable for harms arising from a Facebook data breach affecting plaintiff’s personal information.
claims.legal_basis: Implied federal and/or state data privacy, negligence, and related data breach liability theories (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Substantive merits not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California for further proceedings.

claims.claim: The Eastern District of Texas should retain the case and not transfer it to the Northern District of California.
claims.legal_basis: Plaintiff’s objections to transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1631 and interest-of-justice considerations, including financial hardship and pro se status.
claims.outcome: Rejected; court overruled objections and upheld transfer to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: The Eastern District of Texas lacks personal jurisdiction over Meta.
defenses.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction doctrine under Due Process Clause and federal venue/transfer statutes, including 28 U.S.C. § 1631.

defenses.defense: Transfer to the Northern District of California is proper and in the interest of justice.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1631 and interest-of-justice factors, including Meta’s location and relevant forum-selection expectations.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s financial hardship and pro se status do not justify keeping the case in Texas.
defenses.legal_basis: Application of transfer and jurisdiction principles; equitable and interest-of-justice analysis under 28 U.S.C. § 1631, which does not prioritize convenience or hardship over lack of jurisdiction.

case_id: 2025-10-20_USCOURTS-mad-3_23-cv-13196_Demand Dogs_ LLC v. Blair.pdf
case_name: Demand Dogs, LLC v. Blair
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company business entity
parties.defendant_description: Individual alleged bourbon-monitoring technology inventor

claims.claim: Correction of inventorship and recognition of Blair as an inventor of the bourbon-monitoring technology covered by the nonprovisional patent filed by Barrel Proof
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law, including 35 U.S.C. § 256 (correction of inventorship)
claims.outcome: Court held Blair’s proposed amended third-party complaint states a sufficient inventorship claim and granted leave to file it against Barrel Proof

claims.claim: Ownership and related rights in the patented bourbon-monitoring technology allegedly derived from Blair’s original invention
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law on ownership of inventions and related state-law ownership principles
claims.outcome: Court found Blair’s allegations of ownership interests sufficient at the pleading stage and allowed amendment to add Barrel Proof as a third-party defendant

claims.claim: Assertion of personal jurisdiction over Barrel Proof, a Tennessee LLC, based on activities in Massachusetts related to developing the patented invention
claims.legal_basis: Due process and Massachusetts long-arm statute standards for specific personal jurisdiction
claims.outcome: Court concluded Blair sufficiently alleged facts supporting personal jurisdiction over Barrel Proof and therefore permitted the amended third-party complaint to proceed

defenses.defense: Challenge to personal jurisdiction over Barrel Proof in Massachusetts because it is a Tennessee LLC
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction and state long-arm statute requirements

defenses.defense: Denial that Blair is an inventor or owner of the patented bourbon-monitoring technology, asserting that the invention belongs to Barrel Proof and its principals
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive patent law standards for inventorship and ownership of patented inventions

defenses.defense: Procedural objection to Blair’s earlier attempt to add Barrel Proof as a third-party defendant for failure to comply with applicable procedural rules
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing amendment and joinder of third-party defendants

case_id: 2025-05-16_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00770_Mobley v. Workday_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mobley v. Workday, Inc.
ai_relevance: Claims that Workday’s AI applicant-screening system causes age-based disparate impact.

parties.plaintiff_description: Job applicants bringing collective age discrimination claims
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing AI hiring and screening software

claims.claim: Age discrimination against applicants over forty via AI-based applicant recommendation system causing disparate impact.
claims.legal_basis: Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA) – disparate impact theory, collective action under 29 U.S.C. § 216(b).
claims.outcome: Court granted preliminary collective certification for the ADEA disparate impact claim, allowing notice to similarly situated applicants over forty; merits not yet decided.

claims.claim: Discrimination based on race via Workday’s AI applicant recommendation system.
claims.legal_basis: Federal anti-discrimination laws (likely Title VII of the Civil Rights Act) – disparate impact and/or disparate treatment theories.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this stage in the described order; court’s ruling focused on preliminary collective certification of the age-based ADEA claim only.

claims.claim: Discrimination based on disability via Workday’s AI applicant recommendation system.
claims.legal_basis: Federal disability discrimination laws (likely Americans with Disabilities Act and/or Rehabilitation Act) – disparate impact and/or disparate treatment theories.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this stage in the described order; court’s ruling focused on preliminary collective certification of the age-based ADEA claim only.

defenses.defense: Workday’s AI applicant recommendation system does not constitute a unified discriminatory policy causing disparate impact on applicants over forty.
defenses.legal_basis: Challenge to collective certification under ADEA and 29 U.S.C. § 216(b), arguing lack of similarity/commonality among proposed collective members.

defenses.defense: Any disparities in outcomes are not caused by age discrimination but by legitimate, non-discriminatory factors embedded in the hiring process.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive defenses under ADEA disparate impact framework, including business necessity and lack of causation between AI system and alleged age-based disparities.

case_id: 2025-07-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-00201_Andersen et al v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.pdf
case_name: Andersen et al. v. Stability AI Ltd. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over access to confidential AI image-generation model source code and materials.

parties.plaintiff_description: class-action from group of visual artists
parties.defendant_description: AI companies operating generative image models

claims.claim: Plaintiffs seek to disclose defendants’ highly confidential materials, including AI model source code, to their expert Dr. Ben Yanbin Zhao for use in this litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Protective order and discovery rules permitting expert access to confidential information when reasonably necessary for case preparation.
claims.outcome: Denied. Court held competitive harm risk to defendants outweighs plaintiffs’ need; Dr. Zhao may not access highly confidential materials.

defenses.defense: Disclosure of highly confidential materials, including AI source code, to Dr. Zhao would create an unacceptable risk of competitive harm because of his research and tools that could affect defendants’ AI models.
defenses.legal_basis: Protective order standards and Rule 26 balancing of need for discovery against risk of competitive injury and misuse of trade secrets.

case_id: 2025-08-21_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-01454_Nazemian et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Nazemian et al. v. NVIDIA Corporation
ai_relevance: Dispute over training large language AI models on copyrighted books.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual authors alleging copyright infringement by AI training
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation developing NeMo Megatron AI models

claims.claim: NVIDIA infringed plaintiffs’ copyrights by using their books contained in the dataset “The Pile” to train NeMo Megatron large language models without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (exclusive rights to reproduce and prepare derivative works).
claims.outcome: On the discovery motion, court allowed targeted discovery into NVIDIA’s use of “The Pile” to train NeMo Megatron models, including models beyond the four initially identified; ultimate merits of infringement claim not yet decided.

defenses.defense: Limitation of discovery to only the four specifically identified NeMo Megatron models, based on NVIDIA’s characterization of those models as a single “family.”
defenses.legal_basis: Civil procedure and proportional discovery limits under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

case_id: 2022-04-26_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on AI-powered legal research tool, specifically the one trained on Westlaw case data to generate summaries (likely LLM) competing with Westlaw.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate publishers of Westlaw legal research platform
parties.defendant_description: Technology company offering AI legal research tool

claims.claim: Copyright infringement against ROSS for using Westlaw content to train and develop its competing legal research tool.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (Copyright Act).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this opinion; motion to dismiss addressed only ROSS’s counterclaims, not plaintiffs’ infringement claims.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with contractual relations based on ROSS allegedly inducing a third-party vendor to breach contracts with plaintiffs regarding Westlaw content.
claims.legal_basis: State tort law on tortious interference with contract.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this opinion; plaintiffs’ underlying tort claim remains pending while court rules on ROSS’s counterclaims.

claims.claim: Antitrust violation under Section 1 of the Sherman Act for unlawful tying of Westlaw’s public law database to plaintiffs’ legal search tool, restraining competition from ROSS and others.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 1 (unlawful tying and unreasonable restraint of trade).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; tying-based Section 1 claim allowed to proceed as plausibly alleged.

claims.claim: Antitrust violation under Section 2 of the Sherman Act for monopolization and attempted monopolization through tying Westlaw’s public law database to plaintiffs’ legal search tool and excluding rivals like ROSS.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 2 (monopolization and attempted monopolization via tying and exclusionary conduct).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied in part; tying-related Section 2 claim allowed to proceed as plausibly alleged.

claims.claim: Antitrust violation under Section 1 of the Sherman Act based on sham litigation theory, alleging plaintiffs’ copyright and related suits were baseless and intended to suppress competition from ROSS.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 1 (sham litigation as anticompetitive conduct; Noerr-Pennington exception).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found ROSS failed to plead specific, plausible facts showing objectively baseless litigation.

claims.claim: Antitrust violation under Section 2 of the Sherman Act based on sham litigation, alleging plaintiffs used baseless lawsuits to maintain or acquire monopoly power in legal research markets.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 2 (monopolization via sham litigation; Noerr-Pennington exception).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held allegations insufficient to plausibly show sham litigation under the two-prong test.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and related state-law claims premised on plaintiffs’ allegedly anticompetitive tying practices and exclusionary conduct in legal research markets.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition and similar business tort statutes (exact state law not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Survives in part to the extent grounded in the same tying and exclusionary conduct that the court found plausibly alleged; any portion premised solely on sham litigation dismissed.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and related state-law claims premised on sham litigation, alleging plaintiffs’ lawsuits were filed to harass and drive ROSS from the market.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition and business tort law incorporating sham litigation theories.
claims.outcome: Dismissed to the extent based on sham litigation, for the same reasons the federal sham litigation antitrust claims were dismissed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ lawsuits are protected petitioning activity and not sham litigation, thus immune from antitrust liability under Noerr-Pennington.
defenses.legal_basis: Noerr-Pennington doctrine and its sham-litigation exception under federal antitrust law.

defenses.defense: ROSS failed to plausibly allege that the litigation was objectively baseless or subjectively intended solely to interfere with competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Supreme Court sham-litigation standard (e.g., Professional Real Estate Investors) applied to Sherman Act claims.

defenses.defense: ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims based on tying are inadequately pled because plaintiffs’ products and markets are not properly defined and no unlawful tying is shown.
defenses.legal_basis: Sherman Act §§ 1–2 requirements for product market definition, market power, and coercive tying arrangements.

defenses.defense: ROSS’s unfair competition and related state-law counterclaims fail to state a claim where they merely repackage deficient antitrust or sham litigation theories.
defenses.legal_basis: State-law pleading standards and derivative nature of unfair competition claims tied to federal antitrust theories.

case_id: 2025-02-11_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Defendant used AI legal research tool trained on plaintiffs’ copyrighted headnotes.

parties.plaintiff_description: Publisher of Westlaw legal research platform
parties.defendant_description: Developer of AI-based legal research tool

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement of Westlaw headnotes and related content
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq., exclusive rights of reproduction and derivative works
claims.outcome: Court granted partial summary judgment for Thomson Reuters, holding ROSS directly infringed copyrights in Westlaw headnotes; only issue of whether some copyrights had expired left for trial.

claims.claim: Rejection of ROSS’s fair use defense to copying Westlaw headnotes for AI training
claims.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under 17 U.S.C. § 107
claims.outcome: Court held ROSS’s use was not fair use as a matter of law and granted summary judgment for Thomson Reuters on this defense.

claims.claim: Infringement claims as to works potentially in the public domain
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, including requirement of valid, unexpired copyright
claims.outcome: Court left factual determination of which works’ copyrights had expired for trial; no summary judgment on that limited subset.

defenses.defense: Fair use based on transformative AI training and legal research functionality
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 fair use factors (purpose, nature, amount, market effect)

defenses.defense: Challenge to validity or subsistence of copyrights in certain older headnotes
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act requirements for valid, unexpired copyright protection

defenses.defense: Argument that indirect acquisition of headnotes (via third parties) limited liability
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act standards for direct infringement and volitional conduct

case_id: 2024-09-27_USCOURTS-ded-1_20-cv-00613_Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al v. ROSS Intelligence Inc..pdf
case_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al. v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over use of legal database to develop competing AI legal search tool.

parties.plaintiff_name: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate owners of Westlaw legal research database and tools.
parties.defendant_description: Company developing AI-based legal research search platform.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on ROSS’s use of Thomson Reuters’ legal database to develop a competing AI-based legal search tool.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (alleged unauthorized copying and use of Westlaw content and related materials).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in the provided summary; case summary focuses only on antitrust counterclaims, not final disposition of copyright claims.

claims.claim: Antitrust tying—allegation that Thomson Reuters illegally tied its legal search tool to its legal database, foreclosing competition from independent search providers like ROSS.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law, including Sherman Act §1 tying doctrine (unlawful tying arrangement and exclusionary conduct).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Thomson Reuters; court held ROSS failed to show separate products or properly define relevant product and geographic markets, so antitrust tying counterclaims were dismissed.

claims.claim: Antitrust monopolization / attempted monopolization (implicit in antitrust counterclaims) based on Thomson Reuters’ alleged use of its database dominance to maintain monopoly power in legal search tools.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law, likely Sherman Act §2 (monopolization and maintenance of monopoly power).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Thomson Reuters on ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims due to insufficient evidence of relevant markets and separate products.

defenses.defense: ROSS’s antitrust counterclaims fail because Thomson Reuters’ legal database and search tool are not separate products for tying purposes.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust tying doctrine requires distinct products; argued single integrated product with no separate demand.

defenses.defense: ROSS failed to define cognizable relevant product and geographic markets necessary to support antitrust claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust law requires properly defined relevant markets to show market power and competitive harm.

defenses.defense: Lack of evidence of anticompetitive effects or foreclosure of competition from alleged tying arrangement.
defenses.legal_basis: Sherman Act §§1–2 require proof of anticompetitive effects, not just product bundling.

case_id: 2024-09-10_USCOURTS-pawd-2_23-cv-01798_ELKIN VALLEY BAPTIST CHURCH v. PNC FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP_ INC_ et al.pdf
case_name: ELKIN VALLEY BAPTIST CHURCH v. PNC FINANCIAL SERVICES GROUP, INC., et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Religious organization operating a church
parties.defendant_description: Commercial banks and financial institutions

claims.claim: Violation of UCC Article 4A (including § 4A-207) for processing a fraudulent wire transfer despite a mismatch between the beneficiary name and account number
claims.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A, including § 4A-207 (funds transfers)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss by PNC denied; UCC-based claim against PNC allowed to proceed. UCC preemption applied in part to FNB, limiting negligence but not clearly dismissing any properly pled UCC claim.

claims.claim: Common law negligence against PNC for failing to detect and prevent the fraudulent wire transfer, including failure to act on knowledge or notice of mismatched account information and irregularities
claims.legal_basis: State common law negligence (duty of reasonable care in handling wire transfers and account monitoring)
claims.outcome: Court denied PNC’s motion to dismiss; negligence claim against PNC allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Common law negligence against FNB for its role as the Church’s bank in initiating and handling the wire transfer, allegedly failing to prevent the fraud
claims.legal_basis: State common law negligence (duty of care owed by customer’s bank)
claims.outcome: Court granted FNB’s motion to dismiss this negligence claim as preempted by UCC Article 4A because the alleged conduct did not go beyond the wire transfer itself.

defenses.defense: UCC Article 4A permits banks to rely on the beneficiary account number even if the name does not match, absent actual knowledge of the discrepancy, so PNC cannot be liable for processing the transfer
defenses.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code § 4A-207 and related Article 4A provisions

defenses.defense: The Church’s common law negligence claims against FNB are preempted by UCC Article 4A because they arise solely from the execution of a wire transfer
defenses.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A preemption of inconsistent common law claims

defenses.defense: FNB exercised its duties within the scope of the UCC-governed wire transfer and engaged in no extra-conduct outside that framework that could support an independent negligence claim
defenses.legal_basis: Uniform Commercial Code Article 4A; state common law limits where UCC provides exclusive remedies

case_id: 2022-09-30_USCOURTS-cand-5_19-cv-04749_Divino Group LLC et al v. Google LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Divino Group LLC et al. v. Google LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Algorithmic content-moderation and recommendation systems central to alleged discrimination.

parties.plaintiff_description: LGBTQ+ YouTube content creators and channel operators
parties.defendant_description: Online video platform operators and parent technology corporation

claims.claim: Discriminatory restriction, demonetization, and moderation of LGBTQ+ content on YouTube
claims.legal_basis: Unruh Civil Rights Act and related anti-discrimination laws
claims.outcome: Dismissed; barred by Section 230 immunity for content moderation decisions, no further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unlawful censorship and viewpoint discrimination in hosting and distributing plaintiffs’ videos
claims.legal_basis: First Amendment and related constitutional / civil-rights theories
claims.outcome: Dismissed; YouTube/Google not treated as state actors, and Section 230 further shielded moderation choices; no further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unfair business practices based on biased moderation and monetization policies
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition / consumer protection statutes (e.g., UCL)
claims.outcome: Dismissed; Section 230 immunity applied to claims premised on moderation and distribution of third-party content; no further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in YouTube’s terms and monetization agreements
claims.legal_basis: State contract law—implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing
claims.outcome: Partially dismissed with limited leave to amend one specific implied-good-faith theory; all other contract-based theories dismissed with prejudice.

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on alleged promises of neutral, non-discriminatory treatment and monetization
claims.legal_basis: State contract law—express contract claims under YouTube’s terms of service and partner agreements
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found insufficient allegations beyond protected moderation decisions and barred by Section 230 where based on content moderation; no further leave to amend.

claims.claim: Misrepresentation and failure to disclose alleged discriminatory moderation practices
claims.legal_basis: State law fraud / misrepresentation and deceptive practices theories
claims.outcome: Dismissed; Section 230 immunity and failure to state a claim; no further leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Immunity for moderation and distribution decisions regarding user-generated videos and related metadata
defenses.legal_basis: Section 230(c)(1) and 230(c)(2) of the Communications Decency Act

defenses.defense: YouTube and Google are private entities, not state actors, so constitutional free-speech and viewpoint-discrimination claims cannot proceed
defenses.legal_basis: First Amendment state-action doctrine

defenses.defense: Content moderation, demonetization, and restriction decisions fall within contractual discretion granted by YouTube’s terms of service and partner agreements
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation under state law

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to plausibly allege intentional discrimination specifically targeting LGBTQ+ creators as a protected class
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of Unruh Act and similar anti-discrimination statutes

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs’ claims are barred or limited because they seek to treat defendants as publishers of third-party content
defenses.legal_basis: Publisher/speaker liability bar under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not adequately plead reliance, causation, or damages for fraud-based and unfair-competition claims
defenses.legal_basis: State law pleading standards for fraud, misrepresentation, and UCL-type claims

case_id: 2025-03-06_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-07919_Brightex Bio-Photonics_ LLC v. L_Oreal USA_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Brightex Bio-Photonics, LLC v. L'Oreal USA, Inc.
ai_relevance: Case concerns AI-based facial image analysis to recommend personalized skincare treatments.

parties.plaintiff_description: Company developing image-based personalized skincare technology
parties.defendant_description: Cosmetics and skincare products corporation

claims.claim: Patent infringement of the ’358 Patent relating to personalized skincare recommendations using facial analysis.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of patented method/system.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; claims held patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101.

claims.claim: Patent infringement of a second asserted patent (in addition to the ’358 Patent).
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) for another related skincare analysis/recommendation patent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; likewise found invalid under 35 U.S.C. § 101 for patent-ineligibility.

defenses.defense: The asserted claims of the ’358 Patent are invalid as directed to an abstract idea of recommending skincare treatments based on skin characteristics.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice/Mayo framework for patent-eligible subject matter.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents lack an inventive concept beyond generic computer and image-processing implementation of a longstanding practice of evaluating skin and recommending treatments.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Supreme Court and Federal Circuit precedent on abstract ideas implemented on generic computers.

case_id: 2024-09-30_USCOURTS-ded-1_19-cv-01410_VB Assets_ LLC v. Amazon.com Services LLC.pdf
case_name: VB Assets, LLC v. Amazon.com Services LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute over Alexa smart speaker voice assistant and related automated technologies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity asserting smart speaker patents.
parties.defendant_description: Large technology and e-commerce corporation operating Alexa platform.

claims.claim: Willful infringement of multiple patents related to smart speaker technology by Amazon’s Alexa products and services.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq., including willful infringement for enhanced damages.
claims.outcome: Jury found Amazon willfully infringed certain claims of four patents and awarded $46.7 million; court upheld willful infringement and liability for three patents but set aside the verdict as to one patent claim for insufficient evidence.

claims.claim: Entitlement to monetary damages for past infringement, including a reasonable royalty for Amazon’s infringing use of the patented technology.
claims.legal_basis: Patent damages provisions under 35 U.S.C. § 284 (adequate damages no less than a reasonable royalty).
claims.outcome: Jury awarded $46.7 million in damages for past infringement; court largely upheld the award consistent with its ruling that one patent claim lacked sufficient evidence of infringement.

claims.claim: Entitlement to ongoing royalty payments for Amazon’s post-verdict use of the patented smart speaker technology.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable and legal relief under 35 U.S.C. § 283–284 for future infringement when an injunction is not granted, via ongoing royalty.
claims.outcome: Court granted VB Assets an ongoing royalty in principle and ordered further briefing to determine the appropriate royalty rate.

claims.claim: Entitlement to pre-judgment and post-judgment interest on the damages award.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 284 and applicable federal law allowing interest to fully compensate for infringement.
claims.outcome: Court granted VB Assets pre- and post-judgment interest, with details to be determined consistent with further proceedings.

defenses.defense: Non-infringement of the asserted patent claims by Amazon’s Alexa products and services.
defenses.legal_basis: Denial of infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271; argument that accused Alexa functionalities do not practice the asserted patent claims.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected in substantial part; jury found infringement of certain claims of four patents, and the court upheld infringement findings for three patents but agreed there was insufficient evidence for one patent claim, overturning the verdict as to that claim.

defenses.defense: No willful infringement because Amazon allegedly lacked the requisite knowledge or intent and had reasonable defenses or beliefs regarding non-infringement or invalidity.
defenses.legal_basis: Challenge to willfulness standard under 35 U.S.C. § 284 and Halo Electronics v. Pulse Electronics, arguing absence of egregious, intentional misconduct.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; jury found willful infringement and the court upheld the willfulness finding for the patents on which infringement was sustained.

defenses.defense: Challenge to the amount and basis of damages, arguing the jury’s damages award was excessive or unsupported by the evidence and apportionment.
defenses.legal_basis: Patent damages law under 35 U.S.C. § 284 and case law on reasonable royalty, apportionment, and evidentiary sufficiency (e.g., Daubert and Rule 50 standards).
defenses.defense_outcome: Largely rejected; the court upheld the $46.7 million jury damages award except to the extent affected by its ruling that one patent claim lacked sufficient evidence of infringement.

case_id: 2025-06-23_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-05417_Bartz et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Bartz et al v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over training large language model Claude on copyrighted books.

parties.plaintiff_description: Punitive class action brought by group of book authors
parties.defendant_description: AI company developing Claude large language model

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s use of plaintiffs’ books to train its large language model Claude.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, including Section 106 exclusive rights; fair use limitation under Section 107.
claims.outcome: Court granted summary judgment for Anthropic, holding that use of the books for AI training was transformative and constituted fair use, so no liability for this training use.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s acquisition and retention of pirated copies of plaintiffs’ books in its central digital library.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act, Section 106 reproduction and distribution rights; fair use limitation under Section 107.
claims.outcome: Court denied summary judgment in Anthropic’s favor; retention of pirated copies in the library was not deemed fair use and remains for trial on liability and remedies.

defenses.defense: Use of copyrighted books to train the Claude AI model is fair use because it is highly transformative and does not substitute for or directly compete with the original works.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use doctrine under Section 107 of the Copyright Act.

defenses.defense: AI training uses the works to extract statistical patterns and generate novel outputs, not to reproduce or distribute the books themselves, minimizing market harm.
defenses.legal_basis: Fair use factors—purpose and character of use, nature of the work, amount used, and effect on the market under Section 107.

case_id: 2021-09-30_USCOURTS-nynd-1_18-cv-00549_Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute et al. v. Amazon.com_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute et al. v. Amazon.com, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over patented natural language interface technology used in Alexa-like systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: University and affiliated patent-holding/licensing company
parties.defendant_description: Large e-commerce and technology corporation

claims.claim: Patent infringement of the ’798 Patent relating to natural language interface (NLI) technology allegedly practiced by Amazon products such as Alexa-enabled systems.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq. for direct and/or indirect infringement of the ’798 Patent claims.
claims.outcome: In this Markman (claim construction) decision, the court did not decide ultimate infringement or liability, but construed the disputed claim terms of the ’798 Patent, providing specific interpretations that will govern later infringement and validity determinations.

defenses.defense: Non‑infringement based on narrower interpretation of disputed claim terms in the ’798 Patent.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal patent law; argument that properly construed claim language does not read on Amazon’s accused products or methods.

defenses.defense: Implied challenge to breadth/meaning of patent claims through proposed claim constructions that would limit or distinguish the patented natural language query processing from Amazon’s implementations.
defenses.legal_basis: Patent claim construction principles under Markman v. Westview Instruments and related Federal Circuit precedent, including intrinsic evidence (claims, specification, prosecution history).

case_id: 2011-08-18_USCOURTS-njd-2_04-cv-03623_SYNCSORT INCORPORATED v. INNOVATIVE ROUTINES INTERNATIONAL INC
case_name: Syncsort Incorporated v. Innovative Routines International Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Software company providing data transformation tools
parties.defendant_description: Software company, maker of CoSORT product

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets in Syncsort’s command language and related materials
claims.legal_basis: State trade secret law protecting proprietary software command language and documentation
claims.outcome: Court held Syncsort’s command language was a trade secret and found IRI misappropriated it by using Syncsort’s reference guide and scripts to develop the ssu2scl translator; injunctive relief granted against IRI.

claims.claim: Unfair competition by using Syncsort’s confidential materials to create a competing script translator
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law based on misappropriation and improper use of competitor’s proprietary information
claims.outcome: Court found IRI’s conduct constituted unfair competition and enjoined IRI from using or distributing the ssu2scl translator and any derivative materials.

defenses.defense: Syncsort’s command language and related information were not trade secrets
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requirement that information be secret and derive independent economic value from secrecy

defenses.defense: IRI’s development of the ssu2scl translator was based on permissible reverse engineering or public information
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret and unfair competition doctrines allowing use of publicly available information and lawful reverse engineering

case_id: 2019-04-01_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-07233_WeRide Corp. et al v. Huang et al.pdf
case_name: WeRide Corp. et al. v. Kun Huang et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on autonomous vehicle software and related AI technologies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Autonomous vehicle technology companies alleging trade secret theft
parties.defendant_name: Kun Huang, Jing Wang, ZZX, AllRide
parties.defendant_description: Former employees and rival autonomous driving companies

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under the Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA) against Kun Huang, ZZX, and AllRide
claims.legal_basis: Federal Defend Trade Secrets Act, 18 U.S.C. § 1836 et seq.
claims.outcome: Court found WeRide likely to succeed and granted preliminary injunction against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide, ordering them to cease using WeRide’s confidential information and allowing expedited discovery.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under the California Uniform Trade Secrets Act (CUTSA) against Kun Huang, ZZX, and AllRide
claims.legal_basis: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act, Cal. Civ. Code § 3426 et seq.
claims.outcome: Court found WeRide likely to succeed and granted preliminary injunction against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide, prohibiting use or disclosure of WeRide’s trade secrets pending further proceedings.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets under DTSA and/or CUTSA against Jing Wang
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act and California Uniform Trade Secrets Act
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction as to Wang because WeRide did not show a likelihood of success on its trade secret misappropriation claims against him.

claims.claim: Breach of contract (e.g., confidentiality, non-disclosure, or related employment agreements) by former employee Kun Huang
claims.legal_basis: State contract law based on Huang’s employment and confidentiality agreements with WeRide
claims.outcome: Court’s preliminary injunction analysis focused on trade secrets; injunction granted in part against Huang based on likelihood of success on trade secret claims; breach of contract claim not separately enjoined beyond protections overlapping with trade secret relief.

claims.claim: Breach of contract by former employee Jing Wang
claims.legal_basis: State contract law based on Wang’s employment and/or confidentiality agreements with WeRide
claims.outcome: Court did not grant preliminary injunctive relief on trade secret or related claims against Wang due to lack of demonstrated likelihood of success; contract claim not independently supported for injunction at this stage.

claims.claim: Defamation by Jing Wang against WeRide
claims.legal_basis: State tort law of defamation
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction on the defamation claim because WeRide failed to show a likelihood of success on the merits of its defamation allegations against Wang.

claims.claim: Related unfair competition / business tort claims against Huang, ZZX, and AllRide (based on use of WeRide’s confidential technology to compete)
claims.legal_basis: California unfair competition and/or common law business tort principles, derivative of trade secret misuse
claims.outcome: To the extent overlapping with trade secret misuse, court’s partial preliminary injunction restricted defendants’ use of WeRide’s confidential and trade secret information; no separate broader injunction issued beyond trade secret-based relief.

defenses.defense: No protectable trade secrets or information is generally known or readily ascertainable
defenses.legal_basis: Challenge to DTSA and CUTSA elements requiring existence of a trade secret.

defenses.defense: No misappropriation by defendants; independent development of technology
