defenses.legal_basis: Rebuttal of DTSA and CUTSA misappropriation elements, asserting lawful, independent creation of autonomous driving software.

defenses.defense: WeRide failed to show likelihood of success or irreparable harm for injunction
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard under Winter v. NRDC and related Ninth Circuit precedent.

defenses.defense: WeRide’s claims against Jing Wang lack evidentiary support
defenses.legal_basis: Failure of proof on elements of trade secret misappropriation and defamation as required under DTSA, CUTSA, and state defamation law.

defenses.defense: Injunction would be overbroad and unduly burden lawful competition
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable limits on injunctive relief and public interest in competition under federal and state law.

case_id: 2024-05-20_USCOURTS-ded-1_23-cv-00802_Staton Techiya_ LLC v. Harman International Industries_ Incorporated et al.pdf
case_name: Staton Techiya, LLC v. Harman International Industries, Inc., et al.
ai_relevance: Patents cover ear-worn tech using intelligent, AI-based sound processing and personalization.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company holding ear-worn audio patents
parties.defendant_name: Harman International Industries, Inc.; Harman-Kardon, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Audio electronics corporations accused of patent infringement

claims.claim: Direct infringement of nine patents covering ear-worn audio and sound-processing technology by making, using, selling, and/or importing accused products.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(a) – direct patent infringement.
claims.outcome: Not resolved at this motion-to-dismiss stage; claims proceed.

claims.claim: Induced infringement of certain asserted patents based on Harman’s alleged pre-suit knowledge and encouragement of customers’ infringing use of accused ear-worn products.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) – induced infringement; pleading standards under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6).
claims.outcome: Court held Techiya sufficiently pled pre-suit induced infringement for some patents; those induced infringement claims survive the motion to dismiss.

claims.claim: Willful infringement of certain asserted patents based on Harman’s alleged pre-suit knowledge and continued infringement in reckless disregard of Techiya’s rights.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 284 (enhanced damages for willful infringement); Federal Circuit willfulness standards (e.g., knowledge and egregiousness).
claims.outcome: Court held Techiya sufficiently pled pre-suit willful infringement for some patents; those willfulness claims survive the motion to dismiss.

claims.claim: Post-suit induced infringement based on Harman’s knowledge of the patents and alleged continued inducement after the complaint was filed.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) – induced infringement; post-suit knowledge pleading requirements under Rule 8/12(b)(6).
claims.outcome: Court granted Harman’s motion to dismiss post-suit induced infringement claims without prejudice for insufficient allegations of Harman’s post-suit knowledge and intent; Techiya may amend.

claims.claim: Post-suit willful infringement based on Harman’s knowledge of the patents and continued infringement after suit was filed.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 284 – willful infringement; standards for post-suit willfulness and knowledge under Federal Circuit law and Rule 8/12(b)(6).
claims.outcome: Court granted Harman’s motion to dismiss post-suit willful infringement claims without prejudice for insufficient pleading of post-suit knowledge and egregious conduct; Techiya may amend.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for induced infringement because the complaint does not adequately plead Harman’s knowledge of the patents and specific intent to induce infringement, particularly for post-suit conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); pleading standards for induced infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271(b).

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for willful infringement because the complaint does not sufficiently allege pre-suit or post-suit knowledge and egregious conduct by Harman.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); willfulness and enhanced damages standards under 35 U.S.C. § 284 and Federal Circuit precedent.

case_id: 2025-08-22_USCOURTS-idd-2_24-cv-00632_Chenco Engineering _ Consulting GMBH v. Do-Fluoride New Materials Co. LTD et al.pdf
case_name: Chenco Engineering & Consulting GMBH v. Do-Fluoride New Materials Co. LTD et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Foreign engineering and consulting company
parties.defendant_name: Do-Fluoride New Materials; Do-Fluoride New Energy
parties.defendant_description: Foreign corporate defendants in materials and energy sectors

claims.claim: Enforcement of foreign court judgments against defendants
claims.legal_basis: Recognition and enforcement of foreign country money judgments under applicable Idaho and/or U.S. law
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; case remanded to Idaho state court for further proceedings

claims.claim: Request to keep action in Idaho state court (opposition to removal)
claims.legal_basis: Lack of federal removal jurisdiction under 9 U.S.C. § 205 and general removal statutes
claims.outcome: Granted; motion to remand granted and case returned to Idaho state court

defenses.defense: Federal removal jurisdiction exists because the dispute relates to an arbitration agreement or award under the New York Convention
defenses.legal_basis: 9 U.S.C. § 205 and the New York Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court held defendants failed to show the case ‘relates to’ a Convention arbitration agreement or award, so no federal jurisdiction

case_id: 2022-11-22_USCOURTS-txwd-6_21-cv-00968_Parus Holdings Inc. v. Apple Inc..pdf
case_name: Parus Holdings Inc. v. Apple Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves Siri’s AI-based speech recognition and natural language processing.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation holding voice-search technology patents
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation, maker of Siri devices

claims.claim: Apple infringed Parus’s patents covering voice-enabled internet search and retrieval systems used in products like Siri-enabled devices.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under the U.S. Patent Act (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: The Western District of Texas is a proper and convenient venue for Parus’s patent infringement suit against Apple.
claims.legal_basis: Venue and convenience considerations under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).
claims.outcome: Rejected; the court held the Northern District of California is clearly more convenient and granted transfer.

defenses.defense: The case should be transferred to the Northern District of California because it is clearly a more convenient forum for parties and witnesses and better serves the interests of justice.
defenses.legal_basis: Motion to transfer venue under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a), considering convenience of witnesses, location of documents, and locus of accused technology’s development.

case_id: 2023-08-03_USCOURTS-tnwd-2_22-cv-02838_Pritchard v. Thompson et al.pdf
case_name: Pritchard v. Thompson et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation of AI-enabled dashcam design and technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Pro se individual inventor and patent holder
parties.defendant_description: Technology company and its representative employees

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to AI-enabled dashcam design and technology
claims.legal_basis: Tennessee Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA) and related trade secret principles
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants and held that trade-secret-based claims are governed by and preempted by TUTSA.

claims.claim: Breach of confidentiality / improper use of information disclosed for purposes of a Non-Disclosure Agreement
claims.legal_basis: State common law contract and confidentiality principles
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held claim was preempted by TUTSA because it was based on alleged trade secret misappropriation and also lacked personal jurisdiction over defendants.

claims.claim: Fraud / fraudulent inducement in obtaining disclosure of dashcam trade secrets
claims.legal_basis: State common law fraud and misrepresentation
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held the claim was preempted by TUTSA as it relied on the same nucleus of trade secret misappropriation facts and the court lacked personal jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Conversion / wrongful appropriation of proprietary dashcam design and related materials
claims.legal_basis: State common law conversion and property torts
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held the claim was preempted by TUTSA because it was based on alleged misappropriation of trade secrets and the court lacked personal jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Unfair competition / unjust enrichment based on use of plaintiff’s AI dashcam concept
claims.legal_basis: State common law unfair competition and unjust enrichment
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held these claims were preempted by TUTSA as they depended on the same alleged trade secret misappropriation and the court lacked personal jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Patent-related infringement or misuse of patented dashcam design
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law principles as referenced by plaintiff
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed; court did not reach the merits because it found no personal jurisdiction over defendants in Tennessee.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Tennessee federal court
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and personal jurisdiction standards; defendants did not purposefully avail themselves of Tennessee.

defenses.defense: Preemption of state law claims by Tennessee Uniform Trade Secrets Act (TUTSA)
defenses.legal_basis: TUTSA’s displacement provision preempts other state law claims based on trade secret misappropriation.

defenses.defense: Insufficient contacts and activities directed at Tennessee
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional minimum contacts requirement for specific jurisdiction under federal and Tennessee law.

case_id: 2024-06-24_USCOURTS-tnmd-3_23-cv-01092_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: AI company Anthropic allegedly used copyrighted song lyrics to train Claude.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Group of music publishing companies alleging copyright infringement.
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company developing and operating Claude model.

claims.claim: Anthropic used plaintiffs’ copyrighted song lyrics to train its AI model Claude without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement under U.S. copyright law (unauthorized reproduction and use of lyrics).
claims.outcome: Not reached on the merits; case dismissed in this court for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue and transferred to the Northern District of California.

claims.claim: Anthropic’s operation and outputs of Claude unlawfully exploit plaintiffs’ copyrighted lyrics.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright infringement and related exclusive rights violations under federal copyright law.
claims.outcome: Not reached on the merits; case dismissed in this court for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue and transferred to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over Anthropic in the Middle District of Tennessee.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and minimum contacts requirements under the U.S. Constitution and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Venue in the Middle District of Tennessee is improper for this dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Improper venue under federal venue statutes and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(3).

case_id: 2023-03-15_USCOURTS-mad-1_20-cv-12236_Findability Sciences_ Inc. v. Soft10_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Findability Sciences, Inc. v. Soft10, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over use and sublicensing of AI-related predictive analytics software (Dr. Mo).

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence and analytics software company
parties.defendant_description: Software company providing Dr. Mo analytics tool

claims.claim: Copyright infringement by Findability’s use and sublicensing of the Dr. Mo software without authorization or proper payment.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment denied; claim proceeds to trial due to genuine disputes of material fact.

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on Findability’s alleged violation of multiple software and licensing agreements governing use and sublicensing of Dr. Mo.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing software license and services agreements.
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment denied; breach of contract counterclaim proceeds to trial.

claims.claim: Breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing in connection with performance of the software agreements.
claims.legal_basis: State common law duty of good faith and fair dealing implied in contracts.
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment denied; claim proceeds to trial.

claims.claim: Unfair or deceptive business practices related to the software relationship and sublicensing conduct.
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts General Laws ch. 93A (unfair and deceptive acts and practices).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment denied; Chapter 93A counterclaim proceeds to trial.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets relating to Dr. Mo and associated confidential information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (state trade secret statute/common law, and/or Defend Trade Secrets Act).
claims.outcome: Findability’s motion for summary judgment denied; misappropriation claim proceeds to trial.

claims.claim: Promissory estoppel based on alleged promises outside or beyond the written software agreements.
claims.legal_basis: State common law doctrine of promissory estoppel (reliance on extra-contractual promises).
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; promissory estoppel counterclaim dismissed for lack of sufficient evidence or because covered by existing contracts.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment for benefits Findability allegedly received from using and sublicensing Dr. Mo without proper compensation.
claims.legal_basis: State common law of unjust enrichment and quasi-contract.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; unjust enrichment counterclaim dismissed as preempted or barred by the existence of governing contracts.

claims.claim: Rescission of the software agreements based on alleged misconduct and nonperformance.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy of rescission under state contract law.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; rescission counterclaim dismissed for lack of applicable evidence or legal basis.

claims.claim: Conversion based on alleged wrongful control over Dr. Mo software and related materials.
claims.legal_basis: State common law tort of conversion.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted in favor of Findability; conversion counterclaim dismissed as preempted by federal copyright law or otherwise unsupported.

defenses.defense: Existing written software and license agreements govern the parties’ relationship, barring quasi-contract theories such as promissory estoppel and unjust enrichment.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law principle that express contracts preclude quasi-contractual recovery for the same subject matter.

defenses.defense: Federal copyright law preempts state-law claims based on rights equivalent to copyright, such as conversion of software and certain unjust enrichment theories.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright preemption under 17 U.S.C. § 301.

defenses.defense: Lack of sufficient evidence to support extra-contractual promises or grounds for rescission.
defenses.legal_basis: Summary judgment standard under Fed. R. Civ. P. 56 requiring evidence of genuine disputes of material fact.

case_id: 2020-10-19_USCOURTS-ded-1_19-cv-00524_VoterLabs_ Inc. v. Ethos Group Consulting Services_ LLC.pdf
case_name: VoterLabs, Inc. v. Ethos Group Consulting Services, LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged misuse and funding of machine-learning software development work.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company providing software and analytics services
parties.defendant_description: Consulting services business entity

claims.claim: Malicious breach of contract based on Ethos’ failure to make the engagement payment and alleged use of that nonpayment as leverage for concessions from VoterLabs.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law – breach of contract with malicious or bad‑faith conduct.
claims.outcome: Ethos’ motion to dismiss this claim was denied; the malicious breach of contract claim remains pending.

claims.claim: Breach of contract generally for failing to make required engagement payment under the parties’ agreement.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law – failure to perform payment obligations under contract.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this opinion; claim continues and was not dismissed.

claims.claim: Fraud by VoterLabs in allegedly misrepresenting how Ethos’ investment and payments would be used, including representing that funds were for software development for Ethos while allegedly using them for separate machine‑learning projects.
claims.legal_basis: State common‑law fraud (intentional misrepresentation, reliance, and damages).
claims.outcome: Court granted Ethos leave to amend its counterclaim to add this fraud claim; merits not yet decided.

claims.claim: Negligent misrepresentation by VoterLabs regarding the intended use of Ethos’ funds and the nature and purpose of the software and machine‑learning work to be performed for Ethos.
claims.legal_basis: State common‑law negligent misrepresentation (duty of care in supplying information).
claims.outcome: Court granted Ethos leave to amend its counterclaim to add this negligent misrepresentation claim; merits not yet decided.

defenses.defense: VoterLabs’ malicious breach of contract claim fails to state a claim because Ethos’ nonpayment of the engagement fee was not malicious and was within its contractual rights or a legitimate business dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) failure to state a claim; contract interpretation principles limiting bad‑faith or punitive‑type contract theories.

defenses.defense: Any alleged misrepresentations by VoterLabs about use of funds or software development justify Ethos’ withholding of payment and support Ethos’ own fraud‑based counterclaims rather than a malicious breach claim.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law doctrines of prior material breach and justification; common‑law principles allowing suspension of performance when the counterparty engages in fraud or misrepresentation.

case_id: 2022-06-29_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-10656_Nuance Communications_ Inc. v. Kovalenko.pdf
case_name: Nuance Communications, Inc. v. Kovalenko
ai_relevance: Dispute involves competing AI-powered radiology workflow and imaging products.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation offering AI radiology and imaging solutions
parties.defendant_description: Individual former employee subject to non-compete

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete covenant by accepting employment with Sirona Medical, Inc., an alleged direct competitor of Nuance.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law; enforcement of restrictive covenant in employment agreement under applicable state law.
claims.outcome: Court found Nuance likely to succeed on the merits and granted a preliminary injunction barring Kovalenko from working for Sirona in conflicting roles during the non-compete period.

claims.claim: Threatened or inevitable disclosure and misuse of Nuance’s confidential information and trade secrets in her role at Sirona.
claims.legal_basis: Contractual confidentiality obligations and trade secret protections under state law (e.g., common law trade secret principles).
claims.outcome: Court concluded Kovalenko’s role at Sirona likely risks use or disclosure of Nuance’s confidential information and relied on this risk in granting the preliminary injunction.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunctive relief to enforce the non-compete and protect confidential information.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy standards for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of hardships, public interest).
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction granted in Nuance’s favor, restricting Kovalenko’s employment with Sirona in any capacity that would violate the non-compete agreement.

defenses.defense: Her employment with Sirona does not violate the non-compete because Sirona is not a direct competitor of Nuance or her role is not competitive.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation of scope and meaning of “competitive business” and permissible employment activities.

defenses.defense: The non-compete covenant is overbroad or otherwise unenforceable as a restraint on trade or on her ability to work.
defenses.legal_basis: State law limits on enforceability of restrictive covenants in employment agreements (reasonableness in scope, duration, and geography).

case_id: 2025-09-02_USCOURTS-dcd-1_20-cv-03010_UNITED STATES OF AMERICA et al v. GOOGLE LLC.pdf
case_name: United States of America et al. v. Google LLC
ai_relevance: Case discusses generative AI (e.g., ChatGPT) as emerging competitive threat to Google Search and as potential constraint on Google’s search monopoly.

parties.plaintiff_description: Federal and state government antitrust enforcers
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation providing search and advertising services

claims.claim: Google unlawfully maintained a monopoly in the general search services market through exclusionary conduct.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – monopolization (maintenance of monopoly power through exclusionary agreements).
claims.outcome: Court found Google liable; held that Google maintained its general search services monopoly through anticompetitive exclusive and default agreements.

claims.claim: Google unlawfully maintained a monopoly in the search text advertising market through exclusionary conduct tied to its search monopoly.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – monopolization of search text advertising via exclusionary practices reinforcing search dominance.
claims.outcome: Court found Google liable; held that Google maintained monopoly power in search text advertising by leveraging exclusionary search distribution agreements.

claims.claim: Google’s exclusive and default distribution agreements with device manufacturers, browser developers, and other partners unlawfully foreclosed rivals and harmed competition.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – exclusionary agreements and de facto exclusivity that substantially foreclose competition.
claims.outcome: Court agreed; held that these agreements were unlawful exclusionary conduct and ordered injunctive remedies restricting such agreements.

claims.claim: Google’s conduct harmed competition and consumers by freezing the search market, limiting innovation, and impeding new forms of search, including generative AI-based competitors.
claims.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – anticompetitive effects and harm to the competitive process and consumer welfare.
claims.outcome: Court credited this theory in part; found that Google’s conduct significantly impeded competitive entry and expansion, including from emerging technologies, and ordered remedies to reduce these barriers.

claims.claim: Structural relief, including potential divestiture of Chrome or Android, was necessary to restore competition.
claims.legal_basis: Antitrust remedial authority under the Sherman Act – request for structural remedies to unwind monopoly power.
claims.outcome: Court rejected structural divestiture; declined to order Chrome or Android divestiture, finding such relief potentially harmful and not justified on the record.

defenses.defense: Google’s exclusive and default agreements were lawful competition on the merits and reflected consumer preference for its superior search product.
defenses.legal_basis: Section 2 of the Sherman Act – argument that conduct was procompetitive, based on product quality and user choice rather than exclusionary intent or effect.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court rejected this defense, finding that the agreements unlawfully foreclosed rivals beyond what product quality alone would justify.

defenses.defense: The challenged agreements did not substantially foreclose competition because rivals could still reach users through other channels.
defenses.legal_basis: Section 2 foreclosure analysis – claim of insufficient market foreclosure and availability of alternative distribution paths.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court rejected this defense, concluding that the scale and centrality of the default and exclusive placements effectively froze the market and substantially foreclosed rivals.

defenses.defense: Emerging technologies, including generative AI products like ChatGPT, would discipline Google’s market power, so Google lacked durable monopoly power.
defenses.legal_basis: Section 2 – lack of durable monopoly power due to potential and nascent competition from new technologies.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court rejected this defense as insufficient; while acknowledging potential future competition from generative AI, it found Google currently possessed and maintained monopoly power through exclusionary conduct.

defenses.defense: Structural remedies such as divestiture of Chrome or Android would be disproportionate, harmful to consumers, and unnecessary to restore competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Limits on antitrust remedies – equitable principles and requirement that remedies be tailored and not unduly harmful.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court accepted this defense in part; it declined to order structural divestiture and instead imposed conduct and data-sharing remedies.

case_id: 2022-06-28_USCOURTS-alnd-5_21-cv-01680_Quantum Research International Inc v. SPG Institute Inc et al.pdf
case_name: Quantum Research International Inc. v. SPG Institute Inc., SP Global, et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporate defense and technology contractor
parties.defendant_description: Business entities and executives operating consortium

claims.claim: Fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the Autonomy Research Network Consortium and related dealings
claims.legal_basis: State-law fraud and misrepresentation principles; alleged deceptive scheme to obtain money and business opportunities
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; court compelled arbitration under Subaward Agreement

claims.claim: Breach of contractual obligations arising from the Subaward Agreement and related consortium arrangements
claims.legal_basis: Contract law based on terms of the Subaward Agreement and associated documents
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; claim ordered to be resolved in arbitration

claims.claim: Civil conspiracy to defraud Quantum and other defense and technology companies through the consortium structure
claims.legal_basis: State-law civil conspiracy based on alleged coordinated fraudulent scheme
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; encompassed within arbitration compelled by the court

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on defendants’ alleged retention of funds or benefits obtained through the scheme
claims.legal_basis: Equitable unjust enrichment and restitution principles
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; to be addressed in arbitration pursuant to arbitration clause

claims.claim: Any additional state-law business torts arising from the alleged scheme (e.g., negligent misrepresentation or similar claims)
claims.legal_basis: State tort law related to misrepresentation and improper business practices
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on the merits; all such claims compelled to arbitration

claims.claim: Request for the court to exercise personal jurisdiction over all defendants
claims.legal_basis: Due process and state long-arm jurisdiction principles; purposeful availment in Alabama
claims.outcome: Court held it had specific personal jurisdiction over defendants and denied dismissal on this ground

claims.claim: Request to litigate claims in federal court notwithstanding arbitration clause
claims.legal_basis: Argument that arbitration clause should not bar court litigation of claims
claims.outcome: Rejected; court enforced arbitration clause and compelled arbitration, staying/dismissing court action accordingly

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over SPG Institute, SP Global, and individual executives
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on personal jurisdiction; absence of sufficient minimum contacts with Alabama

defenses.defense: Claims must be dismissed or stayed because they are subject to binding arbitration
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and arbitration clause in the Subaward Agreement covering disputes arising from or related to the agreement

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state claims with sufficient particularity and plausibility
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8 and 9(b) (inadequate pleading of fraud and other claims)

case_id: 2024-09-30_USCOURTS-cand-3_21-cv-08812_In re Meta Platforms_ Inc._ Securities Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Meta Platforms, Inc. Securities Litigation
ai_relevance: Case concerns Meta’s automated, algorithmic content-moderation systems and their alleged misrepresentation to investors, including cross-check system and algorithms affecting young users’ mental health.

parties.plaintiff_description: Institutional investors and putative securities class-action group
parties.defendant_description: Public technology corporation and individual corporate officers

claims.claim: Meta and its executives made materially false or misleading statements about the effectiveness and nature of their content moderation systems, including the cross-check system and algorithmic moderation of harmful content, causing investor losses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal securities fraud under Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and SEC Rule 10b-5 (misrepresentation and omission of material facts).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted in part and denied in part; some statements about content moderation and cross-check deemed non-actionable or inadequately pled and dismissed, while other statements—particularly those tied to algorithmic moderation of harmful content—were sufficiently pled and allowed to proceed against certain defendants.

claims.claim: Meta and its executives misrepresented or omitted material facts about algorithmic bias and the operation of algorithms that allegedly amplified or failed to adequately moderate harmful content on Meta platforms.
claims.legal_basis: Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 (material misstatements/omissions and scienter).
claims.outcome: Court denied the motion to dismiss as to certain algorithm-related statements, holding that plaintiffs adequately alleged falsity and scienter; those securities fraud claims based on algorithmic bias and moderation practices proceed against some defendants, while other algorithm-related statements were dismissed as puffery or not sufficiently linked to falsity.

claims.claim: Meta and its executives made materially false or misleading statements minimizing or mischaracterizing the impact of Instagram on young users’ mental health, thereby misleading investors about significant business and regulatory risks.
claims.legal_basis: Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 (misrepresentation/omission of material risks to the business).
claims.outcome: Court allowed claims based on certain statements about Instagram’s impact on young users to proceed, finding plaintiffs had adequately alleged that some statements were misleading and material; other broader or more generalized statements about user well-being were dismissed as non-actionable opinion or corporate optimism.

claims.claim: Meta is liable as a corporate entity for the alleged securities fraud committed by its officers and agents through false and misleading public statements and SEC filings.
claims.legal_basis: Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (corporate liability for statements of officers and authorized agents).
claims.outcome: To the extent underlying misrepresentation claims survived the motion to dismiss, corporate liability claims against Meta also survived; where specific statement-based claims were dismissed, corresponding corporate liability theories were dismissed as well.

claims.claim: Individual Meta executives are liable as control persons for Meta’s alleged primary securities law violations.
claims.legal_basis: Section 20(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (control person liability).
claims.outcome: Control person claims under Section 20(a) were allowed to proceed against those executives for whom the court found adequately pled primary violations and control; Section 20(a) claims tied only to dismissed primary violations were themselves dismissed.

defenses.defense: Challenged statements about content moderation, cross-check, and algorithms were non-actionable corporate puffery, vague optimism, or general policy statements, not specific, verifiable facts.
defenses.legal_basis: Securities law doctrine that immaterial puffery and generalized aspirational statements cannot form the basis of a Rule 10b-5 claim.

defenses.defense: Alleged misstatements were not materially false or misleading because Meta’s disclosures, taken as a whole, adequately warned of risks and limitations in content moderation and user safety.
defenses.legal_basis: Materiality and falsity standards under Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5; ‘total mix’ of information available to a reasonable investor.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to plead a strong inference of scienter, as there were no particularized facts showing that Meta or its executives knew their statements about algorithms, cross-check, or Instagram’s impact were false when made.
defenses.legal_basis: Private Securities Litigation Reform Act (PSLRA) heightened pleading standard for scienter in securities fraud actions.

defenses.defense: Some alleged misstatements were forward-looking and accompanied by meaningful cautionary language, and thus protected by the PSLRA safe harbor for forward-looking statements.
defenses.legal_basis: PSLRA safe harbor for forward-looking statements under 15 U.S.C. § 78u-5.

defenses.defense: Certain statements about Instagram’s impact on young users and user well-being were non-actionable opinions or statements of belief, not objectively false factual assertions.
defenses.legal_basis: Opinion-statement doctrine under Omnicare and related securities law precedent distinguishing opinions from false statements of fact.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to adequately plead loss causation because they did not sufficiently link the alleged corrective disclosures about algorithms, cross-check, or youth harm to the claimed stock price declines.
defenses.legal_basis: Loss causation requirement under Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, as interpreted in Dura Pharmaceuticals and progeny.

case_id: 2022-09-20_USCOURTS-mad-1_21-cv-11477_INTEGRATED TECHNOLOGY SOLUTIONS LLC v. iRacing.com Motorsport Simulations_ LLC.pdf
case_name: Integrated Technology Solutions, LLC v. iRacing.com Motorsport Simulations, LLC
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company patent owner
parties.defendant_description: Limited liability company racing simulation developer

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 10,046,241 covering systems that modify racing video games based on environmental and player interaction changes.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) asserting rights in U.S. Patent No. 10,046,241.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice at Rule 12 stage; court held all asserted claims of the ’241 patent invalid as patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101 pursuant to the Alice framework, so infringement claim could not proceed.

defenses.defense: The asserted patent claims are directed to an abstract idea and therefore claim ineligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank Int’l two-step test for patent eligibility.

defenses.defense: The patent lacks an inventive concept that transforms the abstract idea into a patent-eligible application.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice step two requiring an inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation.

case_id: 2022-06-17_USCOURTS-ksd-6_21-cv-01270_Andes Capital Financing LLC et al v. Crossed Keys LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Andes Capital Financing LLC et al v. Crossed Keys LLC et al
ai_relevance: Dispute over squeeze-out of minority shareholders in AI company Torch

parties.plaintiff_name: Andes Capital Financing LLC et al
parties.plaintiff_description: Minority shareholder entities in AI company Torch
parties.defendant_description: Majority shareholder entities controlling Torch merger

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty in connection with squeeze-out merger and undervaluation of minority shares
claims.legal_basis: State corporate/LLC fiduciary duty law governing majority and controlling shareholders
claims.outcome: Underlying claim not resolved in this order; court only decided discovery scope and allowed post-merger discovery in part

claims.claim: Fraud related to alleged intentional undervaluation and misleading conduct during squeeze-out merger
claims.legal_basis: State common-law fraud and related misrepresentation principles
claims.outcome: Underlying fraud claim not resolved in this order; court only decided discovery scope and allowed post-merger discovery in part

claims.claim: Breach of Torch operating agreements by forcing out minority shareholders at unfair price
claims.legal_basis: Contract law based on Torch’s operating agreements
claims.outcome: Underlying contract claim not resolved in this order; court only decided discovery scope and allowed post-merger discovery in part

claims.claim: Motion to compel discovery of post-merger documents and information
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 37 regarding scope of discovery and motions to compel
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; court ordered production of certain post-merger documents relevant to fiduciary duty and fraud claims but refused broader custodial searches and ongoing rolling updates past a set date due to proportionality concerns

defenses.defense: Post-merger documents are outside relevant timeframe and not proportional to needs of case
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) on relevance and proportionality in discovery

defenses.defense: Burden and expense of additional custodial searches and ongoing updates outweigh likely benefit
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) proportionality limits on discovery scope

case_id: 2021-02-23_USCOURTS-mdd-1_20-cv-00335_Trugreen Limited Partnership v. Allegis Global Solutions_ Inc..pdf
case_name: TruGreen Limited Partnership v. Allegis Global Solutions, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AGS’s AI recruiting chatbot “Olivia” allegedly underperforming and contributing to claimed contract breach.

parties.plaintiff_description: Commercial lawn care services business
parties.defendant_description: Recruitment process outsourcing and staffing services company

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failure to perform recruitment obligations under the Recruitment Process Outsourcing Agreement, including not recruiting the promised number and quality of employees and problems with the AI chatbot “Olivia.”
claims.legal_basis: Common law breach of contract under the governing state law and the written Recruitment Process Outsourcing Agreement between the parties.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to Count I; breach of contract claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Negligent misrepresentation regarding AGS’s capabilities and performance, including representations about its recruitment services and the effectiveness of the AI chatbot “Olivia.”
claims.legal_basis: Common law negligent misrepresentation based on alleged false statements made during negotiations and performance of the Agreement.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on AGS’s motion to dismiss (Count II dismissed).

claims.claim: Promissory estoppel based on AGS’s alleged promises about recruitment performance and technology (including “Olivia”) that TruGreen claims it reasonably relied upon to its detriment.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable promissory estoppel under state common law, pled in the alternative to contract.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on AGS’s motion to dismiss (Count III dismissed).

claims.claim: Additional non-contract, non-estoppel claim(s) (e.g., possibly unjust enrichment or related quasi-contract / tort theories) arising from alleged failures in recruitment services and technology performance.
claims.legal_basis: State common law quasi-contract or tort theories pled in addition to breach of contract and misrepresentation.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on AGS’s motion to dismiss (Count IV dismissed).

claims.claim: Further ancillary claim (e.g., another tort or equitable theory tied to AGS’s recruitment performance and use of “Olivia”) asserted alongside the main contract claim.
claims.legal_basis: State common law ancillary theory distinct from breach of contract, negligent misrepresentation, and promissory estoppel.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on AGS’s motion to dismiss (Count V dismissed).

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for negligent misrepresentation because the dispute is governed by a contract and alleged misstatements are not actionable torts.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss; economic loss doctrine and contract-tort boundary principles under state law.

defenses.defense: Promissory estoppel and other quasi-contract or equitable claims are barred where an express, enforceable contract (the Recruitment Process Outsourcing Agreement) governs the parties’ relationship.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss; contract preclusion of quasi-contract and estoppel remedies under state common law.

defenses.defense: Declaratory or other non-contract claims seeking damages beyond what the Agreement allows are improper or unavailable at the pleading stage.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss; limitations on declaratory relief and contractually limited damages under state contract law.

case_id: 2025-07-25_USCOURTS-pamd-3_25-cv-01284_Deleman v. HighLevel_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Deleman v. HighLevel, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual operating marketing SaaS business
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing marketing software-as-a-service platform

claims.claim: Wrongful termination of plaintiff’s HighLevel account causing business losses and damages
claims.legal_basis: Breach of contract and related state-law commercial claims (implied from termination dispute)
claims.outcome: Compelled to arbitration; court did not reach merits of liability or damages

claims.claim: Request for temporary restraining order to restore or maintain access to HighLevel services
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief under federal procedural standards for TROs
claims.outcome: Denied; plaintiff failed to show likelihood of success, irreparable harm, or that arbitration could not adequately address his concerns

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to prevent HighLevel from terminating or interfering with account during dispute
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief under federal preliminary injunction standards
claims.outcome: Denied; same reasons as TRO—no sufficient showing on merits, irreparable harm, or inadequacy of arbitration

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is bound by arbitration clause in the terms of service he accepted
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law enforcing valid arbitration agreements
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court granted motion to compel arbitration and stayed/removed claims from judicial forum

defenses.defense: Court should not issue TRO or preliminary injunction because plaintiff cannot satisfy required elements
defenses.legal_basis: Federal standards for injunctive relief: likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, and public interest
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court denied plaintiff’s motions for TRO and preliminary injunction

case_id: 2023-05-23_USCOURTS-utd-2_20-cv-00894_A. v. United Healthcare Insurance et al.pdf
case_name: A. v. United Healthcare Insurance et al.
ai_relevance: Confidential guidelines could train competitors’ AI/ML benefit-decision models.

parties.plaintiff_description: Two individuals under health plan
parties.defendant_description: Health insurance companies and plan administrators

claims.claim: Defendants wrongfully denied or limited coverage for mental health treatment in violation of ERISA.
claims.legal_basis: Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) – improper benefit denial and failure to provide required plan-related information.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; underlying ERISA benefit and disclosure claims remain pending.

claims.claim: Defendants violated the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act by applying more restrictive standards to mental health benefits than to medical/surgical benefits.
claims.legal_basis: Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act (MHPAEA), enforced through ERISA.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; parity claims remain pending.

claims.claim: Defendants must disclose internal guidelines, criteria, and assessment tools used for mental health benefit determinations without confidentiality restrictions, based on ERISA/MHPAEA disclosure obligations.
claims.legal_basis: ERISA and MHPAEA mandatory disclosure provisions; plaintiffs argued these override or limit confidentiality designations in discovery.
claims.outcome: Rejected in part at discovery stage; court upheld defendants’ confidentiality designations and allowed continued use of a protective order for the documents.

defenses.defense: Internal guidelines, assessments, and related documents are proprietary and commercially sensitive, warranting protection from public disclosure.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) – good cause for protective order to prevent annoyance, embarrassment, oppression, or undue burden/expense, including commercial harm.

defenses.defense: Existing protective order already allows plaintiffs sufficient access to the documents for litigation purposes, so removing confidentiality is unnecessary and would cause undue commercial harm.
defenses.legal_basis: Balancing test under Rule 26 and case law on modifying protective orders; court’s discretion to weigh litigants’ needs against risk of competitive harm.

defenses.defense: ERISA and MHPAEA disclosure provisions do not require that these materials be made publicly available outside the confines of discovery and protective orders.
defenses.legal_basis: Interpretation of ERISA and MHPAEA disclosure obligations as compatible with, and not overriding, court-ordered confidentiality protections in civil discovery.

case_id: 2024-02-12_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03416_Silverman et al v. OpenAI_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Silverman et al. v. OpenAI, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over training AI models (ChatGPT) on copyrighted books without consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors and putative class of copyright holders.
parties.defendant_description: AI company and related entities operating ChatGPT.

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ books to train OpenAI’s AI language models, including ChatGPT, without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Not described as dismissed in the summary; appears to survive at least in part at motion-to-dismiss stage, with plaintiffs allowed to amend related allegations.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement for allegedly profiting from and having the right and ability to control infringing uses of plaintiffs’ works by the AI models and users.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq. (vicarious liability doctrine).
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for failure to sufficiently allege required elements; plaintiffs granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Violation of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act for removal or alteration of copyright management information associated with plaintiffs’ works in the training and output of the AI models.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), 17 U.S.C. § 1202.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss due to insufficient factual allegations; plaintiffs granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Negligence in developing, training, and deploying AI models using plaintiffs’ copyrighted books without adequate care for authors’ rights and interests.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law negligence under California law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim; plaintiffs granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment based on OpenAI’s alleged receipt and retention of benefits from using plaintiffs’ works to train AI models without compensating the authors.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable unjust enrichment / restitution under California law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss; court found unjust enrichment not independently viable as pled; plaintiffs granted leave to amend.

claims.claim: Unfair business practices by using copyrighted books without consent to train AI models, thereby gaining an unfair competitive advantage and harming authors.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, “unfair” prong.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to the “unfair” prong; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Other UCL theories (unlawful and/or fraudulent prongs) premised on alleged copyright and related violations.
claims.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law (UCL), Cal. Bus. & Prof. Code § 17200, “unlawful” and/or “fraudulent” prongs.
claims.outcome: To the extent based on dismissed underlying claims, these theories were dismissed or limited; plaintiffs given opportunity to amend consistent with the court’s rulings.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because plaintiffs did not adequately plead elements of vicarious infringement, DMCA violations, negligence, unjust enrichment, or certain UCL theories.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Insufficient factual allegations connecting specific model outputs to plaintiffs’ works and to any actionable copying or removal of copyright management information.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 8(a) and 12(b)(6) (Twombly/Iqbal).

defenses.defense: UCL claims cannot proceed where based solely on alleged violations that are not independently actionable or insufficiently pled.
defenses.legal_basis: California Unfair Competition Law doctrine limiting “unlawful” and “fraudulent” prongs to adequately pled underlying violations.

case_id: 2019-06-18_USCOURTS-mad-1_18-cv-12336_Conning v. Halpern et al.pdf
case_name: Andrew Scott Conning v. Jack Halpern and CJK Dictionary Institute, Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual based in Massachusetts
parties.defendant_name: Jack Halpern and CJK Dictionary Institute, Inc.
parties.defendant_description: Individual and corporation based in Japan

claims.claim: Defamation
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts common law of defamation
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; defamation claim allowed to proceed in District of Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with advantageous or contractual relations
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts common law of tortious interference
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; tortious interference claim allowed to proceed in District of Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Violation of Massachusetts consumer protection laws
claims.legal_basis: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 93A
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; Chapter 93A claim allowed to proceed in District of Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Enforcement of an arbitration award
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state law governing confirmation and enforcement of arbitration awards
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction denied; claim to enforce arbitration award allowed to proceed in District of Massachusetts.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction
defenses.legal_basis: Massachusetts long-arm statute and Fourteenth Amendment Due Process Clause; defendants argued their limited contacts with Massachusetts were insufficient for specific jurisdiction.

case_id: 2024-03-29_USCOURTS-mad-1_23-cv-11097_Bulwer v. EchoNous_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Bulwer v. EchoNous, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over work on AI-enabled ultrasound diagnostic device and software.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual medical doctor and echocardiography specialist contractor
parties.defendant_description: Corporation developing AI-enabled ultrasound software and devices

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment for pre-October 26, 2021 services provided to EchoNous related to its Kosmos AI-enabled ultrasound device.
claims.legal_basis: Common law unjust enrichment (equitable restitution for benefits conferred without payment).
claims.outcome: Court denied EchoNous’ motion to dismiss; unjust enrichment claim for pre-Agreement services may proceed in Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Quantum meruit for the reasonable value of pre-October 26, 2021 services addressing technical challenges and creating training protocols for Kosmos.
claims.legal_basis: Common law quantum meruit (implied-in-law contract for value of services).
claims.outcome: Court denied EchoNous’ motion to dismiss; quantum meruit claim for pre-Agreement services may proceed in Massachusetts.

claims.claim: Opposition to enforcement of forum selection clause requiring litigation in Washington state for these pre-Agreement service claims.
claims.legal_basis: Contract interpretation; forum selection clause applicability only to disputes “related to” the Independent Contractor Agreement effective October 26, 2021.
claims.outcome: Court held the clause did not cover pre-Agreement services; motion to transfer venue to Washington denied and case remains in Massachusetts.

defenses.defense: Independent Contractor Agreement bars recovery for pre-October 26, 2021 services because it governs the parties’ entire relationship, including past work.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law; argument that written agreement supersedes prior understandings and implied obligations, precluding unjust enrichment and quantum meruit.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court held the Agreement was not retroactive and did not cover pre-Agreement services.

defenses.defense: Forum selection clause in the Independent Contractor Agreement requires that the case be brought in Washington state, not Massachusetts.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law; enforceability of mandatory forum selection clauses under federal venue and transfer standards (e.g., 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a)).
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court found the pre-Agreement services were not sufficiently related to the Agreement to trigger the clause, so venue remains in Massachusetts.

case_id: 2023-04-03_USCOURTS-mad-1_22-cv-11708_Groma_ LLC v. BuildRE_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Groma, LLC v. BuildRE, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: One defendant designs AI-based vehicle automation software; dispute is trademark jurisdictional, not about AI.

parties.plaintiff_description: Massachusetts-based business entity
parties.defendant_description: Texas and Turkey-based business entities

claims.claim: Federal and/or state trademark infringement regarding use of the Groma name/mark.
claims.legal_basis: Trademark laws (likely Lanham Act and related state trademark/unfair competition provisions).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over all defendants.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop defendants’ alleged trademark infringement.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief ancillary to trademark infringement claims.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the court lacked personal jurisdiction and dismissed the case.

defenses.defense: Massachusetts court lacks personal jurisdiction over Texas and Turkey-based defendants.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; insufficient minimum contacts with Massachusetts.

case_id: 2017-08-29_USCOURTS-cand-3_17-cv-03049_Purepredictive_ Inc. v. H20.AI_ Inc..pdf
case_name: PurePredictive, Inc. v. H2O.AI, Inc.
ai_relevance: Patent concerns automated predictive analytics using AI and machine learning models.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation owning predictive analytics patent.
parties.defendant_description: Corporation providing machine learning software platform.

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 8,880,446 related to an automated predictive analytics factory.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 for alleged infringement of the ’446 Patent.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court held all asserted claims of the ’446 Patent are patent-ineligible abstract ideas under 35 U.S.C. § 101, so no viable infringement claim remained.

claims.claim: Request for relief including damages and injunctive relief for alleged infringement of the ’446 Patent.
claims.legal_basis: Remedies provisions under the Patent Act, including 35 U.S.C. §§ 283–284.
claims.outcome: Denied as moot because the underlying patent infringement claim was dismissed under 35 U.S.C. § 101.

defenses.defense: The asserted claims of the ’446 Patent are directed to abstract ideas involving mathematical algorithms and predictive analytics and are therefore not patent-eligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank and related abstract-idea jurisprudence.

defenses.defense: The patent merely implements conventional mathematical processes on generic computer components without an inventive concept, so it cannot be enforced against H2O.AI.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice two-step framework requiring an inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation.

case_id: 2024-10-23_USCOURTS-mdd-1_23-cv-01822_Battle v. Microsoft Corporation.pdf
case_name: Jeffery Battle v. Microsoft Corporation
ai_relevance: Claims arise from Bing search and Microsoft Copilot AI chatbot misidentification

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer allegedly misidentified as terrorist
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation providing Bing and Copilot services

claims.claim: Defamation based on Bing search results and Microsoft Copilot content allegedly conflating plaintiff with a convicted terrorist
claims.legal_basis: State-law defamation and related tort principles concerning false and harmful statements
claims.outcome: Court did not reach merits; claim compelled to arbitration under Microsoft Services Agreement and federal case stayed

claims.claim: General harm and reputational injury caused by Microsoft’s AI-driven services misidentifying plaintiff as a terrorist
claims.legal_basis: State-law tort claims for reputational and personal harm (e.g., negligence or similar theories)
claims.outcome: Court did not reach merits; claim compelled to arbitration under Microsoft Services Agreement and federal case stayed

defenses.defense: Existence of a binding arbitration agreement in the Microsoft Services Agreement covering plaintiff’s use of Microsoft services
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law enforcing arbitration clauses
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court held arbitration agreement valid and enforceable and compelled arbitration

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s claims fall within the scope of the Microsoft Services Agreement’s arbitration clause
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation principles determining breadth of arbitration provisions
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court found plaintiff’s defamation and related harm claims subject to arbitration

defenses.defense: Request that the court stay the judicial proceedings pending completion of arbitration
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act authority to stay actions when issues are referable to arbitration
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted; court stayed the case rather than dismissing it

case_id: 2025-03-25_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over training Anthropic’s Claude AI on copyrighted song lyrics.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers and copyright owners of song lyrics
parties.defendant_description: AI company developing and operating Claude models

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s alleged use of plaintiffs’ copyrighted song lyrics to train its Claude AI models without authorization or license.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (exclusive rights in copyrighted works, including reproduction and use in training datasets).
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling yet; court denied plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction for failure to show likelihood of irreparable harm.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop Anthropic from using, reproducing, or relying on plaintiffs’ copyrighted lyrics in training, operating, or updating its AI models pending final resolution of the case.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief standards under federal law (likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, balance of equities, and public interest).
claims.outcome: Denied; court held plaintiffs did not demonstrate a likelihood of irreparable harm sufficient to justify preliminary injunctive relief.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs have not shown irreparable harm from Anthropic’s alleged use of lyrics in AI training or outputs, so preliminary injunction is unwarranted.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal standard for preliminary injunctions requiring proof of likely irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs are unlikely to succeed on the merits of their copyright claims, or at least have not made a sufficient showing at the preliminary injunction stage.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring likelihood of success on the merits.

case_id: 2014-11-17_USCOURTS-mied-2_13-cv-14026_Odish v. Morgenthaler Ventures et al.pdf
case_name: Odish v. Morgenthaler Ventures et al.
ai_relevance: alleged diminution of value of SILVIA AI platform (chatbot, human interacting bot) owned by Cognitive Code, in which plaintiffs claimed interests.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual investor and his consulting LLC
parties.defendant_description: Technology company, venture firm, and related business entities

claims.claim: Defendants committed acts that diminished the value of Cognitive Code, Inc. and its SILVIA AI platform, harming plaintiffs’ ownership and economic interests.
claims.legal_basis: State-law business torts and related economic injury theories (e.g., interference, mismanagement, or similar claims) asserted under Michigan law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching merits because the court found no personal jurisdiction over any defendants.

claims.claim: Defendants’ contacts with Michigan were sufficient to subject them to personal jurisdiction in the Eastern District of Michigan for claims related to Cognitive Code and SILVIA.
claims.legal_basis: Michigan long-arm statute and federal due process (minimum contacts and purposeful availment).
claims.outcome: Rejected; the court held defendants lacked sufficient Michigan contacts and recommended dismissal for lack of personal jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over the defendants because they have insufficient contacts with Michigan related to the dispute over Cognitive Code and SILVIA.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal due process limits on personal jurisdiction and Michigan long-arm statute requirements.

defenses.defense: Even if plaintiffs allege harm in Michigan, defendants did not purposefully avail themselves of conducting activities in Michigan in connection with the challenged conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional minimum-contacts and purposeful-availment standards for specific jurisdiction.

case_id: 2021-05-14_USCOURTS-cand-5_20-cv-07173_Prevail Legal_ Inc. v. Gordon et al.pdf
case_name: Prevail Legal, Inc. v. Gordon et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-powered real-time transcription software critical to plaintiff’s services.

parties.plaintiff_description: Company providing AI-based real-time transcription services.
parties.defendant_description: Software development company and its owner in Hawaii.

claims.claim: Unauthorized deletion of software critical to Prevail’s AI transcription operations, causing project delays and damages.
claims.legal_basis: State-law tort and/or contract claims related to wrongful interference with software and business operations (exact causes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction in the Northern District of California; plaintiff allowed to refile in Hawaii.

claims.claim: Assertion that California federal court could exercise personal jurisdiction over ShakaCode and Justin Gordon based on server location and communications with Prevail executives in California.
claims.legal_basis: Federal due process and California long-arm statute standards for specific personal jurisdiction (purposeful direction and relatedness).
claims.outcome: Court held personal jurisdiction was lacking; incidental California server location and communications were insufficient, so the case was dismissed without prejudice.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over ShakaCode and Justin Gordon in California because their conduct was not purposefully directed at California.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction; California long-arm statute coextensive with federal due process.

defenses.defense: Connections to California—such as a third-party server located there and communications with Prevail’s executives—are too attenuated to establish jurisdiction.
defenses.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction doctrine requiring more than incidental or fortuitous forum contacts to satisfy purposeful availment/direction.

case_id: 2024-08-14_USCOURTS-ded-1_24-cv-00084_Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc..pdf
case_name: Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves AI-driven dashboard camera technology allegedly infringed and misused.

parties.plaintiff_description: Delaware corporation offering AI telematics solutions.
parties.defendant_description: Delaware corporation providing fleet management technology.

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to Samsara’s technology, including AI-driven dashboard cameras.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under Title 35 of the U.S. Code.
claims.outcome: Substantive patent claims not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Misappropriation of Samsara’s proprietary technology and confidential information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and related proprietary rights law (likely state and/or federal).
claims.outcome: Substantive misappropriation claims not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Opposition to Motive’s motion to transfer venue from Delaware to the Northern District of California.
claims.legal_basis: Plaintiff’s reliance on 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) factors favoring its chosen forum.
claims.outcome: Court rejected Samsara’s position and granted Motive’s motion to transfer venue to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: Request to transfer venue to the Northern District of California based on convenience and interests of justice.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (change of venue for convenience and in the interest of justice).

case_id: 2016-02-29_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff’s AI technology forms core alleged trade secrets at issue.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology startup corporation
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and related individual and corporate defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop’s AI technology and business information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trade secret law (e.g., DTSA/UTSA equivalents).
claims.outcome: Underlying claim not resolved in this order; court allowed third‑party discovery in part to obtain evidence, limiting scope and time to protect privacy and ensure relevance.

claims.claim: Breach of duties and other related business torts arising from Gatti’s alleged misuse of Loop’s confidential information.
claims.legal_basis: State contract and fiduciary duty/tort law (e.g., breach of fiduciary duty, breach of contract, unfair competition).
claims.outcome: Substantive claim not decided; court partially granted subpoenas for documents (e.g., financial, communications) that could support these claims, while denying overbroad or insufficiently justified requests.

claims.claim: Request for third‑party discovery via subpoenas for documents such as communications, financial records, and phone records to prove misappropriation and related violations.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26 and 45 governing discovery and subpoenas.
claims.outcome: Court granted motion to enforce subpoenas in part and denied in part, narrowing time frames and categories to reduce privacy intrusion and require clear relevance.

defenses.defense: Subpoenaed materials are irrelevant to the trade secret and related claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) relevance and proportionality limits on discovery.

defenses.defense: Subpoenas are overbroad and unduly burdensome in scope and time.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 45(d)(3) (undue burden).

defenses.defense: Subpoenas invade privacy interests of defendants and third parties (e.g., personal communications, financial and phone records).
defenses.legal_basis: Privacy protections under Rule 26 balancing, Rule 45, and applicable state privacy principles.

case_id: 2020-05-15_USCOURTS-azd-2_19-cv-04685_Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.pdf
case_name: Modulus Financial Engineering Incorporated v. Modulus Data USA Incorporated et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation owning financial software trademarks
parties.defendant_name: Modulus Data USA Inc. et al.
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants accused of trademark infringement

claims.claim: Federal trademark infringement
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1114 and related provisions
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants

claims.claim: Unfair competition and false designation of origin
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a) and related state law
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants

claims.claim: Cancellation of defendants’ trademark registrations
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1119 and related provisions
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for lack of personal jurisdiction over defendants

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Arizona federal court
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause; minimum contacts and purposeful availment standards for specific jurisdiction

defenses.defense: Insufficient contacts or activities expressly aimed at Arizona
defenses.legal_basis: Ninth Circuit specific jurisdiction and “express aiming” jurisprudence under Calder effects test

case_id: 2020-06-25_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-12551_Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC.pdf
case_name: Singular Computing LLC v. Google LLC
ai_relevance: Patents cover specialized low-precision arithmetic hardware for AI/ML workloads.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company owning asserted processing patents
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation and service provider

claims.claim: Patent infringement of Singular’s Compact Arithmetic Processing Elements patents by Google’s computing systems.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on patents covering low precision, high dynamic range arithmetic processing methods and hardware.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; at this stage, the court denied Google’s motion to dismiss under 35 U.S.C. § 101, allowing the infringement claims to proceed.

claims.claim: Asserted patents claim patent-eligible subject matter, not merely abstract ideas.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligible subject matter) and case law under Alice/Mayo framework.
claims.outcome: Court agreed at motion-to-dismiss stage that Singular plausibly alleged patent-eligible inventive concepts; motion to dismiss denied.

defenses.defense: Asserted patent claims are directed to abstract ideas and therefore ineligible for patent protection.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice/Mayo two-step framework for patent eligibility.

defenses.defense: Even if implemented on computers, the claims merely recite generic computer functionality without an inventive concept.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Supreme Court and Federal Circuit precedent on abstract ideas implemented on generic computers.

case_id: 2021-06-08_USCOURTS-cand-3_20-cv-09148_People.ai_ Inc. v. SetSail Technologies_ Inc..pdf
case_name: People.ai, Inc. v. SetSail Technologies, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over ML-based CRM and data analytics patent infringement.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company offering AI-driven sales and CRM analytics.
parties.defendant_description: Technology company providing sales performance and analytics software.

claims.claim: Direct infringement of People.ai’s patents by SetSail’s software products.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(a) – direct patent infringement of data analytics and CRM patents involving machine learning.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice on Rule 12(b)(6); court found complaint lacked sufficient factual allegations showing how SetSail’s software met specific claim elements.

claims.claim: Indirect infringement of People.ai’s patents (inducement and/or contributory infringement).
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271(b) and/or § 271(c) – indirect patent infringement based on SetSail’s making, using, offering for sale, or selling accused software.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; underlying direct infringement allegations were inadequately pled, so indirect infringement theories were not plausibly stated.

claims.claim: Willful infringement of People.ai’s patents by SetSail.
claims.legal_basis: Enhanced damages for willful infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 284 and related Federal Circuit precedent.
claims.outcome: Effectively dismissed with the complaint; court found no sufficient factual basis for plausible willfulness where basic infringement was not adequately alleged.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for patent infringement due to insufficient factual allegations.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Twombly/Iqbal pleading standards requiring plausible, fact-based allegations showing how accused products practice each claim element.

defenses.defense: Complaint does not explain how accused software meets specific elements of asserted patent claims (“how and why” requirement).
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Circuit and district court precedent on patent pleading sufficiency (e.g., requiring element-by-element or function-by-function factual mapping, not conclusory assertions).

case_id: 2021-09-01_USCOURTS-casd-3_20-cv-00862_Lin et al v. Suavei_ Inc. et al.pdf
case_name: Lin et al. v. Suavei, Inc. et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misrepresentations about machine-learning cybersecurity product capabilities.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual investors in Suavei, Inc. technology company
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation and its board members

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty by certain board members related to misrepresentations about the company and its technology product.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate fiduciary duty law (duty of care and loyalty).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; plaintiffs allowed to amend to plead sufficient facts.

claims.claim: Breach of duty of loyalty by certain board members in connection with alleged misleading statements about the product’s capabilities and corporate governance conduct harming investors.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate law duty of loyalty owed by directors to stockholders.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice; plaintiffs allowed to amend to clarify and support the claim.

claims.claim: Direct claims by stockholders based on alleged misrepresentations about the product’s capabilities (including containerized microservices architecture) that allegedly affected stockholders directly rather than the corporation as a whole.
claims.legal_basis: State corporate and securities-related principles distinguishing direct from derivative stockholder claims.
claims.outcome: Court allowed these allegations to remain; did not strike paragraphs and treated them as potentially viable direct claims, subject to further proceedings.

claims.claim: Assertion of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Wong for claims arising from alleged misrepresentations and fiduciary breaches.
claims.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction under applicable state long-arm statute and Due Process Clause (minimum contacts).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held it lacked personal jurisdiction over Defendant Wong and granted her motion to dismiss.
