claims.claim: Assertion of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante for claims arising from alleged misrepresentations and fiduciary breaches.
claims.legal_basis: Personal jurisdiction under applicable state long-arm statute and Due Process Clause (minimum contacts).
claims.outcome: Denied; court held it had personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante and allowed claims against him to proceed.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Wong.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause and state long-arm statute; insufficient minimum contacts with the forum state.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Defendant Infante.
defenses.legal_basis: Due Process Clause and state long-arm statute; argued insufficient contacts, contested by plaintiffs.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for breach of fiduciary duty and duty of loyalty.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) standard; alleged facts insufficient to plausibly show breach under state corporate law.

defenses.defense: Motion to strike paragraphs alleging direct stockholder harm from misrepresentations as improper or irrelevant.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(f) motion to strike redundant, immaterial, impertinent, or scandalous matter from the complaint.

case_id: 2025-03-31_USCOURTS-flsd-0_24-cv-60715_Anderson v. MSC Cruises_ S.A..pdf
case_name: Anderson v. MSC Cruises S.A.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual cruise ship worker alleging personal injury
parties.defendant_description: Cruise line company operating passenger vessels

claims.claim: Negligence and related maritime personal-injury claims arising from injuries suffered while working aboard MSC’s vessel
claims.legal_basis: General maritime law and/or Jones Act–type seafarer injury principles; asserted directly against vessel operator MSC Cruises
claims.outcome: Court granted MSC Cruises’ motion to compel arbitration; claims ordered to be resolved in arbitration pursuant to the employment contract’s arbitration clause governed by Maltese law with arbitration in Panama

claims.claim: Vicarious liability and/or joint-employer liability for unsafe working conditions aboard the vessel
claims.legal_basis: Maritime tort and employment-related liability theories premised on plaintiff’s work for Espit Ventures aboard MSC’s ship
claims.outcome: Included within the scope of the compelled arbitration; court did not reach merits and required these theories to be arbitrated under the Espit employment agreement’s arbitration provision

defenses.defense: Right to compel arbitration under plaintiff’s employment contract with Espit Ventures
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and doctrine of equitable estoppel allowing a non-signatory (MSC) to enforce the arbitration clause where plaintiff’s claims are intertwined with the contract containing the arbitration agreement

defenses.defense: Non-signatory status does not bar enforcement of arbitration clause
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable estoppel and related federal common law of arbitration permitting non-signatories to compel arbitration when claims rely on or are closely connected to the underlying contract

case_id: 2025-03-26_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI model Claude training and outputs using song lyrics.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishing companies and rights holders
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company developing Claude models

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s AI model using and distributing song lyrics in a way that facilitates infringement by users or other third parties.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law – secondary liability for contributory infringement under the Copyright Act.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for lack of specific allegations of direct third‑party infringement and insufficiently pled knowledge; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement based on Anthropic’s alleged ability to supervise and control infringing uses of song lyrics by its AI model and to profit from such uses.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law – secondary liability for vicarious infringement under the Copyright Act.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss because plaintiffs did not adequately allege direct third‑party infringement or Anthropic’s right and ability to supervise such infringement; dismissal with leave to amend.

claims.claim: Removal or alteration of copyright management information (CMI) in connection with the use of song lyrics by Anthropic’s AI model, including training and outputs that allegedly omit or strip attribution and other CMI.
claims.legal_basis: Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA), 17 U.S.C. § 1202 – prohibition on removal or alteration of copyright management information.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on motion to dismiss for failure to sufficiently allege Anthropic’s knowledge and intent regarding CMI removal; dismissal with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to allege specific acts of direct copyright infringement by any third party that Anthropic supposedly contributed to or benefited from.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards for secondary copyright liability under the Copyright Act and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not plausibly allege that Anthropic knew of, or had reason to know of, specific infringing acts by users or other third parties.
defenses.legal_basis: Knowledge requirement for contributory infringement and for DMCA § 1202 claims, evaluated under Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs did not adequately allege that Anthropic had the right and ability to supervise the specific infringing conduct or that it directly profited from such infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Elements of vicarious copyright infringement under the Copyright Act and Rule 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs insufficiently alleged that Anthropic intentionally removed or altered copyright management information, or distributed works knowing CMI had been removed, as required by the DMCA.
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory elements of DMCA § 1202 and federal pleading standards under Rule 12(b)(6).

case_id: 2023-08-18_USCOURTS-dcd-1_22-cv-01564_THALER v. PERLMUTTER et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over copyrightability of AI-generated artwork created autonomously by Creativity Machine.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office officials and federal agency

claims.claim: Challenge to denial of copyright registration for AI-generated artwork
claims.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act and Copyright Act; alleged that the Copyright Office unlawfully refused registration by imposing a human-authorship requirement not supported by statute or misapplied to his application.
claims.outcome: Court rejected the challenge and upheld the Copyright Office’s denial of registration, holding that works generated autonomously by AI without human authorship are not copyrightable.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that AI-generated work is copyrightable
claims.legal_basis: Declaratory Judgment Act and Copyright Act; sought declaration that the AI-created image qualifies as a protectable “work of authorship” and that Thaler could be recognized as its author or owner.
claims.outcome: Court denied declaratory relief, holding that the work is ineligible for copyright because it lacks human authorship and Thaler cannot be deemed the author of a fully autonomous AI creation.

claims.claim: Request for order compelling registration of the AI-generated work
claims.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act; sought an order directing the Register of Copyrights to issue a registration for the AI-generated artwork.
claims.outcome: Court declined to order registration and entered judgment for defendants, affirming the agency’s refusal to register the work.

defenses.defense: Human authorship is a prerequisite for copyright protection
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act interpreted in light of longstanding precedent and Copyright Office practice requiring human creativity; non-human authors (including autonomous AI) cannot obtain copyright.

defenses.defense: Agency acted within its statutory authority and was not arbitrary or capricious
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act; the Copyright Office reasonably applied the human-authorship requirement in denying registration for a work admittedly created autonomously by AI.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff cannot be the author of a work created entirely by AI
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act’s concept of “author” as a human being; ownership cannot be claimed where no human created the expressive content.

case_id: 2016-06-30_USCOURTS-nmd-1_14-cv-00965_Clark v. Dashner et al.pdf
case_name: Clark v. Dashner et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Author and his book publisher
parties.defendant_description: Author and his book publisher

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on allegations that "The Maze Runner" copied protectable elements of Clark’s earlier novel "The Maze."
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law under the Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.), requiring ownership of a valid copyright and copying of protectable expression with substantial similarity.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice; court found no substantial similarity in protectable elements and that overlapping features (maze, moving walls, robotic creatures) were unprotectable ideas and genre concepts.

claims.claim: Unfair trade practices arising from alleged misuse and exploitation of concepts and elements from "The Maze" in marketing, selling, and distributing "The Maze Runner."
claims.legal_basis: State unfair trade practices statute (unfair or deceptive trade practices) asserted in addition to copyright claim.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as preempted by federal copyright law because the claim did not add extra elements beyond rights equivalent to those protected by copyright.

claims.claim: Unfair competition based on alleged wrongful appropriation of the success and goodwill of "The Maze" through publication and promotion of "The Maze Runner."
claims.legal_basis: State-law unfair competition principles overlapping with copyright interests in the literary work.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as preempted by federal copyright law; the claim was based on the same alleged copying of expressive elements as the copyright claim.

defenses.defense: No substantial similarity between protectable elements of the two works; any similarities concern only general ideas, concepts, and scènes à faire common to the genre.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law’s idea–expression dichotomy and substantial similarity standard; only protectable expression, not ideas or stock elements, can be infringed.

defenses.defense: Alleged similarities involve unprotectable ideas and common genre tropes, such as a dangerous maze, moving walls, and robotic creatures.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 102(b) (exclusion of ideas, concepts, and systems from protection) and case law on unprotectable scènes à faire and stock elements.

defenses.defense: State-law unfair trade practices and unfair competition claims are preempted because they are equivalent to rights within the general scope of copyright.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption provision, 17 U.S.C. § 301, which preempts state-law claims that do not contain extra elements beyond rights equivalent to copyright.

case_id: 2011-04-04_USCOURTS-cand-5_05-cv-03534_Goldberg v. Cameron et al.pdf
case_name: Goldberg v. Cameron et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual screenwriter and composer alleging infringement
parties.defendant_name: Gale Anne Hurd; Pacific Western Productions
parties.defendant_description: Film producer and production company defendants

claims.claim: Contributory copyright infringement based on alleged copying of plaintiff’s script "Long Live Music" and soundtrack "Energy" in the Terminator film franchise.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law under the Copyright Act (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.), contributory infringement theory requiring access, knowledge, and substantial similarity.
claims.outcome: Summary judgment granted for defendants; court found no substantial similarity and no evidence that Hurd had access to or knowledge of plaintiff’s works, so contributory infringement claim failed.

defenses.defense: No substantial similarity between plaintiff’s works and the Terminator franchise.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright law substantial similarity requirement for infringement; without substantial similarity, no direct or contributory infringement can be found.

defenses.defense: Lack of access or knowledge of plaintiff’s works by Gale Anne Hurd before creation of the Terminator films.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement requires proof of access to the copyrighted work; absence of access defeats infringement and contributory infringement claims.

defenses.defense: Failure of contributory infringement claim because no underlying direct infringement can be established.
defenses.legal_basis: Contributory infringement doctrine requires an underlying act of direct infringement; without direct infringement, contributory liability cannot attach.

case_id: 2024-08-14_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-06049_Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc..pdf
case_name: Samsara Inc. v. Motive Technologies Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-powered driver safety camera technology and patents.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing AI-powered fleet safety cameras.
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering fleet management and safety systems.

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to driver safety and dashboard camera technology.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under Title 35 of the U.S. Code.
claims.outcome: Substantive patent infringement claims not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Misappropriation or theft of proprietary driver safety technology.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and related state-law intellectual property protections (likely under California law).
claims.outcome: Substantive misappropriation claims not decided; case transferred to the Northern District of California under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a).

claims.claim: Request to keep the action in the District of Delaware as the chosen forum.
claims.legal_basis: Plaintiff’s choice of forum and general venue principles.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court granted defendant’s motion and ordered transfer to the Northern District of California.

claims.claim: Motion to transfer venue from the District of Delaware to the Northern District of California.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) (convenience of parties and witnesses; interest of justice).
claims.outcome: Granted; the court ordered the entire action transferred to the Northern District of California.

defenses.defense: The Northern District of California is a more convenient and appropriate venue.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) factors: convenience of parties and witnesses, locus of operative facts, and interest of justice.

defenses.defense: California has the strongest connection to the dispute, including parties, witnesses, and governing state law issues.
defenses.legal_basis: Venue transfer jurisprudence weighing local interest and application of California law.

defenses.defense: Judicial economy favors transfer because related proceedings are already pending in the Northern District of California.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) interest-of-justice factor and avoidance of duplicative litigation.

case_id: 2025-01-23_USCOURTS-ksd-6_24-cv-01055_Pathways Management Services_ LLC et al v. Northstar Hospital et al.pdf
case_name: Pathways Management Services, LLC et al. v. NorthStar Hospital et al.
ai_relevance: Protective order restricts use of confidential discovery materials with generative AI tools, barring uploads to open AI systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Business entity operating healthcare-related services facility
parties.defendant_description: Competing healthcare facility and associated defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of confidential business information and trade secrets to establish a competing facility
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation and unfair competition under applicable trade secret and competition laws
claims.outcome: Ongoing; court issued a protective order governing use and disclosure of confidential information during discovery, including AI-related restrictions.

claims.claim: Unfair competition by using plaintiffs’ proprietary information to compete against them
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition under state law and related common law doctrines
claims.outcome: Ongoing; no final liability ruling yet, but discovery is proceeding under a strict protective order.

defenses.defense: Request for protective measures to safeguard confidential information exchanged in discovery
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure governing protective orders and confidentiality in discovery

defenses.defense: Limitations on use and disclosure of confidential information, including prohibition on submitting it to open generative AI tools
defenses.legal_basis: Stipulated protective order approved by the court to prevent improper dissemination or misuse of sensitive data

case_id: 2025-07-29_USCOURTS-tned-3_24-cv-00329_Axis Dynamics et al v. Knox County Tennessee et al.pdf
case_name: Axis Dynamics et al v. Knox County Tennessee et al
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Construction-related company alleging contract rights
parties.defendant_description: Financial institution providing construction loan financing

claims.claim: Breach of contract based on alleged third-party beneficiary rights under the construction loan agreement between the Hawks and FUSB.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing third-party beneficiary rights and enforcement of contracts by non-signatories.
claims.outcome: Dismissed on FUSB’s motion to dismiss; court held Axis Dynamics is not a third-party beneficiary and cannot enforce the loan agreement.

defenses.defense: Axis Dynamics is not an intended third-party beneficiary of the construction loan agreement and therefore lacks standing to enforce it.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law principles limiting enforcement to parties and intended third-party beneficiaries; interpretation of the loan agreement’s terms.

case_id: 2024-01-25_USCOURTS-nyed-2_20-cv-06370_Meehan v. VIPKid et al.pdf
case_name: Meehan v. VIPKid et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged misuse of teachers’ biometric data to develop AI and facial recognition systems without consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual teacher and proposed class representative
parties.defendant_description: Online education companies and associated corporate defendants

claims.claim: Fraud based on alleged undisclosed collection and use of teachers’ biometric data and other information, including for AI and facial recognition development.
claims.legal_basis: Common law fraud and misrepresentation under applicable state law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice in court and compelled to arbitration pursuant to the Independent Contractor Agreement’s arbitration clause.

claims.claim: Conversion of teachers’ biometric data, likeness, and related personal information allegedly taken and used without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Common law conversion under applicable state law.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice in court and compelled to arbitration pursuant to the Independent Contractor Agreement’s arbitration clause.

claims.claim: Deceptive and unfair business practices related to the operation of the VIPKid platform and undisclosed data/biometric collection and use.
claims.legal_basis: State consumer protection and deceptive trade practices statutes.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice in court and compelled to arbitration pursuant to the Independent Contractor Agreement’s arbitration clause.

claims.claim: Labor law violations arising from the teacher engagement, including alleged misclassification and related wage-and-hour issues.
claims.legal_basis: State and/or federal labor and employment statutes governing wages and classification.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice in court and compelled to arbitration pursuant to the Independent Contractor Agreement’s arbitration clause.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of similarly situated VIPKid teachers for the same alleged fraud, conversion, deceptive practices, and labor violations, including AI-related biometric misuse.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 and underlying substantive state and federal laws.
claims.outcome: Class claims not reached on the merits; entire action dismissed from court and claims compelled to arbitration under the Independent Contractor Agreement.

claims.claim: Claims against foreign investor/affiliate defendants (including China Renaissance and Sequoia) for participation in or benefit from the alleged wrongful conduct, including AI-related biometric exploitation.
claims.legal_basis: State common law and statutory liability theories (aiding and abetting, joint enterprise, or similar).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of personal jurisdiction as to certain foreign defendants, including China Renaissance and Sequoia; no merits determination.

defenses.defense: All claims must be resolved by binding arbitration under the Independent Contractor Agreement’s arbitration clause.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contractual arbitration provision in the Independent Contractor Agreement.

defenses.defense: The court lacks personal jurisdiction over certain foreign defendants, including China Renaissance and Sequoia.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on personal jurisdiction under the U.S. Constitution and applicable state long-arm statute.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff is bound by the Independent Contractor Agreement he accepted when using the VIPKid platform, including its dispute resolution terms.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract formation and enforceability principles under state contract law.

case_id: 2016-02-24_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs, Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute arises from alleged misuse of AI technology trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology startup company
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and related defendants, including law firm

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s technology and business information.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely state trade secrets statute and/or DTSA-equivalent theories).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; underlying claim continues. This order only addresses subpoena to Orrick.

claims.claim: Unfair competition arising from alleged misuse of Loop AI’s confidential and proprietary information.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition law and related business tort principles.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; underlying claim continues. This order only addresses subpoena to Orrick.

claims.claim: Demand for production of Orrick’s internal communications via subpoena to support Loop AI’s claims against defendants.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 45) and challenge to assertion of attorney‑client privilege and work‑product protection.
claims.outcome: Partially denied: court granted Orrick’s motion to quash as to most documents, finding them privileged; partially granted to Loop AI as to two emails involving an attorney no longer with Orrick, which were ordered produced.

defenses.defense: Orrick’s internal communications about its representation and ethical obligations are protected by attorney‑client privilege.
defenses.legal_basis: Attorney‑client privilege doctrine protecting law firm’s consultations with its in‑house or internal counsel.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted: court held these communications are privileged and not discoverable, despite concurrent representation issues.

defenses.defense: Work‑product protection over internal assessments and strategy regarding the dispute and Orrick’s obligations.
defenses.legal_basis: Work‑product doctrine under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(3) and related case law.
defenses.defense_outcome: Largely accepted to the extent documents reflected legal strategy; reinforced the decision to quash most of the subpoena.

defenses.defense: Concurrent or past simultaneous representation of Loop and other defendants does not waive Orrick’s privilege over its internal legal communications.
defenses.legal_basis: Privilege law on concurrent representation and law‑firm internal investigations; privilege not vitiated absent specific waiver or exception.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted: court held privilege still applies notwithstanding prior simultaneous representation.

defenses.defense: Communications that did not involve legal advice or included third parties (e.g., an attorney no longer with Orrick) are not privileged and may be produced without undermining core protections.
defenses.legal_basis: Limits of attorney‑client privilege: no protection for non‑legal communications or those including non‑client third parties.
defenses.defense_outcome: Partially accepted but led to limited disclosure: court ordered production of two emails involving an attorney no longer with Orrick, while maintaining privilege over the rest.

case_id: 2017-05-01_USCOURTS-ca13-16-01999_EMC Corporation v. Clouding Corp..pdf
case_name: EMC Corporation v. Clouding Corp.
ai_relevance: Patent concerns AI-based automated system for diagnosing and resolving computer issues.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation challenging patent validity
parties.defendant_description: Patent-holding technology corporation

claims.claim: Clouding Corp. holds valid patent claims covering an AI-based system for diagnosing and solving computer system issues, including saving the system state when a solution cannot be determined.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. patent law granting exclusive rights to patented inventions
claims.outcome: PTAB initially upheld patentability of certain claims as not obvious; Federal Circuit vacated and remanded for further obviousness analysis.

claims.claim: EMC Corporation contends that the challenged patent claims are unpatentable as obvious in light of the combined teachings of Barnett and Allen, particularly regarding saving the state of the computer system when a solution cannot be determined.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 103 (obviousness) based on prior-art references Barnett and Allen
claims.outcome: Federal Circuit held PTAB erred by not fully considering EMC’s combination-of-references arguments; PTAB decision vacated and case remanded to reconsider obviousness, including whether the combination suggests saving the system state.

defenses.defense: The patent claims are not obvious because the prior art, including Barnett and Allen, does not teach or suggest the claimed step of saving the state of the computer system when a solution cannot be determined.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 103; non-obviousness over cited prior art

defenses.defense: PTAB’s original determination that the claims were not unpatentable for obviousness should be upheld because EMC’s arguments about the Allen reference and its combination with Barnett were insufficient or not properly raised.
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative patent review standards and deference to PTAB fact-finding on obviousness

case_id: 2025-01-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_24-cv-02655_Dubus et al v. NVIDIA Corporation.pdf
case_name: Dubus et al v. NVIDIA Corporation (consolidated with Nazemian v. NVIDIA Inc.)
ai_relevance: Case concerns protection of NVIDIA’s proprietary AI and machine-learning technology, models, and source code in discovery.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual plaintiffs in civil actions against NVIDIA
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation specializing in GPUs and AI hardware/software

claims.claim: Underlying civil claims by Dubus and Nazemian against NVIDIA (exact causes of action not specified in summary).
claims.legal_basis: Not specified in provided summary (likely statutory and/or common-law claims).
claims.outcome: No merits ruling described; court only ruled on discovery confidentiality via protective order.

claims.claim: Request to protect confidential discovery material, including AI and machine-learning source code, models, and algorithms, from improper disclosure or use.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(c) (protective orders) and trade secret/confidential business information doctrines.
claims.outcome: Granted; court entered a detailed protective order governing designation, access, use, and handling of confidential and highly confidential material.

defenses.defense: Need to limit disclosure and use of NVIDIA’s proprietary technology, trade secrets, and non-public AI/ML materials to prevent competitive harm.
defenses.legal_basis: FRCP 26(c) good-cause standard for protective orders; trade secret and confidential business information protections under federal and state law.

defenses.defense: Implementation of strict access controls, confidentiality tiers, and a prosecution bar is necessary to balance discovery needs with protection of sensitive AI-related information.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority to manage discovery; FRCP 26(c) allowing tailored protective measures including prosecution bars.

case_id: 2023-08-29_USCOURTS-nyed-2_20-cv-06370_Meehan v. VIPKid et al.pdf
case_name: Meehan v. VIPKid et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged secret biometric collection to build AI ‘virtual human’ teachers.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual teacher, class representative for online instructors
parties.defendant_description: Online education companies operating remote English-teaching platform

claims.claim: Defendants secretly collected and used teachers’ biometric data (e.g., facial geometry) without informed consent while they taught on the VIPKid platform.
claims.legal_basis: Privacy and biometric data protection laws; intrusion upon seclusion; related statutory and common-law privacy rights (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Claim not adjudicated on merits; court recommended dismissal of lawsuit in favor of arbitration under contractual arbitration clause.

claims.claim: Defendants used the collected biometric and video data to develop AI, AGI, and ‘virtual human’ teachers intended to replace human teachers, without disclosure or compensation.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair and deceptive practices; misrepresentation/omission; unjust enrichment; possible misuse of likeness and data (exact statutory bases not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Claim not adjudicated on merits; court recommended that dispute be resolved in arbitration pursuant to the parties’ agreement.

claims.claim: Defendants engaged in a conspiracy among VIPKid and related entities to exploit American teachers’ biometric data for AI development.
claims.legal_basis: Civil conspiracy and related common-law theories tied to underlying privacy and unfair-practice violations.
claims.outcome: Claim not adjudicated on merits; entire conspiracy theory sent to arbitration and case recommended for dismissal from court.

claims.claim: Class action claims on behalf of similarly situated teachers for unlawful biometric collection and AI-related misuse of their data.
claims.legal_basis: Class action under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23, premised on underlying privacy, biometric, and unfair-practice claims.
claims.outcome: Class certification and class claims not reached; court recommended dismissal and compelled arbitration of Meehan’s individual dispute under the arbitration agreement.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s claims are subject to a binding arbitration agreement he signed, requiring that disputes be resolved by arbitration rather than in court.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contractual arbitration clauses in VIPKid teacher agreements, including delegation of enforceability questions to the arbitrator.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted by court; recommendation to dismiss case and compel arbitration, leaving validity and scope issues to arbitrator.

defenses.defense: Questions about the validity, scope, and enforceability of the arbitration clause must be decided by the arbitrator, not the court.
defenses.legal_basis: Delegation provision within the arbitration agreement and FAA principles that arbitrators decide gateway issues when clearly delegated.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted by court; court declined to rule on validity/enforceability of arbitration clause and referred those issues to arbitration.

case_id: 2015-09-18_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged misuse of Loop AI’s artificial intelligence trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology company and trade secret owner
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and alleged co-conspirators, including Italian competitors

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s technology and business information
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trade secret law (e.g., DTSA/UTSA equivalents)
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; court only narrowed discovery subpoenas and protective order terms.

claims.claim: Conspiracy with Almaviva Defendants to sabotage Loop AI’s investor relations
claims.legal_basis: State law civil conspiracy and related business tort principles
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; underlying merits unaffected, only discovery scope decided.

claims.claim: Unlawful use of Loop AI’s confidential and proprietary AI-related information by competitors
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation and unfair competition statutes/common law
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; court addressed only third‑party discovery and confidentiality procedures.

claims.claim: Relief through subpoenas to Russell Reynolds Associates for documents and depositions about Gatti’s placement with a competitor
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26 and 45 governing discovery and subpoenas
claims.outcome: Partially granted and narrowed; court limited subpoena scope to documents directly related to Gatti’s employment and interactions with Loop AI and Almaviva Defendants, and set deposition procedures.

claims.claim: Entry of a broad protective order with additional plaintiff‑requested restrictions on use and handling of confidential information
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) (protective orders)
claims.outcome: Partially denied; court rejected several extra plaintiff provisions but required inclusion of a secure transmission provision for sensitive materials.

defenses.defense: Subpoenas to Russell Reynolds Associates are overbroad, unduly burdensome, and seek irrelevant information
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 45(d) proportionality and burden limits

defenses.defense: Opposition to plaintiff’s proposed expansive protective order terms as unnecessary and overly restrictive
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) balancing of need for protection against burden and fairness in discovery

case_id: 2016-07-19_USCOURTS-cand-3_16-cv-02935_Doe 1 et al v. Xytex Corporation et al.pdf
case_name: Doe 1 et al. v. Xytex Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: Indirectly referenced: sperm donor’s profile said he pursued a Ph.D. in artificial intelligence, but AI did not cause or shape the legal dispute.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumers using artificial insemination services
parties.defendant_description: Corporate providers of human semen and related services

claims.claim: Product-liability and related claims arising from the sale of human semen for artificial insemination, including alleged misrepresentations in the donor profile.
claims.legal_basis: State product-liability and misrepresentation laws (specific statutes not detailed in summary).
claims.outcome: No merits ruling yet; court only addressed procedural issue of transfer and held motion to transfer in abeyance.

defenses.defense: The case must be litigated in Georgia pursuant to a forum-selection clause in the website’s site usage agreement.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract law enforcing forum-selection clauses; motion to transfer venue based on the clause and related federal venue-transfer standards.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs are bound by the browsewrap site usage agreement, including the forum-selection clause, through their use of the website.
defenses.legal_basis: Contract assent principles applied to online browsewrap agreements and enforceability of website terms.

case_id: 2011-06-03_USCOURTS-cand-4_11-cv-00420_Autonomy_ Inc v. Adiscov_ L.L.C..pdf
case_name: Autonomy, Inc. v. Adiscov, L.L.C.
ai_relevance: Patent concerns use of artificial intelligence for electronic discovery processes.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation challenging validity of AI e-discovery patent.
parties.defendant_description: Limited liability company holding AI e-discovery patent.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Adiscov’s patent relating to AI-based electronic discovery is invalid and/or unenforceable.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act and federal patent law (invalidity and unenforceability of patent).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without reaching patent merits because court found no personal jurisdiction over Adiscov in California.

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that Autonomy does not infringe Adiscov’s patent.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act and federal patent law (non‑infringement).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice on jurisdictional grounds; court declined to adjudicate non‑infringement due to lack of personal jurisdiction over Adiscov.

defenses.defense: The California federal court lacks personal jurisdiction over Adiscov.
defenses.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Adiscov has insufficient minimum contacts or activities purposefully directed at California to justify being sued there.
defenses.legal_basis: Minimum contacts and purposeful availment requirements under International Shoe and related personal jurisdiction precedent.

case_id: 2015-09-08_USCOURTS-cand-4_14-cv-01650_Blue Spike_ LLC v. Google Inc..pdf
case_name: Blue Spike, LLC v. Google Inc.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding company asserting comparison technology patents
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation and online services provider

claims.claim: Google’s products and services infringed five Blue Spike patents covering systems and methods for generating digital “abstracts” or fingerprints of electronic content and comparing them to identify or verify content.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under the Patent Act, 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq., based on five asserted patents related to electronic content comparison and fingerprinting.
claims.outcome: Court granted Google’s motion for judgment on the pleadings and held all asserted patent claims invalid under 35 U.S.C. § 101 as unpatentable abstract ideas, disposing of Blue Spike’s infringement claims.

defenses.defense: The asserted patents are invalid because they are directed to an abstract idea—comparing one thing to another using digital fingerprints—and therefore claim ineligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (patent-eligible subject matter; abstract idea doctrine under Alice/Mayo framework).

defenses.defense: The patent claims lack an inventive concept beyond the abstract idea of content comparison implemented on generic computer technology.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101 (requirement of an “inventive concept” to transform an abstract idea into patent-eligible subject matter).

case_id: 2022-03-03_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-10019_Wired Infomatics_ LLC v. OmniMD.pdf
case_name: Wired Informatics, LLC v. OmniMD, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on performance of Invenio AI natural language processing software.

parties.plaintiff_description: Business providing AI software and related services
parties.defendant_description: Business customer licensing AI medical software

claims.claim: Breach of contract for failure to pay license fees under the Master Software License and Services Agreement.
claims.legal_basis: Common law breach of contract under the Master Software License and Services Agreement.
claims.outcome: Plaintiff’s motion for partial summary judgment on this claim was denied due to genuine disputes of material fact regarding plaintiff’s performance and contractual obligations, including technical support.

claims.claim: Breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing based on OmniMD’s nonpayment and conduct under the Agreement.
claims.legal_basis: Common law implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing arising from the contract.
claims.outcome: Plaintiff’s motion for partial summary judgment on this claim was denied because factual disputes remained about whether plaintiff fulfilled its obligations and whether defendant’s conduct was unjustified.

defenses.defense: The Invenio Program did not function as promised and failed to perform as represented, so OmniMD was justified in withholding payment.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure of consideration / material breach by plaintiff; common law contract principles regarding nonperformance and defective performance.

defenses.defense: Wired Informatics failed to provide the level and type of technical support required under the Agreement, excusing OmniMD’s performance.
defenses.legal_basis: Prior material breach and nonperformance by the other party under common law contract principles.

case_id: 2015-12-21_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation of AI-related trade secrets and technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology company
parties.defendant_description: Former CEO and associated defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s technology and business information.
claims.legal_basis: California trade secret law and related federal trade secret principles; procedural requirement under Cal. Code Civ. Proc. § 2019.210 to identify trade secrets with reasonable particularity before discovery.
claims.outcome: On the discovery motion, the court held Loop AI’s existing trade secret disclosure was insufficient and ordered Loop AI to provide a more detailed, particularized trade secret disclosure compliant with § 2019.210.

claims.claim: Request to proceed with full discovery without first providing a more particularized trade secret disclosure.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 et seq.) and argument that § 2019.210 should not bar or unduly limit discovery in federal court.
claims.outcome: Denied in part; the court required a more detailed trade secret disclosure before discovery into the trade secret misappropriation claim, but allowed other, non–trade secret-related discovery to proceed.

defenses.defense: Motion to compel a specific, particularized trade secret disclosure before allowing discovery into trade secret issues.
defenses.legal_basis: California Code of Civil Procedure § 2019.210 requiring identification of trade secrets with reasonable particularity before discovery in trade secret actions.

defenses.defense: Motion to stay all discovery until Loop AI served an adequate trade secret disclosure.
defenses.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority to manage discovery and apply § 2019.210 as a prerequisite to discovery on trade secret claims.

case_id: 2015-09-21_USCOURTS-txed-2_14-cv-00906_Gonzalez v. InfoStream Group Inc..pdf
case_name: Gonzalez v. InfoStream Group Inc.
ai_relevance: Patents cover AI-enabled host websites improving label-based internet searching.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual patent owner and inventor
parties.defendant_description: Corporation accused of patent infringement

claims.claim: Patent infringement of five U.S. patents covering digital label-based website searching systems and methods.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) and related patent law doctrines.
claims.outcome: Court issued claim construction order; construed disputed terms largely by their plain and ordinary meaning, rejecting indefiniteness challenges. Ultimate infringement/liability not decided in this opinion.

defenses.defense: Disputed claim terms (including “digital label,” “stored websites,” and “Host Website’s computer”) are indefinite and/or should be narrowly construed so that defendants do not infringe.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 112(b) (indefiniteness) and claim construction principles under Markman and Phillips line of cases.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected in relevant part; court found terms had plain and ordinary meaning and were not indefinite.

defenses.defense: “Host Website’s computer” term should not be corrected or should be interpreted inconsistently with other claim language to avoid infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Claim construction and prosecution history principles; limits on judicial correction of claim language.
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court adopted a corrected, contextually consistent interpretation of “Host Website’s computer.”

case_id: 2024-06-25_USCOURTS-ilsd-3_23-cv-03303_Phoenix Insurance Company et al v. Ackercamps.com LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Phoenix Insurance Company et al. v. Ackercamps.com LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Case concerns ESI protocol including documents created by AI applications.

parties.plaintiff_description: Insurance companies bringing civil litigation claims.
parties.defendant_description: Business entities defending against insurance-related claims.

claims.claim: Request for a court-ordered protocol governing discovery of electronically stored information (ESI) and hard-copy documents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 34 and related discovery rules; parties’ stipulation submitted for court approval.
claims.outcome: Court approved and entered the stipulated ESI and document production protocol as an order, making it binding on all parties.

claims.claim: Establishment of standards for search, processing, and production of ESI, including metadata handling, deduplication, and preservation of parent-child relationships.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules, proportionality and reasonableness requirements under Rules 26 and 34; parties’ negotiated stipulation.
claims.outcome: Court adopted the detailed standards in the stipulated protocol, requiring both sides to follow these technical procedures during discovery.

claims.claim: Creation of procedures for asserting and logging privileged or work-product-protected information within ESI and hard-copy productions.
claims.legal_basis: Attorney–client privilege and work-product doctrine as applied through Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(5) and 26(b)(3).
claims.outcome: Court approved the stipulated procedures for privilege designations and privilege logs, including how to handle inadvertently produced privileged material.

claims.claim: Implementation of confidentiality protections for produced ESI and documents, including treatment of sensitive information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules and any applicable protective-order principles; parties’ agreement on confidentiality terms within the protocol.
claims.outcome: Court incorporated the confidentiality provisions of the stipulated protocol into its order, requiring parties to follow those protections in discovery.

defenses.defense: Agreement to a stipulated ESI and document protocol as a cooperative approach to discovery, avoiding disputes over scope, format, and technical handling.
defenses.legal_basis: Parties’ inherent authority to stipulate to discovery procedures under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, subject to court approval.

case_id: 2022-08-05_USCOURTS-ca13-21-02347_Thaler v. Vidal.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Vidal
ai_relevance: Dispute over whether AI system DABUS can be a patent inventor.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual inventor and owner of AI system DABUS
parties.defendant_description: Federal government official heading U.S. Patent and Trademark Office

claims.claim: The USPTO unlawfully rejected patent applications listing AI system DABUS as the sole inventor.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Patent Act provisions governing inventorship and patent application requirements; challenge to PTO’s interpretation of “inventor” as limited to natural persons.
claims.outcome: Rejected. Court held the Patent Act unambiguously requires inventors to be human beings, so PTO properly denied applications naming DABUS.

claims.claim: An artificial intelligence system such as DABUS qualifies as an “inventor” under the Patent Act’s use of the term “individual.”
claims.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of 35 U.S.C. §§ 100(f), 100(g), 101, 115, and related provisions using the term “inventor” and “individual.”
claims.outcome: Rejected. Court held “individual” in the Patent Act means a natural person, not an AI system.

defenses.defense: Under the Patent Act, only natural persons can be inventors, so applications naming DABUS were properly refused.
defenses.legal_basis: Text and structure of 35 U.S.C. §§ 100(f), 100(g), 101, 115, and related provisions; ordinary meaning of “individual” as human being.

defenses.defense: The PTO must follow the existing statutory scheme and cannot recognize non-human entities as inventors absent congressional change.
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative adherence to statute; separation of powers principles limiting agency authority to alter clear statutory definitions.

case_id: 2024-07-25_USCOURTS-kyed-3_23-cv-00053_Woods v. Morris Mohawk Gaming Group et al.pdf

ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 4(f)(3) (service on individuals in a foreign country by court-directed means) and due process requirements for notice
claims.outcome: Denied; court held plaintiff had not shown sufficient efforts with traditional or internationally compliant service methods and proposed email service did not satisfy due process

defenses.defense: Challenge to adequacy and legality of service via email on foreign defendants
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 4(f), international service protocols (e.g., Hague Convention), and constitutional due process notice requirements

case_id: 2019-12-16_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-11438_Nuance Communications Inc. v. Omilia Natural Language Solutions_ Ltd..pdf
case_name: Nuance Communications Inc. v. Omilia Natural Language Solutions, Ltd.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-based speech recognition and conversational virtual agent technologies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation providing speech and AI solutions
parties.defendant_description: Foreign corporation offering conversational AI platforms

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Omilia’s Conversational Virtual Agent and related AI platforms used in automated speech recognition and interactive voice response systems.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this decision; case allowed to proceed because the court found personal jurisdiction over Omilia and denied its motion to dismiss.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in Massachusetts federal court.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on specific personal jurisdiction under the U.S. Constitution and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2).

defenses.defense: Improper service of process.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(5) and service requirements for foreign corporations.

case_id: 2024-06-17_USCOURTS-cand-5_22-cv-03699_Forrest v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Forrest v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Meta’s automated, AI-powered ad tools allegedly helped create and target scam ads misusing plaintiff’s likeness.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual Australian businessman and public figure
parties.defendant_description: Social media and online advertising corporation

claims.claim: Negligence in operating and monitoring Facebook advertising platform and tools that enabled scam ads using plaintiff’s likeness
claims.legal_basis: Common law negligence under applicable state law
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of likeness based on unauthorized use of plaintiff’s name and image in scam cryptocurrency ads
claims.legal_basis: State-law right of publicity / misappropriation of likeness
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Negligent failure to warn users and the public about fraudulent ads using plaintiff’s likeness
claims.legal_basis: Common law negligence duty-to-warn theory
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; claim dismissed (leave to amend not specified as granted).

claims.claim: Unjust enrichment arising from Meta’s alleged benefit from hosting and promoting scam ads
claims.legal_basis: Equitable claim of unjust enrichment under state law
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; unjust enrichment claim dismissed.

claims.claim: Declaratory judgment regarding Meta’s liability and obligations concerning scam ads using plaintiff’s likeness
claims.legal_basis: Declaratory Judgment Act and related state declaratory relief principles
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; declaratory judgment claim dismissed without leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Immunity under Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act for user-generated advertising content
defenses.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 230(c)(1) and related case law

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6)

defenses.defense: Meta is not an information content provider of the scam ads and thus cannot be liable for their content
defenses.legal_basis: Communications Decency Act § 230 definitions and precedent distinguishing platforms from content providers

defenses.defense: No cognizable duty to warn users about third-party fraudulent advertisements
defenses.legal_basis: Common law negligence principles limiting duty to warn

defenses.defense: Equitable unjust enrichment unavailable where legal remedies or other causes of action govern the dispute
defenses.legal_basis: State law limits on unjust enrichment as an independent cause of action

case_id: 2025-11-11_USCOURTS-cand-3_25-mc-80299_In Re Application of X AI LLC for Subpoena to OpenAI_ Inc._ OpenAI Global_ LLC and OpenAI Opco_ LLC.pdf
case_name: In re Application of X.AI LLC for Subpoena to OpenAI, Inc., OpenAI Global, LLC, and OpenAI OpCo, LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation and transfer of proprietary AI code and confidential AI-related information between competing AI companies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology company and employer of Fraiture
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence research and product companies subpoena recipients

claims.claim: Application for discovery from OpenAI entities for use in UK litigation against former employee Jimmy Fraiture, alleging misappropriation of confidential and proprietary AI code and information.
claims.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1782 (assistance to foreign and international tribunals)
claims.outcome: Denied. Court exercised discretion under § 1782 and found the Intel factors and related considerations weighed against granting discovery, including OpenAI’s likely participation in UK proceedings, the early and undeveloped stage of the UK case, concerns about circumvention of UK and US discovery rules, and the undue breadth and burden of the requested discovery.

defenses.defense: Discovery should be denied because OpenAI is or will be a participant in the UK proceeding, making § 1782 assistance less necessary.
defenses.legal_basis: Discretionary Intel factor analysis under 28 U.S.C. § 1782 (participation of target in foreign proceeding).

defenses.defense: The UK litigation is at a premature and undeveloped stage, so the requested discovery is not yet appropriate or necessary.
defenses.legal_basis: Intel factors and comity considerations under 28 U.S.C. § 1782 regarding timing and posture of foreign proceeding.

defenses.defense: Granting the application would risk circumventing UK and US discovery rules and procedures.
defenses.legal_basis: Intel factor concerning attempts to circumvent foreign proof-gathering restrictions or other policies; discretionary limits under 28 U.S.C. § 1782.

defenses.defense: The requested discovery is overly broad and unduly burdensome for OpenAI.
defenses.legal_basis: Intel factor addressing whether the requests are unduly intrusive or burdensome; general proportionality and burden principles applied in § 1782 context.

case_id: 2016-07-06_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misappropriation of AI technology trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology startup company
parties.defendant_description: Multiple individual and corporate defendants

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s artificial intelligence technology and associated information.
claims.legal_basis: California Uniform Trade Secrets Act (CUTSA) and related California trade secret law; subject to Cal. Civ. Proc. Code § 2019.210 disclosure requirements.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; court found Loop AI’s trade secret disclosure insufficient under § 2019.210 and granted defendants’ motion to enforce prior order requiring more detailed, particularized trade secret identification. Consideration of sanctions deferred to trial judge.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to identify alleged trade secrets with reasonable particularity.
defenses.legal_basis: California Code of Civil Procedure § 2019.210 requiring pre-discovery identification of trade secrets with reasonable particularity.

defenses.defense: Inability to prepare a defense or conduct discovery without adequate trade secret disclosure.
defenses.legal_basis: Due process principles and procedural fairness in trade secret litigation under California law, enforced through § 2019.210 and the court’s prior disclosure order.

case_id: 2015-09-02_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves startup developing AI technology and related business interference.

parties.plaintiff_description: Artificial intelligence technology startup company
parties.defendant_description: Corporation alleging contractual interference counterclaim

claims.claim: Intentional interference with contractual relations (counterclaim by IQ System, Inc. against Loop AI)
claims.legal_basis: California common law tort of intentional interference with contractual relations; challenged under California anti-SLAPP statute (Cal. Code Civ. Proc. § 425.16) and limited by California litigation privilege (Cal. Civ. Code § 47(b)).
claims.outcome: Counterclaim was stricken in full under California’s anti-SLAPP statute because it arose from Loop AI’s protected petitioning/litigation activity and IQ System failed to show a probability of prevailing due to the absolute bar of the litigation privilege.

defenses.defense: Anti-SLAPP protection for petitioning activity
defenses.legal_basis: California anti-SLAPP statute (Cal. Code Civ. Proc. § 425.16) arguing that IQ System’s intentional interference counterclaim arose from Loop AI’s protected activity of filing and prosecuting the lawsuit and related litigation communications.

defenses.defense: Litigation privilege bars liability for litigation communications
defenses.legal_basis: California litigation privilege (Cal. Civ. Code § 47(b)) asserting that Loop AI’s statements and communications made in connection with the judicial proceeding cannot form the basis of IQ System’s intentional interference with contractual relations claim.

case_id: 2025-04-18_USCOURTS-cand-3_23-cv-03698_X Corp. v. Bright Data Ltd..pdf
case_name: X Corp., Inc. v. Bright Data Ltd.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Social media platform owner and operator that aims to create a generative AI chatbot that can answer all questions
parties.defendant_description: Data-scraping and data services company

claims.claim: Breach of contract and related claims based on Bright Data’s scraping of data from X’s platform in violation of X’s Terms of Service and other platform rules.
claims.legal_basis: Contract law and associated state-law causes of action (exact statutes not specified in summary).
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; court addressed only Bright Data’s counterclaims on X Corp.’s motion to dismiss.

claims.claim: Unreasonable restraint of trade by X Corp. through new Terms of Service and practices that restrict data scraping and penalize entities like Bright Data, thereby limiting competition in the market for publicly available social media data.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 1 (unreasonable restraints of trade).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held Bright Data plausibly alleged an unreasonable restraint of trade.

claims.claim: Monopolization and/or attempted monopolization by X Corp. in the market for access to and use of publicly available data from its platform, through restrictive Terms of Service and enforcement practices.
claims.legal_basis: Sherman Act § 2 (monopolization / attempted monopolization).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held Bright Data plausibly alleged monopolization-related claims.

claims.claim: Related state antitrust and unfair competition claims challenging X Corp.’s restrictive data-access and scraping rules as anticompetitive.
claims.legal_basis: State antitrust and unfair competition laws (specific statutes not detailed in summary).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court allowed these related state-law counterclaims to proceed.

claims.claim: Fraudulent competition claim alleging that X Corp.’s conduct and Terms of Service were fraudulent or deceptive under California’s unfair competition statute.
claims.legal_basis: California Business & Professions Code § 17200 (fraudulent prong).
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found Bright Data failed to plausibly allege fraudulent competition under § 17200.

defenses.defense: Bright Data’s antitrust and related state-law counterclaims fail to state a claim because X Corp.’s Terms of Service and scraping restrictions are lawful exercises of its rights over its platform and do not unreasonably restrain trade or constitute monopolization.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); substantive antitrust standards under Sherman Act §§ 1 and 2.

defenses.defense: Bright Data’s fraudulent competition claim under California’s Section 17200 is inadequately pleaded and does not allege sufficient facts showing deception or fraud on consumers or competitors.
defenses.legal_basis: California Business & Professions Code § 17200 (fraudulent prong) and Rule 9(b)/12(b)(6) pleading standards.

case_id: 2025-08-12_USCOURTS-txwd-1_25-cv-00855_De Los Santos v. Mattress By Appointment LLC.pdf
case_name: De Los Santos v. Mattress By Appointment LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute involves promotion of unauthorized AI tools to other dealers.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual mattress dealer under MBA agreement
parties.defendant_description: Mattress retail franchisor / dealer network business

claims.claim: Request for declaratory judgment that the court, not an arbitrator, should decide jurisdictional and arbitrability issues under the dealer agreement.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Declaratory Judgment Act and contract interpretation principles regarding arbitration clauses and jurisdiction.
claims.outcome: Denied; the court held the arbitration agreement, including the delegation clause, is valid and enforceable, so arbitrability must be decided by the arbitrator.

claims.claim: Allegation by Mattress By Appointment LLC that Santos breached the dealer agreement by attempting to promote unauthorized artificial intelligence tools to other MBA dealers.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing breach of contract and compliance with contractual restrictions on marketing and use of third‑party tools.
claims.outcome: Substantive breach claim not decided on the merits; the court recommended compelling arbitration so that an arbitrator will resolve this alleged breach.

claims.claim: Allegation by Mattress By Appointment LLC that Santos breached the dealer agreement by failing to comply with required mattress purchase obligations.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing performance of purchase requirements in commercial dealer agreements.
claims.outcome: Substantive breach claim not decided on the merits; the court recommended compelling arbitration so that an arbitrator will resolve this alleged breach.

claims.claim: Motion by Mattress By Appointment LLC to compel arbitration of all disputes arising from the dealer agreement, including arbitrability questions.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and the arbitration clause with a delegation provision in the dealer agreement.
claims.outcome: Granted; the court found a valid arbitration agreement and clear delegation clause and recommended that all disputes, including arbitrability, be submitted to arbitration and that the case be stayed pending arbitration.

defenses.defense: Challenge to the enforceability and scope of the arbitration agreement, arguing that the court should decide arbitrability and that the clause should not bar judicial resolution of the dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act principles on contract formation, unconscionability, and the presumption that courts decide arbitrability absent a clear and unmistakable delegation.

defenses.defense: Jurisdictional objection seeking a declaratory ruling that the court retains authority over the dispute despite the arbitration clause.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal subject‑matter and personal jurisdiction doctrines, and interpretation of the dealer agreement’s jurisdiction and arbitration provisions.

case_id: 2021-05-03_USCOURTS-ohsd-1_21-cv-00131_Concentrix CVG Corporation et al v. Daoust et al.pdf
case_name: Concentrix CVG Corporation et al. v. Stephan J. Daoust et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing customer management and related services
parties.defendant_description: Former employee and competitor company

claims.claim: Breach of non-compete agreement by Daoust through employment with competitor TaskUs
claims.legal_basis: Contract law; enforcement of restrictive covenant/non-compete under applicable state law
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction; found Concentrix failed to show strong likelihood of success on the non-compete claim at this stage

claims.claim: Misappropriation or threatened misappropriation of Concentrix trade secrets by Daoust in his role at TaskUs
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law under state trade secret statute and/or Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA)
claims.outcome: Court denied preliminary injunction; held Concentrix had not shown a strong likelihood of success or sufficient evidence of actual or threatened misappropriation at this stage

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunctive relief to bar Daoust from working for TaskUs and to enforce restrictive covenants
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy standards for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of harms, public interest)
claims.outcome: Preliminary injunction denied; court found no strong likelihood of success on the merits and insufficient evidence of irreparable harm

defenses.defense: Concentrix cannot show likelihood of success on its non-compete claim
defenses.legal_basis: Non-compete is unenforceable or not breached under applicable contract and employment law standards

defenses.defense: No actual or threatened misappropriation of trade secrets by Daoust
defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requires proof of misappropriation or real threat; mere knowledge from prior employment is insufficient

defenses.defense: Concentrix cannot demonstrate irreparable harm from Daoust’s employment at TaskUs
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable principles governing preliminary injunctions require clear evidence of irreparable harm, which was not shown

defenses.defense: Balance of harms and public interest do not favor injunctive relief
defenses.legal_basis: Preliminary injunction standard weighing hardship to employee and competition against employer’s asserted interests

case_id: 2017-12-01_USCOURTS-txed-2_16-cv-00980_Intellectual Ventures II LLC v. FedEx Corporation et al.pdf
case_name: Intellectual Ventures II LLC v. FedEx Corporation et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding intellectual property company
parties.defendant_description: Package delivery and logistics corporations

claims.claim: Defendants infringed five asserted patents owned by Intellectual Ventures II LLC.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 and related provisions.
claims.outcome: No merits ruling yet; court only granted plaintiff extra time to respond to defendants’ Rule 12(c) motions.

defenses.defense: The five asserted patents are invalid because they claim ineligible subject matter.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; raised via Rule 12(c) motions for judgment on the pleadings.
defenses.defense_outcome: No decision on validity yet; court deferred ruling and considered possible conversion of the motions to summary judgment after further briefing.

defenses.defense: Rule 12(c) judgment on the pleadings should dispose of the infringement claims based on patent ineligibility.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(c).
defenses.defense_outcome: Not decided on the merits; court instead granted plaintiff an extension to respond and deferred decision on whether to convert to summary judgment.

case_id: 2025-06-25_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-01451_In Re Mosaic LLM Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Mosaic LLM Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute over training large language models on copyrighted works.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors alleging copyright infringement by AI training use.
parties.defendant_description: Technology companies developing and deploying large language models.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on training Mosaic ML’s LLMs, including Databricks’ DBRX models, on datasets that allegedly contain plaintiffs’ copyrighted works without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act – direct infringement of exclusive rights in copyrighted works (e.g., 17 U.S.C. §§ 106, 501).
claims.outcome: Court granted plaintiffs leave to amend to add a direct infringement claim against Databricks regarding its new DBRX LLMs; merits of the infringement claim not yet decided.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement as to an expanded and updated list of allegedly infringed works used in training the defendants’ LLMs.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. Copyright Act – infringement of additional registered or protectable works (17 U.S.C. §§ 106, 501).
claims.outcome: Court granted plaintiffs leave to amend to update and expand the list of allegedly infringed works; no ruling yet on liability for those works.

defenses.defense: Opposition to amendment based on undue delay in seeking to add new direct infringement allegations and additional works.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a) – arguing that leave to amend should be denied due to undue delay and potential prejudice.

case_id: 2016-03-10_USCOURTS-cand-4_15-cv-00798_Loop AI Labs_ Inc. v. Gatti et al.pdf
case_name: Loop AI Labs Inc. v. Gatti et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged misappropriation of Loop AI’s artificial intelligence technology and related trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology company developing artificial intelligence systems
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants accused of misusing AI trade secrets

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to Loop AI’s artificial intelligence technology and associated competitive business information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trade secret law (e.g., DTSA/UTSA equivalents) as pled in the underlying complaint.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; in this discovery order the court allows Almawave to question Loop’s Rule 30(b)(6) witness on most trade-secret-related topics, denying a protective order as to many of them but limiting some topics as overbroad or irrelevant.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and related business torts arising from alleged misuse of Loop AI’s confidential and proprietary AI technology and information.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition and business tort statutes and common law, as alleged in the complaint.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; court’s ruling only addresses scope of deposition topics, permitting most questioning related to these allegations while restricting some irrelevant or overly broad areas.

claims.claim: Breach of confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations concerning Loop AI’s proprietary technology and business information.
claims.legal_basis: Contract and/or common-law duties of confidentiality as asserted in the complaint.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; court allows discovery into alleged breaches via Rule 30(b)(6) topics, subject to limits protecting privileged and clearly irrelevant information.

defenses.defense: Deposition topics are proper, relevant, and necessary to test Loop AI’s trade secret and other allegations.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26 and 30(b)(6) permitting broad, relevant discovery.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted in part; court finds most topics reasonable and denies protective order as to those, allowing questioning.

defenses.defense: Topics do not improperly seek privileged information because they are framed to obtain facts, not attorney-client communications or work product.
defenses.legal_basis: Discovery rules distinguishing discoverable facts from protected privileged communications and work product.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted in part; court allows questioning on many topics while recognizing and preserving privilege where clearly implicated.

defenses.defense: Requested protective order by Loop AI is overbroad and would unduly restrict Almawave’s ability to obtain discovery on core issues like trade secret misappropriation and unfair competition.
defenses.legal_basis: FRCP 26(c) standard requiring good cause for protective orders and balancing burden versus need for discovery.
defenses.defense_outcome: Accepted in part; court denies portions of Loop AI’s motion and refuses to narrow many topics, but still trims some as overbroad or irrelevant.

case_id: 2023-09-05_USCOURTS-txnd-3_22-cv-01699_Synergy Advisory Services LLC v. ClearPrism LLC.pdf
case_name: Synergy Advisory Services, LLC v. ClearPrism, LLC
ai_relevance: Consulting dispute over marketing and sales of AI-based software products.

parties.plaintiff_description: Business entity providing consulting and advisory services
parties.defendant_description: Business entity marketing AI-based software solutions

claims.claim: Breach of Settlement Agreement for failure to make required payments resolving prior consulting-fee dispute.
claims.legal_basis: Breach of contract under the Settlement Agreement governing payment obligations.
claims.outcome: Court granted Synergy’s motion for partial summary judgment; ClearPrism found in breach and ordered to pay $141,250 in damages.

claims.claim: Right to recover unpaid amounts due under the Settlement Agreement, including remaining installment payments.
claims.legal_basis: Contractual right to payment and enforcement of settlement terms under state contract law.
claims.outcome: Court held Synergy is entitled to recover the unpaid balance of $141,250 from ClearPrism.

defenses.defense: ClearPrism did not breach the Settlement Agreement or did not owe the full claimed amount.
defenses.legal_basis: General denial of breach and/or amount of damages under contract law.

defenses.defense: Synergy was not entitled to summary judgment because material facts were allegedly in dispute.
defenses.legal_basis: Procedural defense under summary judgment standards requiring genuine dispute of material fact.

case_id: 2018-10-11_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-01959_Usens_ Inc. v. Chi.pdf
case_name: uSens, Inc. v. Shi Chi
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-based computer-vision tracking tech for AR/VR products and related trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation developing AI-based AR/VR tracking technologies.
parties.defendant_description: Individual former consultant to AI tech company.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction barring defendant from using or disclosing uSens’ confidential information and alleged trade secrets related to AI-based computer-vision tracking technologies.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret misappropriation and breach of confidentiality obligations under applicable trade secret and contract law; equitable standard for preliminary injunction (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, public interest).
claims.outcome: Denied. Court held uSens failed to clearly identify specific trade secrets, failed to show the information met the statutory definition of trade secrets, and failed to establish that uSens—not non-party Hangzhou Linggan—owned the alleged trade secrets.

claims.claim: Request for order compelling defendant to return a Dell laptop and cell phone allegedly containing uSens’ confidential information and trade secrets.
claims.legal_basis: Property and trade secret rights, and contractual/confidentiality obligations; equitable relief ancillary to trade secret and confidentiality claims.
claims.outcome: Denied as part of the preliminary injunction motion because uSens did not sufficiently prove ownership of the information and devices or establish the existence and ownership of protectable trade secrets justifying such mandatory relief at the preliminary stage.

defenses.defense: uSens failed to identify any specific, legally cognizable trade secrets with sufficient particularity.
