defenses.legal_basis: Trade secret law requires clear identification of alleged trade secrets to obtain injunctive relief; failure undermines likelihood of success on the merits.

defenses.defense: The information at issue did not meet the statutory definition of trade secrets (e.g., not adequately shown to be secret or to derive independent economic value from secrecy).
defenses.legal_basis: Statutory trade secret requirements under applicable trade secret law (e.g., DTSA/California UTSA) for existence of a trade secret.

defenses.defense: uSens did not establish that it, rather than non-party Hangzhou Linggan, owned the alleged confidential information and trade secrets.
defenses.legal_basis: Plaintiff must prove ownership of the trade secrets to obtain injunctive relief; lack of standing/ownership defeats likelihood of success.

defenses.defense: Failure to satisfy the overall standard for a preliminary injunction, including likelihood of success on the merits and entitlement to mandatory relief compelling return of devices.
defenses.legal_basis: Equitable standard for preliminary injunction in federal court (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, and public interest).

case_id: 2023-09-06_USCOURTS-tnwd-2_22-cv-02838_Pritchard v. Thompson et al.pdf
case_name: Pritchard v. Thompson et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI-enabled dashcam patent and alleged misuse of AI technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual inventor and patent holder
parties.defendant_description: Individual employee and technology corporation

claims.claim: Patent infringement relating to AI-enabled dashcam technology
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under Title 35 of the U.S. Code
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as to Aaron Thompson and Harman Connected Services for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue in the Western District of Tennessee

claims.claim: Trade secret misappropriation concerning confidential dashcam and AI design information
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely DTSA and/or state trade secret statutes)
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as to Aaron Thompson and Harman Connected Services for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue in the Western District of Tennessee

claims.claim: Additional related intellectual property and business tort claims arising from alleged misuse of plaintiff’s dashcam invention
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state intellectual property and unfair competition laws
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice as to Aaron Thompson and Harman Connected Services for lack of personal jurisdiction and improper venue in the Western District of Tennessee

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction in the Western District of Tennessee
defenses.legal_basis: Due process limits on personal jurisdiction under the U.S. Constitution and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2)

defenses.defense: Improper venue in the Western District of Tennessee
defenses.legal_basis: Federal venue statutes and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(3)

defenses.defense: Opposition to transfer of the case to Michigan
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) and § 1406(a)

case_id: 2025-05-23_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: Dispute over confidentiality of AI system Claude’s training data, prompts, and usage metrics in discovery.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music rights holders and related corporate entities.
parties.defendant_description: Artificial intelligence company developing Claude AI system.

claims.claim: Request to seal certain discovery materials related to Claude, including usage metrics, specific prompts, and datasets used to train the AI system.
claims.legal_basis: Protective order and Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) “good cause” standard for sealing competitively sensitive and confidential business information in discovery filings.
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; court allowed sealing of competitively sensitive information but refused sealing of prompt descriptions and specific usage numbers that were already public or not sufficiently sensitive.

claims.claim: Assertion that disclosure of detailed usage metrics and training datasets would cause competitive harm to Anthropic by revealing proprietary information about Claude’s operation and development.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and confidential business information protections under Rule 26(c) and related case law applying the “good cause” standard to non-dispositive discovery materials.
claims.outcome: Partially accepted; court found good cause to seal some competitively sensitive materials but rejected sealing for information that was either publicly disclosed or insufficiently sensitive, such as certain prompt descriptions and specific usage figures.

defenses.defense: Opposition to broad sealing on the ground that much of the requested material, including some prompt descriptions and usage numbers, is not truly confidential or has already been publicly disclosed.
defenses.legal_basis: Common law and First Amendment-based presumption of public access to court records, limited by only “good cause” for non-dispositive discovery materials; argument that Anthropic failed to meet that standard for all requested items.

case_id: 2025-02-14_USCOURTS-ord-3_25-cv-00051_Shita v. Taylor.pdf
case_name: Shita v. Taylor
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on alleged misappropriation and ownership of AGI technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Self-represented individual alleging AGI trade secret theft
parties.defendant_description: Individual, former business associate over AGI technology

claims.claim: Trade secret misappropriation relating to AGI technology
claims.legal_basis: State trade secret law (likely Oregon Uniform Trade Secrets Act)
claims.outcome: Dismissed at screening for failure to state a claim; plaintiff granted leave to amend to adequately plead existence and misappropriation of trade secrets.

claims.claim: Conversion of AGI-related property or assets
claims.legal_basis: State common law conversion
claims.outcome: Adequately stated; conversion claim allowed to proceed past initial screening.

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty arising from business/partner relationship
claims.legal_basis: State common law breach of fiduciary duty
claims.outcome: Dismissed at screening for insufficient factual allegations; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with business or economic relations
claims.legal_basis: State common law tortious interference
claims.outcome: Dismissed at screening for failure to plead required elements; leave to amend granted.

claims.claim: Request for temporary restraining order (TRO) to stop defendant’s use or disclosure of AGI technology
claims.legal_basis: Equitable injunctive relief under federal procedural rules (Fed. R. Civ. P. 65) and state substantive rights
claims.outcome: Denied; court found insufficient showing for ex parte/emergency relief and underlying claims not adequately pleaded.

claims.claim: Motion to seal the entire case
claims.legal_basis: Court’s inherent authority and local rules governing sealing; plaintiff’s interest in protecting alleged trade secrets
claims.outcome: Denied; court held plaintiff did not meet standards for sealing the case record.

claims.claim: Application to proceed in forma pauperis (IFP)
claims.outcome: Granted; plaintiff allowed to proceed without paying filing fees, but complaint subjected to screening and partially dismissed with leave to amend.

defenses.defense: Insufficient pleading of trade secret elements and misappropriation
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6); requirements of state trade secret law.

defenses.defense: Failure to adequately allege existence and scope of any fiduciary duty
defenses.legal_basis: State common law elements of fiduciary duty and federal pleading standards.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for tortious interference (missing elements such as improper means or purpose)
defenses.legal_basis: State common law of tortious interference and Rule 12(b)(6) standards.

defenses.defense: No basis for extraordinary relief via TRO or for sealing the case
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for injunctive relief under Fed. R. Civ. P. 65 and constitutional/public access presumption to court records.

case_id: 2025-03-28_USCOURTS-mad-1_24-cv-10446_Overjet_ Inc. v. VideaHealth_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Overjet, Inc. v. VideaHealth, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over competing dental AI systems for analyzing X‑rays and detecting disease.

parties.plaintiff_description: Dental AI technology company and software developer
parties.defendant_description: Competing dental AI software and technology company

claims.claim: Trademark infringement
claims.legal_basis: Federal and/or state trademark law protecting Overjet’s marks and brand identifiers used with its dental AI products
claims.outcome: Not specified in summary; motion to dismiss outcome not clearly described.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement
claims.legal_basis: Copyright law protecting Overjet’s unique combination of design elements and visual outputs in its dental AI X‑ray analysis software
claims.outcome: Court found allegations plausible and denied VideaHealth’s motion to dismiss the copyright claim, allowing it to proceed.

claims.claim: Patent infringement
claims.legal_basis: Patent law protecting Overjet’s proprietary technological methods for AI‑based dental X‑ray scanning and disease detection
claims.outcome: Court found allegations plausible and denied VideaHealth’s motion to dismiss the patent infringement claim, allowing it to proceed.

defenses.defense: Motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6), arguing Overjet’s copyright and patent allegations were insufficiently pled or not legally cognizable.

case_id: 2022-03-11_USCOURTS-azd-2_21-cv-00093_Yammine v. Toolbox for HR Spolka z Ograniczona Odpowiedzialnoscia Spolka Komandytowa.pdf
case_name: Yammine v. Toolbox for HR Spolka z Ograniczona Odpowiedzialnoscia Spolka Komandytowa
ai_relevance: Dispute involves recruitment software using AI to identify job‑changing tech professionals.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual software professional and domain registrant
parties.defendant_description: Polish software company offering AI recruitment tools

claims.claim: Trademark infringement related to the 'CV Timeline' name and associated marks
claims.legal_basis: Trademark law (likely Lanham Act and/or analogous protections)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held counterclaim stated a plausible claim and allowed it to proceed.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets connected to TB4HR’s recruitment software and related confidential information
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely state trade secrets statute or DTSA)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court found sufficient allegations of trade secret status and misuse, allowing the claim to proceed.

claims.claim: Breach of fiduciary duty by Yammine in connection with his relationship with TB4HR and use of company-related assets, including the CV Timeline domain
claims.legal_basis: State common law of fiduciary duty
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; court held TB4HR adequately alleged existence and breach of fiduciary duties.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with business expectancies arising from Yammine’s conduct regarding the CV Timeline domain and related business opportunities
claims.legal_basis: State common law of tortious interference with business expectancy or prospective economic advantage
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court found TB4HR failed to allege specific, concrete business expectancies or lost deals, so the claim was insufficiently pled.

claims.claim: Personal jurisdiction challenge by Yammine to TB4HR’s counterclaims in Arizona federal court
claims.legal_basis: Constitutional due process limits on personal jurisdiction; Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 12(b)(2)
claims.outcome: Court held it had personal jurisdiction over Yammine for TB4HR’s counterclaims and denied his motion to dismiss for lack of personal jurisdiction.

claims.claim: Request by TB4HR for jurisdictional discovery to further support personal jurisdiction
claims.legal_basis: Discretionary jurisdictional discovery under federal procedural law
claims.outcome: Denied; court concluded the existing record was sufficient to decide jurisdiction without additional discovery.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Yammine for TB4HR’s counterclaims in Arizona
defenses.legal_basis: Due process clause and minimum contacts doctrine; Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(2)
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found sufficient contacts and exercised personal jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for trademark infringement
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); insufficiency of allegations under trademark law
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court held TB4HR plausibly alleged ownership/use and likelihood of confusion.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for misappropriation of trade secrets
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); inadequate pleading of trade secret elements
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found TB4HR sufficiently alleged protectable trade secrets and misappropriation.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for breach of fiduciary duty
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); challenge to existence and breach of fiduciary relationship
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court held allegations of fiduciary relationship and breach were adequate at the pleading stage.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim for tortious interference with business expectancies
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); requirement to plead specific business expectancies and resulting damages
defenses.outcome: Accepted; court dismissed the tortious interference counterclaim for lack of specific alleged business expectancies.

case_id: 2022-03-14_USCOURTS-azd-2_21-cv-00093_Yammine v. Toolbox for HR Spolka z Ograniczona Odpowiedzialnoscia Spolka Komandytowa.pdf
case_name: Yammine v. Toolbox for HR Spolka z Ograniczona Odpowiedzialnoscia Spolka Komandytowa
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual software/business collaborator
parties.defendant_name: Toolbox for HR Spolka z Ograniczona Odpowiedzialnoscia Spolka Komandytowa
parties.defendant_description: Business entity marketing CV Timeline product

claims.claim: Declaratory and related claims by Yammine regarding ownership/control of the CV Timeline domain name
claims.legal_basis: Domain name and intellectual property-related rights under applicable law (exact statutes not specified in summary)
claims.outcome: Not resolved on this motion; court focused on counterclaims and jurisdiction, case proceeds.

claims.claim: Cyberpiracy / cybersquatting against Yammine
claims.legal_basis: Anti-cybersquatting / cyberpiracy law (likely ACPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1125(d))
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim denied; claim survives.

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets against Yammine
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret law (likely federal DTSA and/or state trade secrets statute)
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim denied; claim survives.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with contract against Yammine
claims.legal_basis: State tort law for interference with existing contractual relations
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim denied; claim survives.

claims.claim: Tortious interference with prospective economic advantage against Yammine
claims.legal_basis: State tort law for interference with prospective business expectancy
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim because TB4HR did not sufficiently allege a specific, identifiable business expectancy.

claims.claim: Other related counterclaims tied to ownership and control of the CV Timeline domain and competing venture
claims.legal_basis: State and/or federal unfair competition and contract/tort principles (not fully specified in summary)
claims.outcome: To the extent included in the motion, the court denied dismissal; these counterclaims proceed.

defenses.defense: Lack of personal jurisdiction over Yammine for TB4HR’s counterclaims
defenses.legal_basis: Due process and personal jurisdiction limits under the U.S. Constitution and Federal Rules of Civil Procedure
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court held that by filing suit in the District of Arizona, Yammine submitted to personal jurisdiction for compulsory counterclaims.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim as to TB4HR’s cyberpiracy counterclaim
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) pleading standards (Twombly/Iqbal)
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found TB4HR adequately stated a cyberpiracy claim.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim as to TB4HR’s misappropriation of trade secrets counterclaim
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and applicable trade secret pleading standards
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found TB4HR adequately stated a trade secrets claim.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim as to TB4HR’s tortious interference with contract counterclaim
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and state tort pleading standards
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court found TB4HR adequately stated a tortious interference with contract claim.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim as to TB4HR’s tortious interference with prospective economic advantage counterclaim
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and state law requirement to plead a specific business expectancy
defenses.outcome: Accepted; court dismissed this counterclaim for insufficient allegations of a concrete business expectancy.

case_id: 2020-08-12_USCOURTS-mnd-0_20-cv-01558_Appdiff_ Inc. v. Bonine et al.pdf
case_name: Appdiff, Inc. v. Bonine et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over ownership and use of AI-company (PinkLion) accounts and information after acquisition by AI-focused tech firm Appdiff.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation in artificial intelligence industry
parties.defendant_description: Former employees/affiliates of acquired AI company

claims.claim: Breach of contract by former employees regarding post-employment obligations and account/control rights
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing employment, acquisition, and related agreements
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling at this stage; request for TRO/preliminary injunction based on this claim was denied for lack of irreparable harm, but case proceeds with expedited discovery.

claims.claim: Deceptive or unfair trade practices by misrepresenting affiliation with Appdiff and/or PinkLion
claims.legal_basis: State deceptive trade practices / unfair competition statutes
claims.outcome: No final merits ruling; injunctive relief (TRO/preliminary injunction) premised on this theory was denied due to insufficient showing of irreparable harm, while underlying claim remains pending.

claims.claim: Misuse or threatened misuse of company information and disputed accounts following acquisition of PinkLion
claims.legal_basis: Contractual rights from acquisition agreements and related state business tort principles
claims.outcome: Court declined to issue TRO/preliminary injunction for failure to show irreparable harm, but ordered expedited discovery to resolve ownership and access to disputed accounts.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to show irreparable harm necessary for TRO/preliminary injunction
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard under Rule 65 and equitable principles

defenses.defense: Disputed ownership and control of accounts and information, not clearly belonging to plaintiff
defenses.legal_basis: Contract interpretation and property/contract law regarding acquisition and account ownership

case_id: 2025-07-01_USCOURTS-mnd-0_25-cv-00213_Fiorito v. Metropolitan Council et al.pdf
case_name: Fiorito v. Metropolitan Council et al.
ai_relevance: Protective order restricts use of generative AI (e.g., ChatGPT) with confidential discovery material to prevent data leakage or misuse.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual litigant in civil discovery dispute
parties.defendant_description: Regional governmental body and related defendants

claims.claim: Request for a protective order governing the handling and exchange of confidential information during discovery, including limits on disclosure and data security requirements.
claims.legal_basis: Federal civil procedure rules governing discovery and protective orders (e.g., Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(c)) to prevent annoyance, embarrassment, oppression, or undue burden or expense.
claims.outcome: Granted. Court entered a protective order setting detailed confidentiality, access, and security rules, including prohibiting use of generative AI platforms with confidential material.

defenses.defense: Need for confidentiality protections over sensitive information produced in discovery, including personal, proprietary, or security-sensitive data.
defenses.legal_basis: Good cause standard for protective orders under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(c) and general privacy and security interests in discovery.

case_id: 2019-03-08_USCOURTS-mnd-0_18-mc-00094_Neo Ivy Capital Management LLC et al v. Savvysherpa LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Neo Ivy Capital Management LLC et al. v. Savvysherpa LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves subpoenas for AI/ML R&D documents allegedly tied to trade secrets.

parties.plaintiff_description: Investment/technology business pursuing arbitration discovery
parties.defendant_name: Savvysherpa LLC and United Healthcare Service
parties.defendant_description: Non-party corporations subpoenaed for documents

claims.claim: Enforcement of subpoenas to obtain documents from Savvysherpa LLC for use in AAA arbitration against former employee Yinglong Guo regarding alleged breach of non-compete and misappropriation of trade secrets.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45; relevance to underlying arbitration claims for breach of contract and trade secret misappropriation.
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; court ordered production of some categories of documents that were relevant and not unduly burdensome, but refused to compel broader or more intrusive requests.

claims.claim: Enforcement of subpoenas to obtain documents from United Healthcare Service related to Guo’s employment and potentially relevant information for the AAA arbitration.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45; discovery in aid of arbitration to obtain third-party documents relevant to claims against Guo.
claims.outcome: Granted in part and denied in part; court limited enforcement to narrower, clearly relevant materials and denied expansive requests imposing undue burden or implicating confidential information.

claims.claim: Request for documents concerning Savvysherpa’s and related entities’ research and development in artificial intelligence and machine learning to show alleged use or benefit from Neo Ivy’s purported trade secrets.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45; relevance to trade secret misappropriation theories in the underlying arbitration.
claims.outcome: Denied; court found the AI/ML R&D requests insufficiently tied to the arbitration issues, overly broad, unduly burdensome, and raising serious confidentiality concerns.

defenses.defense: Subpoena requests are overbroad, not sufficiently relevant to the underlying arbitration, and seek information beyond what is reasonably necessary.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45(d)(3)(A); court must quash or modify subpoenas that require disclosure of irrelevant or excessive information.

defenses.defense: Compliance with the subpoenas would impose an undue burden on non-party entities Savvysherpa and United Healthcare Service.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45(d)(1)–(3); protection of non-parties from undue burden or expense in responding to subpoenas.

defenses.defense: Requested materials include highly confidential and proprietary business information, including sensitive AI/ML research and development, that should not be disclosed.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 45(d)(3)(B); protection of trade secrets and confidential commercial information from compelled disclosure.

case_id: 2025-09-11_USCOURTS-cand-5_23-cv-03440_In re Google Generative AI Copyright Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Google Generative AI Copyright Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute over training generative AI models on copyrighted works without consent.

parties.plaintiff_description: Creators alleging unauthorized use of copyrighted works for AI training
parties.defendant_description: Technology companies operating and overseeing generative AI models

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement for using plaintiffs’ copyrighted works to train specific Google generative AI models without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.)—unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works in training datasets.
claims.outcome: Partially allowed to proceed as to certain specifically alleged AI models; dismissed without prejudice as to other models lacking detailed factual allegations.

claims.claim: Vicarious copyright infringement against Alphabet for Google’s alleged infringing use of plaintiffs’ works in AI training.
claims.legal_basis: Vicarious liability under copyright law—right and ability to supervise infringing activity and direct financial benefit.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held parent-subsidiary relationship alone insufficient to show Alphabet’s control over or direct involvement in the alleged infringement.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement claims related to unspecified or broadly referenced Google generative AI systems without model-specific facts.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (17 U.S.C. §§ 101 et seq.), pled generally across Google’s AI ecosystem.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for lack of sufficiently detailed, model-specific allegations; plaintiffs allowed opportunity to amend if they can plead more specific facts.

defenses.defense: Alphabet is not liable merely because it is Google’s parent company and does not exercise the requisite control over the alleged infringing conduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Corporate law principles limiting parent-company liability; vicarious copyright liability requires specific control and benefit, not just ownership.

defenses.defense: Claims tied to certain AI models are inadequately pled because plaintiffs do not allege concrete facts connecting their works to those specific models or training processes.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Rule 8 and Rule 12(b)(6), requiring plausible, non-conclusory factual allegations for each asserted model.

case_id: 2015-12-03_USCOURTS-gamd-5_15-cv-00115_ABBASI v. BHALODWALA et al.pdf
case_name: ABBASI v. BHALODWALA et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: The individual software developer who created the Lottery Tracking System (LTS).
parties.defendant_description: Competing business and associated individuals

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged copying of the Lottery Tracking System (LTS) software and related materials.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Copyright Act, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; copyright infringement claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: Unfair competition and false designation of origin related to use of similar branding and marketing for competing lottery tracking software.
claims.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a), 15 U.S.C. § 1125(a).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; Lanham Act unfair competition claim allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: State-law unfair competition and deceptive trade practices arising from marketing and sale of allegedly copied software as defendants’ own product.
claims.legal_basis: State unfair competition and deceptive trade practices statutes (specific state laws referenced in complaint).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; state-law unfair competition/deceptive practices claims allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: State-law misappropriation of proprietary software and related confidential information in creating a competing product.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law misappropriation and related business tort doctrines.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; misappropriation-related claims allowed to proceed.

claims.claim: State-law claims for interference with plaintiff’s business relationships and economic advantage through sale and promotion of the allegedly infringing software.
claims.legal_basis: State common-law tortious interference and similar business torts.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied; interference-related claims allowed to proceed.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Insufficient factual allegations of copying and substantial similarity of software.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright infringement pleading standards under federal law.

defenses.defense: Lanham Act and unfair competition allegations are conclusory and do not plausibly show consumer confusion or protectable rights.
defenses.legal_basis: Lanham Act § 43(a) and Rule 8 plausibility standards (Twombly/Iqbal).

defenses.defense: State-law claims preempted or otherwise barred by federal copyright law and fail to allege required elements.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act preemption doctrine and state common-law pleading standards.

case_id: 2021-02-17_USCOURTS-cand-4_19-cv-04060_Lambda Labs_ Inc. v. Lambda_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Lambda Labs, Inc. v. Lambda, Inc.
ai_relevance: Trademark discovery dispute about AI and machine learning products and services.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering AI and machine learning products/services.
parties.defendant_description: Corporation operating education services, including coding and AI.

claims.claim: Motion to compel more complete interrogatory responses about products, services, trademarks, and trade/customer information.
claims.legal_basis: Federal discovery rules requiring complete, non-evasive interrogatory responses (Fed. R. Civ. P. 26, 33, 37) in trademark infringement litigation.
claims.outcome: Granted; court ordered Lambda Labs to amend and provide more detailed and complete interrogatory responses, particularly regarding AI and ML offerings and related trademark use.

claims.claim: Request for protective order limiting or restricting deposition questions concerning reputational issues and trademark-related topics.
claims.legal_basis: Protective order standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(c) to prevent annoyance, embarrassment, oppression, or undue burden or expense.
claims.outcome: Denied; court held the deposition questions were relevant to the trademark dispute, including potential confusion and reputational issues, and refused to limit that questioning.

defenses.defense: Existing interrogatory responses were sufficiently detailed and complete, especially regarding AI/ML products and services and related trademarks.
defenses.legal_basis: Compliance with scope and proportionality requirements of Fed. R. Civ. P. 26 and 33; contention that no further supplementation was required.

defenses.defense: Deposition questions about reputational concerns and trademark issues were overly intrusive or not sufficiently relevant, justifying a protective order.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(c) allowing protective orders to limit discovery that is unduly burdensome, harassing, or not proportional to the needs of the case.

case_id: 2020-07-30_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-12235_Mantha v. Quotewizard.com_ LLC.pdf
case_name: Mantha v. QuoteWizard.com, LLC
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on AI-driven automated texting (Drips LLC) used for messages.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual consumer receiving alleged unlawful texts
parties.defendant_description: Business entity offering insurance quote services

claims.claim: Violation of the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) by sending unauthorized text messages using an Automatic Telephone Dialing System (ATDS).
claims.legal_basis: 47 U.S.C. § 227(b) – TCPA restrictions on calls/texts using an automatic telephone dialing system without prior express consent.
claims.outcome: Initially dismissed for insufficient factual allegations about ATDS use; court later granted leave to amend, and held the amended complaint plausibly states a TCPA claim, allowing it to proceed to discovery.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to adequately allege that the system used to send texts qualified as an Automatic Telephone Dialing System (ATDS).
defenses.legal_basis: TCPA statutory definition of ATDS under 47 U.S.C. § 227(a)(1) and pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6).

defenses.defense: Texts were not sent without the requisite consent, or were otherwise compliant with the TCPA.
defenses.legal_basis: TCPA consent requirements under 47 U.S.C. § 227(b) and related FCC interpretations (implied defense from context).

case_id: 2023-04-05_USCOURTS-ca13-23-01230_Aljindi v. US.pdf
case_name: Aljindi v. United States
ai_relevance: Plaintiff claimed U.S. misused his AI-related scientific contributions and ideas.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual pro se claimant, alleging IP violations
parties.defendant_description: Federal government, alleged user of plaintiff’s ideas

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on alleged government use of his contributions in Artificial Intelligence, Information Security, and Legacy Information Systems.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law; protection of original works of authorship.
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a claim; ideas and principles are not copyrightable, and complaint did not identify any specific protectable expression infringed.

claims.claim: General intellectual property / proprietary ideas misappropriation related to his scientific and technical concepts in AI, Information Security, and Legacy Information Systems.
claims.legal_basis: Implied reliance on intellectual property protections beyond copyright (e.g., concepts akin to trade secret or patent), though not properly pleaded or supported.
claims.outcome: Dismissed; allegations concerned unprotectable abstract ideas and principles, not any legally cognizable IP right within the Court of Federal Claims’ jurisdiction.

defenses.defense: Ideas, concepts, and principles are not protected by copyright; only specific expressions are.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act’s idea–expression dichotomy and established case law that ideas are uncopyrightable.

defenses.defense: Complaint failed to state a claim within the Court of Federal Claims’ jurisdiction or under any money-mandating source of law.
defenses.legal_basis: Rules governing motions to dismiss for failure to state a claim and jurisdictional limits of the Court of Federal Claims.

case_id: 2019-07-30_USCOURTS-mad-1_19-cv-10019_Wired Infomatics_ LLC v. OmniMD.pdf
case_name: Wired Informatics, LLC v. OmniMD Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute centers on performance and representations of Wired’s AI engine “Invenio.”

parties.plaintiff_description: The individual software developer who created the AI-based Invenio engine
parties.defendant_description: Former client, healthcare software and services company

claims.claim: Breach of contract by OmniMD for failing to perform obligations under the software development and licensing agreement related to the Invenio AI engine.
claims.legal_basis: State contract law governing breach of written software and services agreements.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this order; court addressed only OmniMD’s counterclaims and left Wired’s affirmative claims pending.

claims.claim: Fraud by Wired in misrepresenting the capabilities and performance of the Invenio software as an artificial intelligence engine suitable for OmniMD’s intended use.
claims.legal_basis: Common-law fraud requiring particularized pleading under Fed. R. Civ. P. 9(b).
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to plead fraud with sufficient particularity; OmniMD granted leave to amend its counterclaim.

claims.claim: Breach of implied warranties by Wired, including implied warranty of merchantability and implied warranty of fitness for a particular purpose, regarding the Invenio AI software.
claims.legal_basis: State commercial law (e.g., UCC-based implied warranties) as applied to software, subject to contractual warranty disclaimers.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice because OmniMD did not adequately plead around or invalidate the contract’s disclaimer of implied warranties; leave to amend granted.

defenses.defense: OmniMD’s fraud counterclaim is inadequately pleaded and does not satisfy Rule 9(b)’s heightened particularity requirements.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b) and case law requiring specific allegations of misrepresentation, reliance, and damages.

defenses.defense: Contractual disclaimer of implied warranties bars OmniMD’s counterclaims for breach of implied warranties regarding the Invenio software.
defenses.legal_basis: Enforceability of warranty disclaimers under state contract and commercial law, including UCC principles.

defenses.defense: OmniMD’s counterclaims fail to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) standard for dismissal of insufficient pleadings.

case_id: 2015-01-29_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_13-cv-04417_Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC and Daimler AG
ai_relevance: Patent concerns an AI-style expert system to screen operators for impairment.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding company asserting impairment-screening technology
parties.defendant_description: Company specializing in automobiles

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392 related to expert systems for screening equipment operators for impairments and controlling equipment operation.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged unauthorized use of the ’392 patent.
claims.outcome: Rejected; court held all asserted claims of the ’392 patent invalid as patent-ineligible under 35 U.S.C. § 101, so no infringement liability.

defenses.defense: The asserted ’392 patent claims are directed to an abstract idea—screening equipment operators for impairments—and are therefore not patent-eligible.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; Alice/Mayo framework for abstract ideas and patent eligibility.

defenses.defense: The ’392 patent lacks an inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation of operator screening, so it cannot be patented.
defenses.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 101; requirement of an inventive concept to transform an abstract idea into a patent-eligible application.

case_id: 2024-06-05_USCOURTS-jpml-1_24-F-03109_IN RE_ Video Game Addiction Products Liability Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Video Game Addiction Products Liability Litigation
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs allege video games use AI-driven mechanics and algorithms to increase addictiveness and engagement, contributing to alleged addiction harms.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individuals and putative classes alleging video game addiction harms
parties.defendant_description: Video game and technology corporations developing and publishing games

claims.claim: Video game companies designed and deployed games with addictive features that trap minors and young adults in prolonged gameplay, causing or contributing to behavioral addiction and related harms.
claims.legal_basis: Products liability and negligence theories based on defective and unreasonably dangerous design, failure to warn, and breach of duties of reasonable care toward users, especially minors.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits in this order; the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation denied centralization of these claims into an MDL, leaving each underlying action to proceed separately in its respective district.

claims.claim: Defendants incorporated artificial intelligence mechanisms, algorithmic feedback loops, reward systems, and pay-to-win options to manipulate user behavior and maximize engagement, thereby increasing the risk of addiction, particularly among minors and young adults.
claims.legal_basis: Products liability, negligence, and possibly consumer protection and unfair practices claims premised on intentional or reckless use of AI and algorithmic design to create addictive gameplay.
claims.outcome: Not adjudicated on liability or damages; the Panel only addressed whether to centralize these AI-related design claims and denied MDL centralization, so the claims continue individually in their original courts.

claims.claim: The various lawsuits share common factual questions about the addictive design of video games and the conduct of video game and technology companies, warranting centralization as multidistrict litigation for efficiency and consistency.
claims.legal_basis: Motion for transfer and centralization under 28 U.S.C. § 1407, arguing that actions involve common questions of fact and that centralization would promote convenience and efficient resolution.
claims.outcome: Denied; the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation held that the actions do not share sufficient common factual questions and that centralization would not promote convenience or the just and efficient conduct of the litigation due to differing games, defendants, and factual circumstances.

defenses.defense: The actions do not share enough common factual questions to justify MDL centralization because they involve different video games, different sets of defendants, and distinct factual circumstances.
defenses.legal_basis: Opposition to transfer under 28 U.S.C. § 1407, arguing lack of predominating common facts and that centralization would not satisfy statutory requirements for efficiency and convenience.

defenses.defense: Centralization would not promote the convenience of parties and witnesses nor the just and efficient conduct of the litigation, given the diversity of products, companies, and alleged injuries across the cases.
defenses.legal_basis: Section 1407 factors concerning convenience and efficiency, asserting that individualized issues predominate and that informal coordination or case-specific management is preferable to MDL treatment.

case_id: 2025-09-16_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-03811_Concord Music Group_ Inc. et al v. Anthropic PBC.pdf
case_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al. v. Anthropic PBC
ai_relevance: AI model allegedly trained on copyrighted songs without permission, raising novel copyright issues.

parties.plaintiff_name: Concord Music Group, Inc. et al.
parties.plaintiff_description: Music publishers alleging copyright infringement by AI training use.
parties.defendant_description: AI company operating large language model system.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on use of plaintiffs’ musical works to train Anthropic’s AI tool without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act – unauthorized reproduction and use of copyrighted works in training data.
claims.outcome: Ongoing; in this discovery order, court addresses only damages-disclosure obligations, not liability.

claims.claim: Claim for monetary damages for alleged copyright infringement, including actual or statutory damages and related monetary relief.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) governing disclosure of damages computation in copyright action.
claims.outcome: Court declined to exclude or limit damages; ordered plaintiffs to provide more detailed damages computation by close of fact discovery, denying Anthropic’s request for immediate supplementation or exclusion.

defenses.defense: Plaintiffs failed to sufficiently disclose their damages computation and supporting methodology.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(1)(A)(iii) and Rule 37(c)(1) (seeking supplementation or exclusion of undisclosed damages evidence).

case_id: 2022-08-26_USCOURTS-cand-5_19-cv-04286_In re Google Assistant Privacy Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Google Assistant Privacy Litigation
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns services improving Google’s AI-powered Google Assistant system.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of users alleging privacy violations.
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation operating Google Assistant platform.

claims.claim: Non‑party Appen Butler Hill Inc. sought to keep its Statement of Work and related submissions, describing services and pricing provided to Google, from public disclosure in the litigation record.
claims.legal_basis: Protective sealing of confidential business and financial information; “good cause” standard for sealing materials only tangentially related to the merits under Ninth Circuit precedent (e.g., Rule 26(c) and related case law).
claims.outcome: Court granted Appen’s motion to seal; documents containing proprietary and competitively sensitive information were ordered filed under seal.

defenses.defense: Disclosure of Appen’s Statement of Work and pricing would reveal proprietary, non‑public, competitively sensitive information and harm Appen’s competitive standing, while the materials were only tangentially related to the merits of the underlying privacy litigation.
defenses.legal_basis: Good‑cause standard for sealing non‑dispositive or tangential materials; protection of trade secrets and confidential commercial information under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(c) and related Ninth Circuit sealing jurisprudence.

case_id: 2025-11-04_USCOURTS-cand-3_24-cv-01451_In Re Mosaic LLM Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re Mosaic LLM Litigation
ai_relevance: Case concerns discovery about generative AI training, fair use, and licensing.

parties.plaintiff_description: Putative class of copyright holders challenging AI training use
parties.defendant_description: Companies operating or deploying Mosaic-related generative AI models

claims.claim: Defendants infringed plaintiffs’ copyrights by using their works to train generative AI models without authorization or adequate licensing.
claims.legal_basis: U.S. copyright law, including exclusive rights and limitations on fair use; underlying infringement claims inferred from discovery dispute context.
claims.outcome: Not resolved in this discovery order; litigation on merits continues.

claims.claim: Defendants’ use of plaintiffs’ works for AI training is not protected by fair use because it harms or threatens the market for plaintiffs’ works and/or licensing markets.
claims.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 (fair use factors, including market effect).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; court addresses only scope of discovery relevant to fair use and market impact.

claims.claim: Plaintiffs sought to limit the scope of electronic discovery by objecting to defendants’ broad search terms related to third‑party AI tools and AI‑training data licenses as disproportionate and irrelevant.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 26(b)(2)(C) (relevance and proportionality in discovery).
claims.outcome: Court agreed in substantial part; denied defendants’ request to compel use of the broad proposed search terms as overly broad and not sufficiently tied to the issues in the case.

claims.claim: Plaintiffs requested that discovery obligations be confined to reasonable efforts to identify where their works are available online, rather than exhaustive, burdensome searches.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) and 26(g) (reasonable inquiry and proportional discovery).
claims.outcome: Court ordered plaintiffs to supplement discovery responses with a reasonable effort to identify locations where their works are available online, but did not require exhaustive or unduly burdensome searches.

defenses.defense: Defendants asserted a fair use defense, arguing that discovery into plaintiffs’ own use of AI tools and their licensing practices for AI training data is relevant to assessing fair use and market impact.
defenses.legal_basis: 17 U.S.C. § 107 (fair use), particularly factors concerning purpose, nature, and market effect; relevance and proportionality under Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b)(1).

defenses.defense: Defendants argued that broad electronic search terms referencing third‑party AI tools (e.g., ChatGPT) and AI‑training data licenses were necessary to test plaintiffs’ claims of market harm and to explore alternative licensing markets.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Civil Procedure 26(b)(1) (scope of discovery) and 37 (motions to compel).

defenses.defense: Defendants sought an order compelling plaintiffs to run the proposed broad search terms across their electronically stored information to capture documents about AI tools and AI‑related licensing.
defenses.legal_basis: Fed. R. Civ. P. 26(b) and 37 (motion to compel discovery).

case_id: 2006-02-14_USCOURTS-waed-2_05-cv-00380_Next It Corporation v. Roy et al.pdf
case_name: Next IT Corporation v. Joshua Knowles (and others)
ai_relevance: Dispute over proprietary AI application technology and related confidential information.

parties.plaintiff_description: Technology corporation developing AI software applications
parties.defendant_description: Former employee and individual technologist

claims.claim: Misappropriation and threatened misuse of proprietary and trade secret technology information obtained during employment.
claims.legal_basis: Trade secret and proprietary information law; contractual and common-law duties of confidentiality.
claims.outcome: Resolved by stipulated permanent injunction barring disclosure or use of Next IT proprietary information indefinitely.

claims.claim: Unfair competition by potentially using Next IT’s confidential technology to develop or support competing software applications.
claims.legal_basis: Unfair competition and trade secret law; employment and confidentiality agreements.
claims.outcome: Resolved by court-approved injunction prohibiting Knowles for three years from engaging in activities that compete with or involve similar technology to Next IT’s software applications.

claims.claim: Risk of solicitation or poaching of Next IT employees using relationships and knowledge gained while employed.
claims.legal_basis: Employment and non-solicitation principles, likely grounded in contract and fiduciary duties.
claims.outcome: Resolved by injunction prohibiting Knowles for one year from recruiting or attempting to recruit current Next IT employees.

claims.claim: Potential reputational harm through disparaging or defamatory statements between the parties.
claims.legal_basis: Defamation and business disparagement principles, resolved by agreement rather than adjudication.
claims.outcome: Resolved by mutual non-defamation provision in the stipulated injunction, binding both parties.

defenses.defense: Resolution by stipulation without admission of liability or wrongdoing.
defenses.legal_basis: Parties’ settlement authority and Federal Rules permitting stipulated injunctions.

case_id: 2024-09-12_USCOURTS-mied-2_24-cv-11786_Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance.pdf
case_name: Robinson v. Global Semiconductor Alliance
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges patented FOCL tech is used to run AI programs without authorization.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual patent holder alleging unauthorized tech use
parties.defendant_description: Industry association for semiconductor-related companies

claims.claim: Patent infringement and unauthorized use of Fiber-Optic Connected Logic (FOCL) technology to run AI programs.
claims.legal_basis: Implied claim under U.S. patent law for infringement and unauthorized use of patented technology.
claims.outcome: Dismissed without prejudice for failure to state a claim; court found insufficient factual allegations tying GSA or any specific party to infringing conduct.

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a claim because it does not plausibly allege that GSA engaged in any specific infringing act or other actionable misconduct.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal pleading standards under Fed. R. Civ. P. 8 and 12(b)(6) requiring sufficient factual matter to state a plausible claim for relief.

case_id: 2016-03-30_USCOURTS-paed-2_15-cv-05387_DUCKWEED_ USA_ INC. et al v. BEHRENS et al.pdf
case_name: Duckweed USA, Inc. et al. v. Behrens et al.
ai_relevance: Licensed clean‑energy system allegedly required an essential artificial intelligence control component.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation licensing and commercializing clean‑energy technology
parties.defendant_description: Individual patent owner and associated defendants

claims.claim: Patent infringement
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law – infringement of licensed patent by original patentee and others
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to standing; court held Duckweed, as exclusive licensee, has standing to sue for patent infringement even though the alleged infringer is the patent owner.

claims.claim: Civil conspiracy to breach the license agreement
claims.legal_basis: State civil conspiracy law premised on alleged breach of contract
claims.outcome: Dismissed; court held civil conspiracy requires an underlying tort, and a mere breach of contract is insufficient.

defenses.defense: Duckweed lacks standing to sue for patent infringement as a licensee
defenses.legal_basis: Patent standing doctrine requiring patentee or exclusive licensee with substantial rights to bring suit

defenses.defense: Civil conspiracy claim legally insufficient because based only on breach of contract, not an independent tort
defenses.legal_basis: State civil conspiracy law requiring an underlying tortious act beyond contract breach

case_id: 2025-04-03_USCOURTS-jpml-1_24-F-03143_IN RE_ OpenAI_ Inc._ Copyright Infringement Litigation.pdf
case_name: In re OpenAI Inc. Copyright Infringement Litigation
ai_relevance: Centralization of lawsuits alleging copyrighted works used without consent to train large language models like GPT-4.

parties.plaintiff_description: Authors and rightsholders suing over AI training use
parties.defendant_description: AI developer and technology corporation defendants

claims.claim: Direct copyright infringement for using copyrighted works without consent to train LLMs such as GPT-4.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law (exclusive rights in 17 U.S.C. §§ 106 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; actions transferred and centralized in the Southern District of New York for coordinated pretrial proceedings.

claims.claim: Secondary or contributory copyright infringement related to facilitating or benefiting from infringing use of copyrighted materials in AI training and outputs.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law doctrines of contributory and vicarious infringement.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; claims consolidated for coordinated pretrial proceedings in the Southern District of New York.

claims.claim: Related state and federal claims associated with alleged misuse of copyrighted content in AI training (e.g., unfair competition or similar ancillary claims).
claims.legal_basis: Various related state and federal laws asserted alongside copyright claims.
claims.outcome: Not resolved on the merits; included within the group of actions centralized in the Southern District of New York for pretrial management.

claims.claim: Objection to centralization based on alleged differences among plaintiffs’ claims and requested relief.
claims.legal_basis: Arguments under multidistrict litigation standards for transfer and centralization (28 U.S.C. § 1407).
claims.outcome: Rejected; the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation ordered transfer and centralization in the Southern District of New York despite plaintiffs’ objections.

defenses.defense: Centralization is appropriate because actions share common factual questions about how OpenAI’s LLMs were trained on copyrighted materials.
defenses.legal_basis: 28 U.S.C. § 1407 standard for multidistrict litigation—common questions of fact and efficiency in coordinated pretrial proceedings.

defenses.defense: Centralization will prevent duplicative discovery, inconsistent pretrial rulings, and conserve resources of parties and the judiciary.
defenses.legal_basis: Judicial efficiency and convenience considerations under 28 U.S.C. § 1407 for transfer and coordination.

case_id: 2019-11-27_USCOURTS-cand-4_19-cv-04433_Demos v. Google et al.pdf
case_name: Demos v. Google et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges defendants misuse AI products to maintain monopolies.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual prisoner bringing pro se antitrust lawsuit
parties.defendant_description: Multiple high-tech and oil corporations

claims.claim: Defendants engaged in antitrust violations by creating and maintaining monopolies in high-tech and oil markets, including through misuse of AI products.
claims.legal_basis: Federal antitrust law (e.g., Sherman and related antitrust statutes) requiring antitrust injury and harm to competition.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice for lack of antitrust standing and speculative, non-cognizable injuries; court found no harm to competition alleged and no amendment could cure defects.

claims.claim: Defendants participated in numerous unspecified antitrust activities related to their AI products and market dominance.
claims.legal_basis: General federal antitrust principles requiring concrete, non-speculative antitrust injury.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as conclusory and speculative; court held allegations failed to state any plausible antitrust claim and could not be saved by amendment.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff lacks antitrust standing because alleged injuries do not constitute antitrust injury or harm to competition.
defenses.legal_basis: Antitrust standing doctrine under federal antitrust law requiring injury to competition, not just to an individual.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations are speculative, conclusory, and fail to state a plausible claim for relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Pleading standards under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 8 and 12(b)(6) requiring non-speculative factual allegations.

case_id: 2022-11-28_USCOURTS-cofc-1_21-cv-01295_ALJINDI v. USA.pdf
case_name: Aljindi v. United States
ai_relevance: Dispute over alleged misuse of AI-related scientific work and concepts.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual researcher and author
parties.defendant_description: Federal government of the United States

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on government use of his scientific work on Information Security, Artificial Intelligence, and Legacy Information Systems.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law under the Copyright Act (28 U.S.C. § 1498(b) jurisdiction in Court of Federal Claims).
claims.outcome: Dismissed for failure to state a plausible claim; court held he sought protection for uncopyrightable ideas, concepts, and principles, not specific protected expression.

claims.claim: Request for summary judgment in his favor on the alleged copyright infringement.
claims.legal_basis: Rule-based motion for summary judgment in the Court of Federal Claims (RCFC 56).
claims.outcome: Denied as futile because underlying copyright infringement claim was legally insufficient and dismissed.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff’s allegations concern uncopyrightable subject matter—ideas, concepts, principles, and discoveries, not protectable expression.
defenses.legal_basis: Copyright Act limitation: 17 U.S.C. § 102(b) (ideas, procedures, processes, systems, methods of operation, concepts, principles, or discoveries not protected).

defenses.defense: Complaint fails to state a plausible claim for relief.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted (RCFC 12(b)(6), analogous to Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6)).

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_18-cv-07246_CCC Intelligent Solutions Inc v. Tractable Inc..pdf
case_name: CCC Information Services Inc. v. Tractable Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute over AI system using images to generate automated repair estimates

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation providing auto-insurance estimating software platform
parties.defendant_description: Company offering AI-based vehicle damage assessment tools

claims.claim: Fraudulent access and use of CCC’s proprietary CCC ONE software and data for Tractable’s benefit
claims.legal_basis: Fraud and misrepresentation; unauthorized access to proprietary software and data (state common law and related statutory theories)
claims.outcome: Ongoing; in this decision, court only addressed and denied Tractable’s motion to compel arbitration, allowing CCC’s claims to proceed in court

claims.claim: Breach or invalidity of any purported agreement, including arbitration provisions, arising from Tractable’s fraudulent access
claims.legal_basis: Contract law principles regarding assent, fraud in the inducement, and formation of agreements
claims.outcome: Court held there was no valid agreement to arbitrate between CCC and Tractable, so CCC’s claims are not subject to arbitration and may proceed in litigation

defenses.defense: CCC’s claims must be resolved through arbitration under an applicable arbitration clause
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Arbitration Act and contract law enforcing arbitration agreements
defenses.defense_outcome: Rejected; court found no valid arbitration agreement between CCC and Tractable due to fraudulent circumstances and lack of assent

case_id: 2019-05-07_USCOURTS-cand-5_18-cv-04327_Lamont v. Conner et al.pdf
case_name: Lamont v. Conner et al.
ai_relevance: Alleged misuse of plaintiff’s confidential information to enhance Google’s AI capabilities.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual alleging trade secret misappropriation
parties.defendant_description: Corporate defendants associated with Google and its investments

claims.claim: Misappropriation of trade secrets related to technology allegedly shared with Google Ventures to enhance Google’s AI capabilities.
claims.legal_basis: Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 (DTSA) and analogous trade secret principles.
claims.outcome: Court found plaintiff failed to show likelihood of success on the merits at the preliminary injunction stage; no injunction issued.

claims.claim: Request for preliminary injunction to stop Google Ventures and Alphabet Inc. from using or disclosing the alleged trade secrets and to preserve the status quo during litigation.
claims.legal_basis: Equitable remedy standards for preliminary injunction under federal law (likelihood of success, irreparable harm, balance of equities, public interest).
claims.outcome: Motion for preliminary injunction denied; court held plaintiff did not clearly demonstrate strong likelihood of success on trade secret claims or irreparable harm.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to show a likelihood of success on the merits of his trade secret misappropriation claims.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring clear showing of likely success on the merits.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to demonstrate irreparable harm absent an injunction.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal preliminary injunction standard requiring proof of irreparable harm.

case_id: 2025-07-01_USCOURTS-cand-5_24-cv-04257_Kemp v. Meta Platforms Inc..pdf
case_name: Kemp v. Meta Platforms Inc.
ai_relevance: Plaintiff alleges Meta’s AI intercepted and misused his communications.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual federal prisoner and pro se litigant
parties.defendant_description: Social media and technology corporation

claims.claim: Meta unlawfully accessed, stored, and misused his electronic communications between 2015 and 2021.
claims.legal_basis: Stored Communications Act (SCA), 18 U.S.C. §§ 2701 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata based on prior lawsuit involving same parties and transactional facts.

claims.claim: Meta unlawfully intercepted his electronic communications and used them, including for advertising or other purposes, without authorization.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Wiretap Act, 18 U.S.C. §§ 2510 et seq.
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata because the same interception allegations were previously litigated and resolved on the merits.

claims.claim: Meta’s conduct violated his privacy and related rights under the Florida Constitution.
claims.legal_basis: Florida Constitution (state constitutional privacy and related provisions).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice as barred by res judicata due to prior final judgment on substantially identical claims against Meta.

defenses.defense: Claims are precluded because they were already litigated in a prior action between the same parties involving the same alleged interception and misuse of communications.
defenses.legal_basis: Res judicata / claim preclusion under federal common law.

case_id: 2020-11-30_USCOURTS-azd-2_20-mc-00039_Spider Labs Limited v. Doe.pdf
case_name: Spider Labs Limited v. Doe
ai_relevance: Dispute concerns allegedly defamatory statements about Spider Labs’ AI technology.

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation offering AI-related technology and services
parties.defendant_description: Anonymous individual online speaker

claims.claim: Defamation based on online statements criticizing Spider Labs’ AI technology and business practices.
claims.legal_basis: State defamation law; request for subpoena to identify anonymous speaker to pursue defamation claim.
claims.outcome: Court found Spider Labs failed to show a prima facie case of defamation; subpoena to identify Doe was quashed and motion for reconsideration was denied.

claims.claim: Motion to compel third party (GoDaddy) via subpoena to disclose John Doe’s identity.
claims.legal_basis: Procedural rules for third‑party subpoenas in aid of anticipated civil action; limited by First Amendment protections for anonymous speech.
claims.outcome: Subpoena previously quashed; on reconsideration the court refused to reinstate it, leaving Doe’s identity protected.

claims.claim: Motion for reconsideration of order granting motion to quash subpoena.
claims.legal_basis: Federal and local rules governing reconsideration (e.g., clear error, new evidence, or change in law).
claims.outcome: Denied; court held Spider Labs offered no new evidence or clear error and still had not established falsity or defamation.

defenses.defense: First Amendment right to anonymous online speech.
defenses.legal_basis: U.S. Constitution, First Amendment protections for anonymous speakers absent a prima facie showing of actionable defamation.

defenses.defense: Plaintiff failed to establish a prima facie case of defamation, including falsity and defamatory meaning.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantive elements of defamation under applicable state law; standards for unmasking anonymous speakers.

defenses.defense: No basis for reconsideration because there was no new evidence, change in law, or clear error in the prior order.
defenses.legal_basis: Standards for motions for reconsideration under federal and local procedural rules.

case_id: 2020-10-21_USCOURTS-laed-2_19-cv-01304_Bertuccelli et al v. Universal City Studios LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Bertuccelli et al. v. Universal City Studios LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Plaintiffs’ experts used AI-based facial recognition to analyze similarity.

parties.plaintiff_description: An artist and his design studio asserting copyright ownership.
parties.defendant_name: Universal City Studios LLC et al.
parties.defendant_description: Film studio and related entertainment companies accused of infringement.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on defendants’ use of a baby face mask allegedly copying the “King Cake Baby” artwork.
claims.legal_basis: Federal copyright law requiring proof of ownership and substantial similarity between protected expression and accused work.
claims.outcome: Ongoing on the merits; at this stage, court allowed plaintiffs’ expert testimony on similarity and denied defendants’ motion to exclude.

claims.claim: Use of expert testimony, including AI-based facial recognition analysis, to demonstrate substantial similarity between the KCB image and the movie mask.
claims.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Evidence 401–403 and 702 (relevance and reliability of expert testimony in copyright substantial similarity analysis).
claims.outcome: Court held both experts, including the AI-using expert, were qualified and their testimony admissible; motion to exclude was denied.

defenses.defense: Challenge to admissibility and reliability of plaintiffs’ expert testimony, including AI-based facial recognition analysis, to show similarity.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rules of Evidence 401–403 and 702; Daubert standard for excluding unreliable or unhelpful expert testimony.
defenses.defense_outcome: Court rejected this challenge and denied the motion to exclude the experts.

defenses.defense: Implicit denial that the baby mask is substantially similar to the copyrighted “King Cake Baby” image, contesting infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Substantial similarity requirement under copyright law; only protectable expression infringed if works are substantially similar.
defenses.defense_outcome: Not resolved at this stage; court only ruled on admissibility of expert evidence, not ultimate similarity or liability.

case_id: 2024-11-14_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged infringement by Meta’s AR/VR AI functionalities and systems.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding business entity asserting technology patents.
parties.defendant_description: Large technology corporation offering AR/VR platforms.

claims.claim: Meta’s augmented and virtual reality systems infringe Mullen’s patents related to wireless telephones.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice (Count II); court found allegations implausible and inadequately pled, and denied further amendment as futile.

claims.claim: Meta’s products infringe Mullen’s patents covering artificial intelligence usage in game or system functionality.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice (Count VII); court held AI-related infringement allegations lacked plausibility and specificity, and refused leave to amend as futile.

claims.claim: Meta’s AR/VR systems infringe Mullen’s patents concerning landscape characteristics in virtual playfields or environments.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.).
claims.outcome: Allowed to proceed; court declined to dismiss these counts, indicating that issues require further claim construction and factual development.

claims.claim: Meta’s devices qualify as location-based game devices covered by Mullen’s asserted patents.
claims.legal_basis: Patent infringement under federal patent law (35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq.), based on classification of accused devices as covered by patent claims.
claims.outcome: To the extent tied to wireless telephone/AI theories, dismissed with prejudice; otherwise, related landscape-characteristics and remaining infringement theories proceed for further litigation.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s complaint fails to plausibly allege infringement of seven asserted patents, including those directed to AI and wireless telephone functionality.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) due to implausibility and lack of factual specificity.
defenses.outcome: Accepted in part; court recommended dismissing Counts II and VII with prejudice.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s allegations do not adequately show that Meta’s AR/VR devices are ‘wireless telephones’ or fall within the claimed device categories.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6); insufficiency of factual allegations tying accused products to claim limitations.
defenses.outcome: Accepted as to wireless-telephone-based claims; those counts dismissed with prejudice.

defenses.defense: Mullen’s AI-related infringement theories are speculative and do not identify how Meta’s systems practice specific AI claim limitations.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6); lack of particularized infringement allegations regarding AI functionality.
defenses.outcome: Accepted; AI-based Count VII dismissed with prejudice.

defenses.defense: Further amendment of the complaint would be futile because prior amendments failed to cure pleading deficiencies.
defenses.legal_basis: Standard for leave to amend under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15(a); futility doctrine.
defenses.outcome: Accepted; court denied Mullen leave to amend the dismissed wireless-telephone and AI counts.

defenses.defense: Claims related to landscape characteristics and virtual playfields are inadequately pled and should also be dismissed.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Rule 12(b)(6) for remaining patent counts.
defenses.outcome: Rejected; court allowed landscape-characteristics-related counts to proceed, subject to later claim construction and factual development.

case_id: 2025-03-18_USCOURTS-caDC-23-05233_Stephen Thaler v. Shira Perlmutter_ et al.pdf
case_name: Thaler v. Perlmutter
ai_relevance: Dispute over whether AI system can be legal author under copyright law.

parties.plaintiff_description: Individual AI developer and copyright applicant
parties.defendant_description: U.S. Copyright Office officials, federal agency

claims.claim: The Copyright Office wrongfully refused registration of artwork because it was created by an AI system listed as the sole author.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976; Administrative Procedure Act (arbitrary and capricious agency action); challenge to human-authorship requirement as inconsistent with statute.
claims.outcome: Rejected. District court and appellate court upheld the Office’s denial of registration and its human-authorship requirement.

claims.claim: An AI system, the “Creativity Machine,” qualifies as an “author” under the Copyright Act, so its work is eligible for copyright protection.
claims.legal_basis: Statutory interpretation of “author” and “works of authorship” under the Copyright Act of 1976.
claims.outcome: Rejected. Appellate court held that only human beings can be authors under the Act, so the AI cannot be an author and the work is not registrable on that basis.

defenses.defense: Copyright protection under the Copyright Act requires human authorship; non-human entities, including AI systems, cannot be authors.
defenses.legal_basis: Text, structure, and history of the Copyright Act of 1976; longstanding Copyright Office practice and precedent requiring human authorship.

defenses.defense: Denial of registration for a work listing only an AI as author was a lawful application of the human-authorship requirement, not arbitrary or capricious.
defenses.legal_basis: Administrative Procedure Act standards for judicial review of agency action; deference to reasonable agency interpretation of the Copyright Act.

case_id: 2025-01-29_USCOURTS-txwd-1_24-cv-00354_Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms_ Inc..pdf
case_name: Mullen Industries LLC v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
ai_relevance: Dispute involves alleged patent infringement by Meta’s AR/VR products, including insufficiently pled claims about use of artificial intelligence to practice patented methods.

parties.plaintiff_description: Limited liability company asserting patent rights
parties.defendant_description: Technology corporation offering AR/VR products

claims.claim: Patent infringement based on Meta’s AR/VR technologies (general infringement allegations).
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent law under 35 U.S.C. §§ 271 et seq. (Count I and other surviving counts).
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to these non‑AI, non‑wireless‑telephone patent claims; Counts I, III, IV, V, and IX proceed.

claims.claim: Patent infringement alleging Meta’s products qualify as “wireless telephones” covered by Mullen’s patents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 based on patent claims directed to wireless telephones (Count II).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice on Meta’s motion to dismiss; court found Mullen failed to plausibly allege that Meta’s AR/VR products meet essential “wireless telephone” claim elements.

claims.claim: Patent infringement alleging Meta’s AR/VR products use artificial intelligence in a manner covered by Mullen’s patents.
claims.legal_basis: Federal patent infringement under 35 U.S.C. § 271 based on patent claims involving AI functionality (Count VII).
claims.outcome: Dismissed with prejudice on Meta’s motion to dismiss; court held Mullen did not plead sufficient factual detail that Meta’s products practiced the claimed AI elements.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because Meta’s AR/VR products are not plausibly alleged to be “wireless telephones.”
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) and patent law requirements that accused products meet all claim limitations.

defenses.defense: Failure to state a claim because Mullen did not plead specific facts showing Meta’s products practice the asserted AI‑related claim elements.
defenses.legal_basis: Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6); Twombly/Iqbal plausibility standard for patent infringement pleadings.

defenses.defense: Only partial dismissal warranted; some asserted patents/claims not adequately challenged at the pleading stage.
defenses.legal_basis: Rule 12(b)(6) limited to claims lacking plausible factual allegations; surviving counts meet minimal pleading standards.

case_id: 2014-09-18_USCOURTS-ilnd-1_13-cv-04417_Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA_ LLC et al.pdf
case_name: Vehicle Intelligence and Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC et al.
ai_relevance: Dispute over patent covering an AI-based expert system for screening impaired equipment operators.

parties.plaintiff_description: Patent-holding company asserting safety screening technology patent.
parties.defendant_name: Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC and Daimler AG
parties.defendant_description: Company that manufacturer automobiles.

claims.claim: Patent infringement of U.S. Patent No. 7,394,392 related to an expert system for safety screening of equipment operators.
claims.legal_basis: 35 U.S.C. § 271 (patent infringement) based on alleged use of systems falling within the construed term “expert system(s)” in the ’392 patent.
claims.outcome: Court construed “expert system(s)” as requiring database, decision, and interface modules; this claim construction governs subsequent infringement analysis and limits the scope of the asserted claims.

defenses.defense: Non‑infringement based on narrow construction of “expert system(s).”
defenses.legal_basis: Patent claim construction principles under Markman; defendants argue their accused systems lack one or more required modules (database, decision, or interface) as defined by the court, and therefore do not fall within the properly construed claims.

case_id: 2021-03-29_USCOURTS-prd-3_19-cv-01690_Mech-Tech College_ LLC et al v. Friger-Salgueiro et al.pdf
case_name: Artificial Intelligence, Corp. v. Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro et al.
ai_relevance: NOT RELATED

parties.plaintiff_description: Corporation producing copyrighted TV review capsules
parties.defendant_name: Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro; Friger Entertainment, LLC
parties.defendant_description: Individual YouTube user and related entertainment company

claims.claim: Copyright infringement based on unauthorized reproduction and display of AIC’s television review capsules on YouTube.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss denied as to Osvaldo Oscar Friger Salgueiro; claim proceeds against him.

claims.claim: Copyright infringement claim against Friger Entertainment, LLC for alleged involvement in unauthorized use and commercial exploitation of AIC’s review capsules on YouTube.
claims.legal_basis: Copyright Act of 1976, 17 U.S.C. § 101 et seq.
claims.outcome: Motion to dismiss granted; claims against Friger Entertainment, LLC dismissed for insufficient allegations of involvement.

defenses.defense: Friger Entertainment, LLC was not involved in the alleged infringing activities and should not be held liable.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6); lack of factual allegations tying LLC to infringement.

defenses.defense: Insufficient factual allegations that Mr. Friger’s use of the review capsules constituted actionable copyright infringement.
defenses.legal_basis: Failure to state a claim under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.
